fields.headline: Mols' early dividend
fields.trailText: Michael Mols played only half a game but it was enough to give Rangers all three points. Even so, they stayed five points adrift of Celtic who kept up their own momentum.
fields.body:
Michael Mols played only half a game but it was enough to give Rangers all three points. Even so, they stayed five points adrift of Celtic who kept up their own momentum.

Rangers' Dutch striker Mols popped up after 14 minutes to rifle home the winner after a period of domination by the champions. Motherwell had managed just one win this season and never really looked like taking anything from the game.

Rangers midfielder Ronald de Boer was conspicuous by his absence but Dick Advocaat's men still managed to give home goalkeeper Andy Goram - a former Ibrox hero - a hard time.

Rangers took just seconds to threaten Motherwell when Barry Ferguson appeared to be edged off the ball by Stephen McMillan. The Ibrox side's reward from the incident was a corner and Lorenzo Amoruso headed just over. Moments later Well's Greg Strong prevented Rangers taking the lead when Mols burst through the middle but his shot deflected off the defender.

With just one win to their credit the home side were desperate to make an impact but it was Rangers who were enjoying the best of the early chances. Amoruso threatened again from another set piece - this time a free-kick from 25 yards which Goram only just managed to push away.

Mols had looked dangerous from the opening minute and it was no surprise when he broke the deadlock. Bursting into the area, he spun round and unleashed a close range effort - the ball flying off Benito Kemble and soaring over Goram into the back of the net.

The pace of the game slowed slightly after the goal but still Rangers enjoyed most of the possession. Mols was blocked by Goram for a corner and Amoruso was on hand to meet Giovanni van Bronck horst's flag kick but the big Italian was denied by the Motherwell goalkeeper.

Motherwell's best chance in the first half came from Kevin Twaddle after 26 minutes but goalkeeper Stefan Klos easily blocked the effort.

Rangers' Tugay may have been the hero in Monaco during the week but he drew attention to himself for the wrong reasons when he was cautioned for dissent after 34 minutes.

Then former Sunderland winger Allan Johnston attempted an opportunistic strike six minutes before the break in a bid to give Rangers a two-goal cushion but the effort only got as far as Strong.

Scott Leitch was Motherwell's first player cautioned and Twaddle quickly followed him into the referee's book in 43 minutes for a harsh challenge on Reyna.

Mols was replaced at the interval but it was still one-way traffic. Rangers were at their most dangerous at set-pieces and came close from a van Bronckhorst corner in 51 minutes - Billy Dodds at full stretch to nod just over the crossbar. Then Johnston set up Reyna and the American unleashed a powerful shot from 20 yards but was slightly off target.

Motherwell looked far more lively after the break but they struggled to create much in the way of clear-cut chances. Steven Hammell had a dig from about 30 yards but the effort was weak and easily scooped up by Klos after 63 minutes.

Tony Vidmar replaced Reyna after 71 minutes and he made an immediate impact with his arrival. Van Bronckhorst picked out the Australian from a free-kick and Vidmar's header looked goalbound but a vigilant Goram managed to hold the ball.

Rangers almost paid for their relaxed, late approach. The hosts had a glorious chance to draw level on 82 minutes but Lee McCulloch blasted straight at the keeper right in front of goal.

fields.headline: Le Saux sweet for Blues
fields.trailText: The shocks keep coming thick and fast in the Premiership. It was hard to decide what was most jaw-dropping here, Manchester United letting a 3-1 lead slip at home or the wholly unexpected revelation that Chelsea possess guts.
fields.body:
The shocks keep coming thick and fast in the Premiership. It was hard to decide what was most jaw-dropping here, Manchester United letting a 3-1 lead slip at home or the wholly unexpected revelation that Chelsea possess guts.

On reflection, perhaps the most pleasant surprise was that the stand-out performers were both Englishmen. Graeme Le Saux was a strong contender for man of the match after setting up all three Chelsea goals, just shading Teddy Sheringham who was involved in all three of United's.

Le Saux, who also made an important clearance off the line to prevent United taking a 4-2 lead in the second half, should be a certainty in the England squad Kevin Keegan announces on Thursday. Sheringham's England days are thought to be over, but there is no doubt he is in the United team on merit and enjoying some of the most productive form of his career. Claudio Ranieri, the new Chelsea coach who pronounced himself 'very satisfied' with his team's efforts to match United's team spirit, paid Sheringham the compliment of reshuffling his defence at half time because of the damage he was doing behind the midfield line.

In the absence of stomach-bug victim Dennis Wise, Ranieri promoted Le Saux to the captaincy, 'because he is English'. The left-back responded to the honour in the eighth minute by helping set up a scorching opening goal by Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink. In fairness, it was Tore Andre Flo's efforts in retrieving Le Saux's slightly overhit cross that made the opportunity, but when the ball came back to Hasselbaink on the edge of the area he controlled smartly with his chest before his shot fairly fizzed into Raimond Van der Gouw's top left corner.

United don't get rattled by merely going behind these days, and were back on terms within six minutes when Sheringham's clever cross from the right fell for Paul Scholes, who, from a position similar to Hasselbaink's, scored with a shot of almost equal velocity.

A bad-tempered 20 minutes followed during which Christian Panucci, Gary Neville and Roy Keane were all booked, but United raised their game just before the interval - a purple patch announced when Andy Cole outrageously dummied Marcel Desailly with a flick of his heel - and looked to have ended the contest with two goals in two minutes.

Desailly and one or two of his colleagues were guilty of ball-watching as Denis Irwin's pass was allowed to run through to first Cole and then Sheringham, who beat Carlo Cudicini from close range. The relative scruffiness of the score must have been a relief for Ranieri, who after the first 15 minutes was probably wondering if he had wandered into the goal of the season contest by mistake.

United's third was prettier, with Cole darting on to Sheringham's through ball and lifting a delicate shot past Cudicini, David Beckam finishing off when the ball rebounded from an upright.

That should have been game set and match - it certainly was at Everton last week - but Le Saux and Co are made of sterner stuff. United let Le Saux reach the byline and Van der Gouw fluffed a routine save from Flo's stooping header, failing to get behind the ball and letting it slip through his hands. 'That was the key goal,' Sir Alex Ferguson admitted. 'That had a big effect on both dressing rooms at half time. It was slack, you very seldom see us lose goals by letting opponents reach the byline.'

It might not have been the only turning point. Switching Jon Harley for Mario Melchiot shackled Sheringham, in fact a series of tactical substitutions suggested Chelsea now have a coach who can not only read a game but respond appropriately. Yet Chelsea would have been struggling had Le Saux not kept out Cole's 65th minute shot after another nonchalent flick past Desailly, or had Ryan Giggs not shot over late on from Ole Gunnar Solskjaer's cross. In between, Chelsea equalised - and it was not pleasant viewing for Ferguson.

Le Saux once again reached the byline on the left, this time beating Beckham in a race, and his cross was turned back by Gianfranco Zola for Flo to score his second. After dismissing rumours that Dwight Yorke had walked out after not even gaining a place on the bench, and confirming that Jaap Stam is undergoing surgery and will be out for a month, Ferguson delivered his final verdict. 'We had too many individuals, and didn't play enough as a team,' he said. Who would have thought Ferguson, and not Ranieri, would end up saying that.

webTitle: Late goal a timely boost for Robson

fields.headline: Late goal a timely boost for Robson
fields.trailText: The Boro fans were clearing their collective throat ready for 'Robson Out!' chants when, in the 89th minute, Villa's Turkish defender Alpay Ozalan, under no particular pressure, turned a centre from Paul Ince into his own net. A stay of execution then for Bryan Robson but his team have still not won a League game at home this term.
fields.body:
The Boro fans were clearing their collective throat ready for 'Robson Out!' chants when, in the 89th minute, Villa's Turkish defender Alpay Ozalan, under no particular pressure, turned a centre from Paul Ince into his own net. A stay of execution then for Bryan Robson but his team have still not won a League game at home this term.

And they can count themselves lucky to have garnered this point. Throughout the first half, they plodded around without plan or purpose. Villa were sharper and more inventive with Ginola, Merson and Boateng showing such flashes of quality that were on offer in a generally mediocre game.

Admittedly Boro looked better for a spell at the start of the second half and Boksic, the expensive striker, brought James into action for the first time in the game with a header that sent the Villa keeper diving across his goal line. So quiet had been James's first half that he came out early in the interval to get in some necessary practice.

If Boro's goal was a gift from the gods then Villa's was hardly a contender for goal of the season. Dublin charged down a back pass. The ball cannoned off on-loan keeper Walsh back to Dublin and he slid it into the path of Julian Joachim, substituting for Ginola. Joachim may have improved his current popularity ratings by coolly shooting in to the corner of the net.

Middlesbrough may lack a recognisable midfield but their greater deficiency is in defence. Villa's Ugo Ehiogu is reputedly the subject of a £9 million bid by the Teessiders. Villa manager John Gregory hinted that it may not be enough - whatever, Ehiogu stayed firmly on the subs bench for this game. Boro could certainly benefit from his authority in a back line that Ginola turned with ridiculous ease at times.

Villa's weakness was an inability to translate constructive football into goals. Against a side as ordinary as Boro they should have coasted home.

John Gregory said: 'It was disappointing to be caught but the game should have been ours by then.'

A relieved Robson said: 'In any club they expect you to do better at home than away. Up until last season we had an excellent record here.'

That's all in the past Mr Robson. Ehiogu or not, you have a mountain to climb.

fields.headline: Can Bradford afford careless Carbone?
fields.trailText: Is it too early in the season to talk about relegation six pointers? Maybe, especially as this scrappy victory, the first on their travels despite not really creating any clear-cut chances, took perennial escapologists Southampton up to an improbable eighth in the table. Hassan Kachloul scored the only goal from a Jo Tessem cross, Bradford claimed he hand-balled before bundling it home, while television replays suggested the last touch may in fact have come from Gunnar Halle.
fields.body:
Is it too early in the season to talk about relegation six pointers? Maybe, especially as this scrappy victory, the first on their travels despite not really creating any clear-cut chances, took perennial escapologists Southampton up to an improbable eighth in the table. Hassan Kachloul scored the only goal from a Jo Tessem cross, Bradford claimed he hand-balled before bundling it home, while television replays suggested the last touch may in fact have come from Gunnar Halle.

Meanwhile Bradford failed to convert a host of chances and lost their unbeaten home record, slipping to the bottom as a result, in the kind of game they know they need to win to survive. Manager Chris Hutchings said: 'On paper this was probably our easiest game so far and we lost. Now we have to bounce back.'

Southampton manager Glenn Hoddle admitted the game was depressing to watch but took comfort from his team's spirit. He said: 'It was an ugly game, one which we might have lost last season but we won it with desire and the way we defended in the second half.

'There are no targets as such, but I do want us to get out of the relegation cluster, and establish ourselves mid-table. We're eighth, we need to work hard to stay there.'

Good Southampton defending notwithstanding, Bradford failed to win - one exceptional second-half Paul Jones save from Ashley Ward apart - simply because of poor finishing.

Benito Carbone was the worst offender. He had four great opportunities, three coming in the first seven minutes, and failed to hit the target once. His worst miss came when Tessem's misplaced pass sent him racing clear but he shot tamely wide with just Jones to beat. 'Beni's very disappointed,' said Hutchings, 'but at least he's creating chances, I would be worried if he wasn't.'

Hutchings has just 26 pro fessionals in his squad. Six first-teamers are currently injured, another three are out on loan. Carbone has got the ability to turn a game with a single swivel, but at £30,000 a week, probably, over twice as much as most of his colleagues, is the occasional bit of magic too expensive a luxury for a club desperate to survive?

fields.headline: Bolton rescued by Hansen
fields.trailText: A last-gasp strike by midfielder Bo Hansen preserved Bolton's unbeaten record in this hard-fought Lancashire derby.
fields.body:
A last-gasp strike by midfielder Bo Hansen preserved Bolton's unbeaten record in this hard-fought Lancashire derby.

Sam Allardyce's side were undoubtedly on course for their first defeat of the season when Hansen's 30-yard drive took a wicked deflection off Blackburn centre-back Craig Short and left keeper John Filan helpless as it entered the net.

Bolton had trailed for almost the entire game after James Thomas's 47th-second opener, only for Hansen to rescue the visitors with only two minutes left on the clock.

It was a dramatic finale from a team with six wins already under their belt and who went into the match with a 100 per cent away record.

Thomas's first ever League goal arrived within a minute of the start and the Welsh under-21 international took it with some aplomb.

webTitle: Wolves aiming to throw off the shackles of history

fields.headline: Wolves aiming to throw off the shackles of history
fields.trailText: Nationwide League update.
fields.body:
Sometimes history can be as much a burden as a blessing. For every Manchester United creating a mythical 'theatre of dreams', there is a Wolverhampton Wanderers bowed down by the wait of expectations.

And, if the truth be told, even the faithful don't truly believe at Molineux any more. The days are long gone when Sir Jack Hayward promised he would lead his club to the Premiership land of plenty. Instead fans are resigned to another season of mid-table mediocrity.

Indeed there is still a chance that it could be somewhat worse than that. Currently 18th in the league, Wolves today host Norwich City, lying 20th, in a game that could already be billed as a relegation six-pointer.

Wolves boss Colin Lee, under-fire from certain sections of the home support after two years of management has seen him promise much but deliver little, admits as much. 'We know it is an important match,' he said. 'Of course it's too early to be talking about a crisis but it's certainly a game we have to win.'

Lee has never been the luckiest of managers, but this season he has been hit by an injury crisis that would make even Gerry Francis blanch.

Wolves are without a recognised centre half, last year's outstanding player, Ludovic Pollet, is injured and they are also minus Harvard Flo, George Ndah, Steve Sedgley, Simon Osbourn and Scott Taylor. Captain Kevin Muscat is suspended along with promising youngster Joleon Lescourt.

And Lee, who may be forced to play new signing midfielder Tony Dinning in defence, admits his side would settle for a point.

'We are playing through such a big injury crisis that all we can hope for at the moment is to pick up the occasional point here and there,' he said. I think our fans have to understand the extent of the injury crisis is so great that we can only hope to play through it and make up the points later on.'

Still it is not all doom and gloom in the Black Country. Summer signing Georgian Temuri Ketsbaia may return after a late fitness test while Norwich old boy Robert Taylor is also in contention.

Norwich, still struggling to come to terms with the £6 million sale of Craig Bellamy to Coventry, have problems of their own. Bryan Hamilton's side have won only one game this season - 3-1 away at Stockport - and the former Northern Ireland manager admits today's match will be a difficult one.

He said: 'Wolves might be going through an indifferent spell lately but they are still a big club and as such we know this will be a tough and competitive game.'

Still if Lee and Hamilton think life is bad they could always take comfort from Paul Jewell's predicament at Sheffield Wednesday. Jewell's side took the lead thanks to a goal from Owen Morrison but then fell apart, losing 3-1 at home to Preston - an own goal by Des Walker a sign of just how the once-mighty have fallen.

Former Manchester United great Steve Bruce may occasionally ponder the same problem. His Huddersfield side are still marooned at the bottom of the First Division after falling to their fifth consecutive home defeat.

Life looks considerably more rosy for Watford who held on with 10 men against Stockport after Tommy Mooney's dismissal to stay in contention with Jean Tigana's seemingly unbeatable Fulham who strolled past Gillingham 3-0. Graham Taylor's side won 3-2 with teenager Tommy Smith on spectacular form.

In the Second Division Millwall adjusted to life without Keith Stevens and Alan McLeary by putting five past a hapless Oxford United, while Third Division Chesterfield continue to impress, beating struggling Blackpool 3-1.

fields.headline: Said & Done
fields.trailText: Jesus becomes nun, sacks coach
fields.body:
Jesus becomes nun, sacks coach

Atletico Madrid President Jesus Gil is ready to sack coach Fernando Zambrano and become a nun after the club began their first season in the Spanish second division with three humiliating defeats. After last Sunday's 1-0 loss at Jaen, furious Gil told reporters: 'I will do anything in my power to get us out of this situation: become a priest, dress up as a nun, or take holy vows every day.' And, of course, sack all the staff.

Gil had promised frustrated fans a spectacular return to the top flight within a season: during the summer club billboards around Madrid carried posters headlined 'Manchester United and Milan have been down there, too' above an image of Atletico icon Kiko against a backdrop of flames, and a slogan: 'Atletico Madrid: Let's make it just one year in hell.' 38,000 fans responded by buying season tickets - the highest figure in 13 years and 14,000 more than the previous season. 'This is a social phenomenon,' Gil said in August. 'With this kind of backing we must go straight back up.' Coach Zambrano, though, had other ideas: 'We must not get carried away: if we want promotion we have to look at ourselves in the mirror every morning and repeat: We are a second-division team, we are a second-division team, we are a second-division team.'

The mantra seems to have taken hold - and Gil has already put Frenchman Luis Fernandez on standby to become his twenty-fourth manager in 13 years. 'My name is Jesus Gil, not Jesus Christ,' he explained, 'but I will perform a miracle.'

Church-goer Roa riles Bosnich

Mark Bosnich's tedious professional crisis continues to grip the back pages. Following the keeper's decision to reject a third loan move last week, the Sun mysteriously re-ran the so-called 'Lettuce' Bosnich slander story - the tale's second outing in 12 months. According to the story, Alex Ferguson was so keen to find an alternative to Bosnich before buying Fabien Barthez that he even tried to sign Carlos 'Lettuce' Roa - Argentine keeper turned vegetarian Seventh Day Adventist who, fairly importantly, refuses to play football on Saturdays. The story first ran in the Mirror last year, and turned up again in the Sun last week - almost as though someone, somewhere, was trying to humiliate the Australian cash cow by keeping the story current. If Bosnich turns down another chance to leave, will the Lettuce make a remarkable third appearance?

Macca to Boro: no escape

More uncertainty for addled Steve McManaman. Real Madrid last night confirmed receiving a new £8m bid from an 'unnamed' Premiership club - and this time the move, almost certainly to Middlesbrough, could go through. According to insiders, Real executives have finally told £3.4m-a-year McManaman to pack his sun cream and prepare for the inevitable. 'Steve did not want to leave when we first received a bid in August but sooner or later he'll have to,' said president Florentino Perez. And coach Vicente Del Bosque wants rid of the scouser now, giving him a shop-window walk-on role against Malaga last week. Asked after the game what he thought of McManaman's prospects, Del Bosque replied: 'You'd better ask the Englishman that when he comes out of the shower.'

Tales from the Tabs

£4m LEB THROWN OUT Claudio Ranieri has moved to neutralise Chelsea's dressing room unrest by agreeing the £4m sale of Frank Leboeuf to Fiorentina. He'll put the cash towards landing Valencia's Argentine winger Gustavo Lopez: 'We've made an approach,' says Colin Hutchison, 'but not yet agreed a fee.'

LUA: GOBSMACKED Newcastle newboy Lomana Lua Lua says his move from Colchester has made him a nervous wreck. 'I've just sat down for lunch with Alan Shearer and could hardly eat it for looking at him. I can't believe all this is happening. I've never played in front of more than 10,000 people.'

WENGER: SHUT IT Arsène Wenger has told Dennis Bergkamp he can have a new contract - but only if he stops complaining. 'I cannot imagine Arsenal without Dennis, but there can be no special individuals. I am a manager, this is a team game. I'd be working in a circus if I picked players just to keep them happy.'

Thierry Henry says Arsenal new-boy Sylvain Wiltord will be a big star at Highbury: 'In the dressing room he likes to dance and sometimes scream for no reason. This is only the beginning. You will soon see when he scores more goals at Highbury he will do even better special things to celebrate.'

 Aston Villa's Ugo Ehiogu should sign for Middlesbrough within the next 24 hours: 'I'm not going to rush it,' says John Gregory, 'but we'll sort it out.'

 Bradford's Jamie Lawrence, says he wants to withdraw his transfer request: 'But I still think I deserve more money.'

 Charlton are tracking more foreigners to add to Karim Bagheri and Radostin Kishishev: 'We're feeling the benefits of a sophisticated scouting network we set up during the summer,' says MD Peter Varney.

 Tore Andre Flo says he'll stay at Chelsea: ' Claudio Ranieri seems positive towards me,'

 Coventry have had a £2.5m offer for Blackburn's Lee Carsley rejected: 'Lee's going nowhere,' says Graeme Souness. Defender Paul Williams, meanwhile, has been charged £4,000 for breaking an electronic substitute board: 'I said sorry.'

 Derby are chasing Celtic's Alan Stubbs and Coventry's Colin Hendry.

 Everton are still waiting for the Department of Employment to approve a work permit for Idan Tal - Walter Smith should also land Eric Decroix in a permanent £1.5m deal.

 Ipswich are set to sign more Americans: DC United youngsters Bobby Convey and Chris Albright are due to arrive on trial.

 Leeds haven't given up on Rio Ferdinand: Harry Redknapp could take a £16m offer.

 Leicester are still watching Sheffield United's Paul Devlin.

 Gregory Vignal has confirmed that he wants to join Liverpool rather than move to France or Spain: the French wonderkid should sign for £500,000 from Montpellier: 'I am very proud.'

 Stockport are back in for Man City's Richard Jobson, but Rotherham have had a loan bid for Gareth Taylor rejected.

 Auxerre's Philippe Mexes says he's flattered by Manchester United's interest, but wants to wait a year.

 Middlesbrough are chasing Australian defender Simon Colosimo.

 Newcastle boss Bobby Robson has told Kieron Dyer to start scoring: 'He looks like he wants to put everything in with a slide rule instead of ramming it home with a sledge-hammer.'

 Australian wonder-teen Anthony Danze has rejected a move to Southampton  Sunderland could sell Darren Holloway to Wimbledon in a £1m deal.  Tottenham won't be spending until the transfer market is secured: 'We're not going to throw money down the drain. The market is frozen,' says George Graham.

 West Ham are listening to massive sponsorship offers for their new Japanese star Tsuneyasu Miyamoto.

fields.headline: Will it be famous?
fields.standfirst: Old Wembley's cachet was fame, but can the new one ever match it?
fields.trailText: Old Wembley's cachet was fame, but can the new one ever match it? wonders Tom Watt
fields.body:
There is nothing more daunting than trying to replace a legend. Who now remembers the Blackpool right-winger who followed Stanley Matthews or the playmaker who took the shirt from Bobby Charlton at Manchester United? So what chance has the new Wembley, following in the shadow of the old Empire Stadium with its twin towers?

Probably not much, actually. Already questions are being asked such as: will it be as good as the Stade de France? Is it likely to be much better than Old Trafford? Or even Arsenal's planned replacement for Highbury?

When the stadium was built in 1923 such contemporary comparisons were unnecessary. Wembley was compared favourably with the Roman Colosseum - Wembley was bigger, of course - and the amphitheatre at Nimes. It was then the finest stadium in the world and there must be doubt, already, if the new stadium will ever be called that.

When I was commissioned to write Wembley's story, I found that the reality of Wembley matched the legend and indeed the title of the book, The Greatest Stage, because of the great events and performers that have been through its doors - and not merely football. The affection the old stadium is held in by many great stars is powerful testimony.

But time has been running out for the old stadium for years. The Taylor Report which followed the Hillsborough disaster in 1989, was crucial to Wembley's fate. Once Wembley was turned all-seat it became all too obvious that the place was designed with terracing in mind. And, when people sit to watch a sporting event, they don't feel so intimately involved with what's happening. So what do they do? They look around... and when they started looking around at Wembley, it became obvious that the place was tatty.

And then there is the question of the towers, and what a vexed question it became. When I started writing the Wembley book, it was still thought the towers would be retained in some form, to give the new stadium a gateway or some link with the old ground. Not now - it was decided it was impossible to retain the towers.

That is a big decision because Wembley, in so many ways, is the twin towers. They are the stamp of the place - they are the stadium architectural equivalent of the Coke bottle. Unique and instantly recognisable.

It may be the people who are now running, designing and building the new Wembley do not think it is important that a sense of tradition from the world's most famous stadium is carried forward into the new development. They may not think that the cachet associated with the towers is crucial. If not, fair enough - but surely retaining the towers in some way would have been the perfect way to link the past with the future.

Down the years, there have been some fantastic moments. Football, of course, is in the vanguard, and FA Cup final day is synonymous with the old ground. It may not be with the new one as the importance of the cups in English football has diminished. But for 30 years or more after it was built, winning the Cup at Wembley was just as important for our top clubs as winning the league title.

Something happened, perhaps in the late Fifties when there was a string of finals ruined by injuries (substitutes were not then allowed), to dilute that importance. That - and the ending of the maximum wage - made the league much more important.

But Cup final day stayed special. My first taste of Wembley as an Arsenal fan came in 1968, unhappily, when we lost to Leeds in the League Cup. Three years later in 1971 came my favourite memory - Arsenal beating Liverpool in the FA Cup final to complete the Double. I was one of 30,000 Arsenal fans who all swear to being dead in line with Charlie George when he struck his spectacular winner.

Another final, the 1969 League Cup won by Swindon - 3-1 - against Arsenal, produced an underdog hero in winger Don Rogers. He now runs a sports shop in the West Country and, when we spoke, he told me that six people a week, some from overseas, still seek him out to talk about how he scored twice and won the Cup for Swindon. That fame, that legend, was made possible only by Wembley.

The 1948 Olympics were key to the Wembley story. The Games led to the construction of the modern Wembley Way with the flyover bridge; the modern tunnel, too, with the dressing rooms behind, were constructed for the Games. Before that, players emerged from a tunnel at roughly two o'clock from the 'new' one - and the original area is still used for vehicular access.

Now the time's almost up. What will happen? Who knows, but I very much doubt if the new Wembley will last close to 80 years. If they manage to capture the spirit and ethos of the old place it may have a chance.

It's misguided to think now of the old Wembley as the world's greatest ground. What it became, and remains, is the most famous stadium in the world. That's what the new Wembley, in all its hi-tech gloss and modernity, has to aspire to.

fields.headline: Uefa 'licence to kill' smaller clubs
fields.trailText: Exclusive British clubs with big debts, inadequate stadiums or an unqualified manager could be banned from competing in the Champions League or Uefa Cup.
fields.body:
British clubs with big debts, inadequate stadiums or an unqualified manager could be banned from competing in the Champions League or Uefa Cup in a move which is likely to prevent many smaller teams from taking part in the European competitions.

The threat has emerged during Uefa's preparations to introduce a Europe-wide licensing scheme for every club in the top division in each of its 51 member countries. Clubs would have to pass a series of tough tests before being allowed to play in either of the European competitions from autumn 2002 onwards.

Player misbehaviour could also see a club banned from Europe - Arsenal could be at risk because of their poor disciplinary record, for example - while repeated violence by a team's fans would also allow Uefa to block them. That could hit clubs such as Galatasaray, Leeds United, Chelsea and Arsenal. Real Madrid, the defending Champions League holders, could become the first victim of the crackdown because of their £170 million debt. Uefa have already warned that Real would not be allowed to enter the 2002 Champions League if their debts remain unpaid.

Under Uefa's plan to enforce demanding 'minimum standards' for all clubs, the giants and the minnows of European football would be judged by the same high standards, with no account taken of clubs' widely-differing incomes and levels of support. Many of the smaller countries in Europe, including Wales, Finland, Sweden, Northern Ireland and the Irish Republic, are already in open revolt. They believe the plan is a deliberate attempt by Europe's super clubs to make themselves dominate the Champions League and Uefa Cup even more than already happens. They fear that promised 'exemptions' may not materialise, and that failure to comply with the new rules will be used as an excuse to ban them.

If implemented, Uefa's licence plan could prevent classic David and Goliath upsets such as Helsingborgs' recent 1-0 victory over Inter Milan over two legs of the Champions League qualifying round, because the Swedish side's ground would fail Uefa's tests.

The licensing plan is modelled on similar schemes which already exist in France and Germany, where clubs are not allowed to go deeply into the red. Uefa's plan requires clubs to have healthy finances, submit to regular financial checks and let auditors inspect their books. With financial secrecy endemic in football, tension is guaranteed.

Even successful managers could be hit by Uefa's insistence that 'all team coaches must have the requisite coaching qualifications - the new Uefa Pro licence-holder.' Underqualified managers would have to obtain that badge or risk a ban on coaching players.

Clubs from Scotland, Wales and Ireland are the most likely casualties of the licensing proposals, but even medium-size clubs in England and Scotland could suffer as a result. For example, when Liverpool abandon Anfield for their planned new home, they will have to incorporate extensive media facilities into the new ground, including a 150-seat press box, three television studios and a 300-seat media working room. West Ham, who played in last season's Uefa Cup, would have to provide the same in their new West Stand at Upton Park.

Hearts of Edinburgh, who will try to overturn a 1-0 Uefa Cup deficit against Stuttgart this Thursday, illustrate the problems facing small and medium-size clubs if Uefa press ahead with the plan. 'Our pitch would be too short, our media facilities inadequate and our coaching standards would not be deemed sufficient because the criteria that Uefa have set out are hugely demanding,' said chairman Chris Robinson.

'Our ground is landlocked and the only way to lengthen our pitch would be to knock down the stands behind either goal, which clearly isn't an option.

'These requirements are fine if it's Manchester United playing Barcelona, but for Barry Town playing Norkopping they are no use. Minimum-quality criteria for football by definition favours the bigger clubs.

'Improving facilities for fans, sponsors and the media is fine, but football should be about the two teams on the pitch and not the sort of ground they have got. Ambitious clubs must not be held back by these criteria,' said the Tynecastle chairman.

If it happens, Bohemians of Ireland may in future be banned from taking part in the Uefa Cup. They caused a minor sensation last Thursday by beating Kaiserslautern 1-0 in Germany, but still lost 3-2 on aggregate. Bohemians' tiny Dalymount Park ground in Dublin holds just 11,000 people, only 2,800 of its 3,000 seats are covered - the Uefa demand is 15,000 for European games - and the club has no money to bring it up to Uefa standards.

The licensing plan is set out in a 25-page Uefa document, which top clubs are now studying. A licence, obtained from a team's national FA, will be needed to play European football.

It says that the threat of a club going bankrupt midway through a season, and not being able to fulfil its fixtures, is a major reason to bring in a licensing system. If that happened, 'the credibility and image of sport as a whole would suffer considerable damage; sponsors, investors, TV stations, the media and, not least, the spectators would stay away,' says Uefa.

So would Uefa ban hugely-indebted Real Madrid? Speaking after the Spaniards spent £37m in the summer buying Luis Figo from Barcelona, Uefa deputy general secretary Markus Struder warned that if Real had not solved their financial problems by 2002, they would have 'no chance' of entering the Champions League.

Dynamo Kiev, who regularly reach the latter stages of the Champions League, could also be at risk. Their ground is antiquated and there is concern that much of the income from European campaigns and selling players such as Andrei Shevchenko and Sergei Rebrov simply disappears. They would be forced to open up their books to auditors.

Scotland is likely to pilot the licensing system from next season, with Scottish FA inspectors visiting Premier Division grounds to see if they meet Uefa's criteria.

David Bowen, general secretary of the Northern Irish Football Association, said: 'There's a general feeling among the smaller FAs in Uefa that the big boys don't want our teams playing in the European cup competitions. The squeeze is on.'

webTitle: Andrew Rawnsley on telling the inside story of Blair and Brown

fields.headline: Just flesh and blood
fields.standfirst:
The Observer's Andrew Rawnsley has rocked the Government with his explosive new book about the relationships at the heart of New Labour. Here for the first time he explains why he wrote it and what it reveals about the nature of power.

Special report: New Labour in power
Latest ICM polls
fields.trailText: The Observer's Andrew Rawnsley has rocked the Government with his explosive new book about the relationships at the heart of New Labour. Here for the first time he explains why he wrote it and what it reveals about the nature of power.
fields.body:
In politics - and, as I have discovered in the past fortnight, in the publishing of books - timing is everything. I wanted Servants of the People to show how New Labour really works from the inside. Like any author, naturally I hoped there would be an appetite for a contemporary account, revealing and rounded, of the relationships at the top of the Government and how they entangle with the making of policy. I was not going to be disappointed if people described the book as incendiary. What I never quite anticipated was that it would light the fires it has since The Observer began serialising the book. Nor could I know - I confess this was simple luck - that it would be published just at the moment when New Labour suffered its spectacular plunge from grace.

A question I've been repeatedly asked is: why? Why did so many people, at such senior levels, co-operate with the book? For one relatively straightforward reason, and another more complicated impulse. If an author is speaking to one party to an argument that has raged within Government, the other dimension wants its point of view reflected in the account as well, and the third angle doesn't want to be missed out either. Why were the sources so candid?

It's probably true of all politicians, but it's especially true of New Labourites, that they tend to talk much more vividly and frankly in private than they do in public. It often struck me, as I conducted interviews, that if they could only translate some of their private emotion into their public performances, they might be more fondly regarded by the country. Indeed, a large part of the point of the book is to reveal the human face of New Labour beneath the suffocating mask of bland sound-biting. These are men and women consumed with high passions and tensions, loves and hates, fears and ambitions, which play out to both destructive and creative effect.

Gathering information was often a simple case of knowing the right questions to put to the people who knew the answers. Journalism is a competitive, frequently cannibalistic profession. I've been both slightly surprised and greatly pleased that no serious commentator, of whatever political complexion, has challenged the veracity of my account. There was, as I anticipated, some ritual attempt at rebuttal from the Government about revelations that wounded them.

So I offer one example of the care I took to be satisfied of the accuracy of what I was being told. It was from a member of the Cabinet that I first learnt that the Governor of the Bank of England had come so close to resignation that the Prime Minister had rung up Eddie George to bring him back from the brink. To hear this from a senior Minister in a position to know would be commonly regarded as sourcing enough for a newspaper story. For the book, I accumulated corroborating and amplifying testimony about the sequence of events from senior civil servants who were eye-witnesses and players in this episode.

And once I had that, I secured conclusive confirmation of the story from the person absolutely best-placed to tell me that it was true that the Prime Minister had phoned the Governor.

I believe there were profounder, some might even call them psychological, reasons for the depth and the candour with which people talked. The tiny and talented group, headed by Tony Blair and Gordon Brown, who created New Labour have never been as self-confident as they have sought to look. New Labour needs explaining to itself.

This is a project in endless search of validation. One of the themes of the book is that the public swagger which has so often been labelled conceit and arrogance is actually the offspring of a deep insecurity about the nature of the project and its durability.

In the early hours of 2 May, as the plane took him from Sedgefield to London to become Prime Minister, an apprehensive Tony Blair said to Cherie: 'But I've never been in government.' We tend to forget - and it is rather a tribute to the Prime Minister and the Chancellor that we neglect this - that none of the key players had ever been in government. The shock in Number 10 is not that they have tumbled in the opinion polls; the surprise is that it didn't happen much, much earlier.

During the long, dream-like period of unprecedented popularity, Tony Blair and those around him were always anxiously awaiting the inevitable moment when the country would pinch them awake.

After the multiple assault and battery on the Government, from the mounting debacles of the Millennium Dome to the fuel crisis, New Labour no longer looks to be in command of events. But the point is not that they have suddenly lost the magic touch. It is that those on the inside have never felt like magicians. The illusionists are best-placed to know what an illusion it was that New Labour was a glossily omnipotent machine always under the masterful control of an assured leader.

That this illusion was maintained for so long was one of the great triumphs of Alastair Campbell's spin.

There was a ready audience in a country that wanted its Government to be a success after the failures of the Major years. And successes, many of them, there have been. Newspaper headlines and serialisations inevitably provide only a flavour of a book. It is inevitable that they will concentrate on the warts, not the all. The Ecclestone Affair is probably the murkiest episode of New Labour's life, but it is only a chapter in the life of this Government, as it is only a chapter of the book. I thought - actually, I still think - that the revelation with the most broadly significant message about New Labour was that Tony Blair felt so wretched at his bleakest hour that he even despaired to one of his closest and most long-standing intimates: 'This is the end. They'll get me for this.'

Was there ever a prospect that he would be forced to resign? No, I'd say none at all. That he feared that he might be ejected from office tells us how fragile New Labour felt its grip to be. Should Gordon Brown now resign? No. The Chancellor does not deserve to be turned into the fall-guy for Ecclestone - and, incidentally, my book doesn't make him so. I place chief responsibility for the affair with Number 10. Solidarity is not one of this Government's most conspicuous features.

One of the striking things about the past week is how slowly his fellow Ministers rallied to the Chancellor when the pressure was at its peak. On Tuesday night, I found myself in the mildly surreal position of defending Gordon Brown on Newsnight, saying that if every politician in a panic who misled an interviewer was forced from office, we would not have many politicians left.

I've been asking myself why this three-year-old affair blew up quite as incandescently as it did. After all, though I hoped to bring new detail to what happened, I thought it was already pretty well-established that New Labour was self-damagingly evasive about the affair. The answer, I suspect, is that much of the media and the Conservatives seized on an opportunity to revisit Ecclestone from a feeling that New Labour had got away too lightly at the time. The climate of goodwill towards the Government in its honeymoon period carried them through without all the awkward questions being properly asked at the time. Then they were taken on trust; now nothing is taken on trust.

That honeymoon was the longest and most sustained for any British Government in history. Time after time, those in New Labour's high command have believed they were faced with meltdown. There were convulsing inner panics and recriminations when Peter Mandelson was defenestrated. The Kosovo conflict - during which Tony Blair performed with much greater courage than has hitherto been appreciated - might have cost him the premiership had it gone as horribly wrong as many in Downing Street feared it might. 'This is shit or bust', as he said.

Yet he and the Government emerged from these crises not only intact, but often enhanced. For three years, the media wrote headline after headline describing New Labour's worst week and Blair's blackest day. For three years, the poll lead stretched on. And yet even this did not leave New Labour content. They fretted that the absence of a credible Opposition made things seem comfortable. The Government - this was the complaint among themselves - was not being given the credit due for its considerable achievements because of the absence of struggle.

Incredible, but true, they worried that they were making government look too easy. So, this time last year, New Labour actually went out to make life more difficult for itself by conjuring up some enemies, the Forces of Conservatism which Tony Blair declared war upon in his Bournemouth conference speech.

Twelve months on, you hear no-one inside New Labour worrying about a paucity of either struggles or enemies as the Government is besieged by aggrieved pensioners, petrol tax protesters and resurgent forces of conservatism. Conference revolt and Cabinet split - headlines which Tony Blair was supposed to have eradicated from association with Labour for eternity - shout from every newspaper. For the first time since Black Wednesday, the polls put the Tories ahead.

The appearance of competence and responsiveness has been battered, and the reputation for disunity amplified by the alacrity with which Ministers have been scrambling to dump the blame for the Government's afflictions on each other.

Given how hair-pulling they were being when New Labour was still way ahead in the polls, if Philip Gould is still writing memos about the focus groups to the Prime Minister, then they must make for very frightening reading.

Tony Blair has turned into another unpopular Prime Minister. His mid-term has arrived later than usual; but come, as he always knew it would, it has. This is what history tells us happens to all governments, but for New Labour these are uncharted waters. A project that has so often believed success was synonymous with popularity is going to be fiercely tested if there is a period of sustained disaffection among the voters.

There are many grounds for believing that the test can be passed. Beneath what the Prime Minister likes to call the passing frenzies, his Government can actually lay claim to some outstanding achievements, and displays fundamental strengths. The economy is healthy. Gordon Brown's war chest is almost embarrassingly bulging. The big tax and spend argument - so long as they are brave enough to make it - is there to be won against a stunt-addicted Conservative Party for whom opportunism always knocks. Investment in public services is growing while the tax burden remains one of the lowest in Europe. Few governments - perhaps no government - since the war have been so well-poised for re-election.

It may even be that becoming unpopular had to happen to New Labour before it could realise its full potential as a government. Now, they will have to find a new tone of voice with which to talk to the country persuasively and firmly.

They will have to summon up the courage to talk about their convictions. The Cabinet will have to become something more than a 45-minute coffee morning where the turbulent dual monarchy of Blair and Brown give other Ministers their message for the day. The party - this, at least, is the fervent hope inside Number 10 - will better appreciate its leaders' achievements now the Conservative threat is real.

They will now pull together or be pulled to pieces. The resentments and rivalries that have too often disfigured relationships at the top of the Government are too bitterly entwined ever to be fully resolved. But the whole is bigger than the sum of the feuding parts.

Tony Blair wants that second term, how he wants it. Gordon Brown wants to be his successor, how he wants it. Peter Mandelson wants to be Foreign Secretary, how he wants it. It may just be that this is the electric jolt they needed; the shock to the system that reminds them of the ambitions for themselves and for Britain that first made them allies and friends.

New Labour's early narcotic period in power was deceiving about the Government. So too is the current climate of apocalypse. On May Day in 1997, Britain did not elect a communion of saints or a squad of supermen. In the autumn of 2000, we are not ruled by a pit of snakes or a bunch of idiots. They are flesh and blood. They have their heroic moments and their desperate ones. So New Labour suddenly looks mortal. Of course it does. It always was.

The appearance of competence and responsiveness has been battered, and the reputation for disunity amplified by the alacrity with which Ministers have been scrambling to dump the blame for the Government's afflictions on each other. Given how hair-pulling they were being when New Labour was still way ahead in the polls, if Philip Gould is still writing memos about the focus groups to the Prime Minister, then they must make for very frightening reading. Tony Blair has turned into another unpopular Prime Minister. His mid-term has arrived later than usual; but come, as he always knew it would, it has. This is what history tells us happens to all governments, but for New Labour these are uncharted waters. A project that has so often believed success was synonymous with popularity is going to be fiercely tested if there is a period of sustained disaffection among the voters. There are many grounds for believing that the test can be passed. Beneath what the Prime Minister likes to call the passing frenzies, his Government can actually lay claim to some outstanding achievements, and displays fundamental strengths. The economy is healthy. Gordon Brown's war chest is almost embarrassingly bulging. The big tax and spend argument - so long as they are brave enough to make it - is there to be won against a stunt-addicted Conservative Party for whom opportunism always knocks. Investment in public services is growing while the tax burden remains one of the lowest in Europe. Few governments - perhaps no government - since the war have been so well-poised for re-election. It may even be that becoming unpopular had to happen to New Labour before it could realise its full potential as a government. Now, they will have to find a new tone of voice with which to talk to the country persuasively and firmly. They will have to summon up the courage to talk about their convictions. The Cabinet will have to become something more than a 45-minute coffee morning where the turbulent dual monarchy of Blair and Brown give other Ministers their message for the day. The party - this, at least, is the fervent hope inside Number 10 - will better appreciate its leaders' achievements now the Conservative threat is real. They will now pull together or be pulled to pieces. The resentments and rivalries that have too often disfigured relationships at the top of the Government are too bitterly entwined ever to be fully resolved. But the whole is bigger than the sum of the feuding parts. Tony Blair wants that second term, how he wants it. Gordon Brown wants to be his successor, how he wants it. Peter Mandelson wants to be Foreign Secretary, how he wants it. It may just be that this is the electric jolt they needed; the shock to the system that reminds them of the ambitions for themselves and for Britain that first made them allies and friends. New Labour's early narcotic period in power was deceiving about the Government. So too is the current climate of apocalypse. On May Day in 1997, Britain did not elect a communion of saints or a squad of supermen. In the autumn of 2000, we are not ruled by a pit of snakes or a bunch of idiots. They are flesh and blood. They have their heroic moments and their desperate ones. So New Labour suddenly looks mortal. Of course it does. It always was.

fields.headline: They think it's all over...
fields.standfirst: From the World Cup Final to a night at the dogs, Wembley has seen it all in 77 years.  Observer Sport tracks down some of the stars - and an interloper - who left their mark on the world's most famous stadium
fields.trailText: From the World Cup Final to a night at the dogs - we track down some of the stars who left their mark on the world's most famous stadium.
fields.body:
Evreyone has favourite Wembley memories. Especially the great goals - and the television age has preserved the bulk of post-war efforts on film or videotape. Few can match Ricky Villa's 1981 FA Cup winning effort for Tottenham against Manchester City in terms of sheer skill and audacity. But none can match Geoff Hurst's 1966 World Cup final hat-trick for drama and controversy.

His second goal, England's third, will be talked about forever. Into extra time at 2-2, Alan Ball crosses from the right, Hurst swivels and shoots - in off the crossbar. But was it over the line? 'I believe very strongly it was in,' said Hurst - now Sir Geoffrey and ready to welcome the Germans back for the stadium's 7 October finale in the 2002 World Cup qualifiers.

'Roger Hunt wheeled away shouting "Goal!" when his striker's instinct would have been to make sure if he thought it hadn't gone in. That's good enough for me. For the umpteenth, thousandth time, it was over the line. If you don't believe me just look in the record books.'

Then there was the sheer power and drama of his third, putting the issue beyond all doubt. The net bulged before the German keeper Hans Tilkowski moved a muscle.

'We'd played two hours at Wembley in difficult conditions on a heavy pitch in a very hard game,' Hurst said. 'When the ball came to me in the final seconds, I was just going to hit it as hard as I could. If it went behind the goal 50 or 60 yards it would have taken a vital few seconds for it to be retrieved and the game would probably have been over. After it went in, I hardly remember what happened next. Someone said, 'well done,' but that's it.'

Hurst and Villa were scorers of great goals, but there were also outstanding feats at the other end. Bert Trautmann's bravery in completing the 1956 FA Cup Final for victorious Manchester City against Birmingham with a broken neck is the stuff of legend but it can't compete with the split-second, gravity-defying brilliance of Jim Montgomery's fabulous double-save that helped to inspire Sunderland to their 1973 triumph over mighty Leeds.

Sunderland, stoically defending the lead given them by Ian Porterfield's 31st-minute goal, were unhinged by Paul Reaney's deep cross from the right. Trevor Cherry popped up unmarked at the far post to power a diving header to Montgomery's left. He dived low and parried but the ball ran straight to Peter Lorimer with the goalkeeper sprawled on the turf. Lorimer shot firmly at the unguarded net only for 'Monty' to spring from the turf, hauling himself left to fist the ball against the crossbar and to safety.

'Immediately after the game I thought I maybe should have held the first one,' says Montgomery - now Darlington's assistant manager - in a moment of brutal self-criticism. 'But when I looked at the tape and looked at the context of the save, I wasn't too hard on myself. I'm grateful that I produced a save like that when it mattered. So many players and teams freeze on the big occasion. I didn't - we didn't - and we did enough to win what was a great game.'

It was Montgomery's only big game at the great ground although many good judges believe he should have played for England there. What made Wembley special for him?

'It's the crowd that makes Wembley different from the Old Traffords and Anfields,' he said. 'As you come up out of the tunnel the noise is phenomenal, like a blanket. Then when you get out on the pitch, you're so remote from the fans, you can't hear them. It's amazing.

'From a fan's point of view, the facilities are abysmal. But Wembley was special and I'll miss those towers. Apart from my save, the thing that sticks in my mind most about Cup Final day was driving up Wembley Way through a sea of red and white and seeing those fantastic towers. It's shameful that they have not been incorporated into the new ground.'

Another save is remembered more for the failure of the striker than the importance of the block. Ten year's after Montgomery's heroics, Gordon Smith had the chance to win the Cup for Brighton against Manchester United. Again the TV commentary has eased the moment into folklore. 'And Smith must score' said John Motson as the ball went from Michael Robinson to striker Smith's feet 12 yards out in the last moments of normal time.

Smith, now a Fifa-accredited agent in Scotland, recalls: 'I just remember Michael bursting through, and I moved up to support him. He rolled the ball to me and I took one touch before hitting a low shot. I am certainly not blaming Michael, but if he had knocked the ball to me with a bit more pace I would probably have struck it first time. As it was I took the touch, then sent United goalkeeper Gary Bailey the wrong way, only to see the ball stick between his legs and stay there. I moved in hoping to seize on any rebound, but the ball just didn't come back out to me.

'Yes, I believe "Smith should have scored" but it was nevertheless a tremendous save by Gary, and I know he was always a bit annoyed that he didn't receive the credit he felt he deserved.'

The final ended 2-2 after extra time, with United winning the replay 4-0.

England suffered some of their darkest moments at Wembley. Hungary, inspired by Ferenc Puskas, humbled England 6-3 in 1953, becoming the first non-British national team to win at the national stadium. Another memorable failure for England came 20 years later, when they were held to a 1-1 draw by Poland and failed to qualify for the 1974 World Cup finals. The match - and the Polish goal - was a nightmare for the Leeds defender Norman Hunter.

For Hunter, 17 October, 1973 was a golden opportunity. England manager Sir Alf Ramsey had 'rested' his skipper, Bobby Moore, after an unconvincing defensive display in defeat against Poland in Chorzow. Hunter was in for the return - playing in his favoured centre-back role in a truly big international match for the first time.

Everyone now knows that Poland's goalkeeper Jan Tomaszewski was inspired - and Jan Domarski got the goal that put England out of the competition. What some may forget - but not Hunter, never Hunter - was that he 'screwed it' in the break that led to the goal. England's failure to qualify led directly to Ramsey's sacking and meant the end of Hunter's hopes of making the World Cup finals as a first-choice England pick.

'Poland's goal was my fault,' he says. Only when he recounts the painful detail does he hesitate. 'It was me against Grezegorz Lato and what I was going to do... I'd set myself to tackle with my left foot. I was going to take him and the ball out. Instead I changed my mind and thought I'd keep it in - thought I'd lift the ball with my right foot...'

In that moment, Hunter was lost. Lato pounced and streaked away down England's right flank. Still, when the ball was played for Lato, a goal was far from certain. 'Yes, Peter Shilton should have thrown his cap on it,' says Hunter ruefully. 'Lato's shot wasn't brilliant but it went under him. He should have really saved it, but... it was my fault. I've never played in a more one-sided game and lost.

'But I've good memories too. I recall playing in an England Probables v Possibles training game as a 22-year-old before the '66 finals. For a young player, that was quite something. I loved it. You can keep the Nou Camp and Bernabeu and all that - Wembley was the place. I'll miss it.'

The following year, 1974, Hunter watched as a sell-out crowd was astonished by the double sending-off of his team-mate Billy Bremner and Liverpool's Kevin Keegan in the first Charity Shield game to be played at Wembley. The pair came to blows after Keegan was hit by a bad tackle near Leeds' penalty box. After referee Bob Mathewson sent them off, they petulantly tore off their shirts as they ran towards the tunnel. Hunter recalls with a chuckle: 'It was out of character for them both but Kevin got the wrong man when he turned on Billy - he was tackled by Johnny Giles!'

From an earlier era, Tony Pawson - an Observer contributor for 50 years and a great amateur sportsman in the Corinthian tradition - recalls the glory of Wembley FA Amateur Cup wins with Pegasus.

'Some 50 years ago my ambitions were playing before full houses at Lord's and Wembley. Despite its shorter history, Wembley was the more atmospheric venue. To drive up Wembley Way was more inspirational than walking through the Grace Gates.

'The joy of twice mounting the steps to receive the Amateur Cup remains a dream fully realised. There will be no more Wembley dreams, only memories. Happily for me the dreams remain joyous memories.'

Not that it's all football...

RUGBY LEAGUE

In all the 73 Rugby League matches to have played at Wembley since 1929 - nine internationals and 64 Challenge Cup finals - the most enduring memory is of a missed goal kick.

It came in 1968, in a sodden final between Wakefield Trinity and Leeds. Ken Hirst, the Wakefield wing, had splashed through the puddles to score a last-minute try which cut his team's deficit to 11-10, leaving Don Fox, Trinity's loose forward who had already won the Lance Todd Trophy as man of the match, with the apparent formality of converting from under the posts.

But Fox toe-poked the ball wide, and immediately slumped to his knees in despair, immersing his head in a puddle. 'He's a poor lad,' said the BBC commentator Eddie Waring. Fox never played again, subsequently retiring from his job as a joiner for the National Coal Board at Sharlston because of ill health. He has never spoken about the incident which ended his career but Peter, his older brother and the former Bradford, Featherstone and Great Britain coach, is keen to set the record straight.

'First of all, it was only the foresight of our Don in taking a short kick-off to Hirst which set up the try,' says Fox. 'And although everyone else thought Wakefield had won the cup, I was worried because I could see our Don trying to wipe the ball on his jersey. But there wasn't a dry spot in the house. If I could, I'd have gone on that field and let him wipe the ball on my shirt.

'He was devastated. Not for missing the goal - as he said, everybody misses the odd kick from under the posts. But not everybody has lost a gold medal for their team-mates. That's a measure of our Don. Only a great man would think of their mates in that predicament.'

Don Fox still lives in Featherstone - no doubt with, at best, mixed emotions and memories of Wembley.

RUGBY UNION

Union's links with Wembley are far more limited than League's - yet one of the British game's most momentous matches took place beneath the twin towers. For a change, the 'home' side were Wales and the vanquished visitors England.

It was 11 April, 1999 when Wales ended their popular, but temporary, tenancy at Wembley during the construction of The Millennium Stadium in Cardiff. On a sunny Sunday afternoon, Grand-Slam-chasing England took on Wales in the last Five Nations match of the season and - with Italy due to join the competition in 2000 - the last in its history.

Despite racing to an early try-scoring lead, England could not escape the range of Neil Jenkins's boot and were only six points ahead as the game went into injury time. Wales won a line-out on the English 22 and Rob Howley fed Scott Quinnell on a set move. Quinnell juggled the ball, which threw the English defence, and sent Scott Gibbs on a dancing rampage through the resultant gap, past four defenders and over the try-line. Jenkins's conversion gave Wales the most famous of victories.

'I also played there in the 1996 Rugby League Challenge Cup,' says Gibbs, 'which was an incredible experience. It's the most famous football ground in the world. But to beat England there in the last minute, with us as the underdogs against the Grand Slam contenders: I wish it could always be like that. Before the game, the English management were asking which way up the steps the England team should go after the game. The ribbons were on the Five Nations trophy.'

Howley, Wales's captain for the day, remembers it with equal fondness: 'It's just unbelievable to think that all those players have changed in the same changing rooms... and when we walked out, the atmosphere was electric.'

THE OLYMPICS

The Games came to Wembley in 1948 when London was the host city. When Dutch sprinter Fanny Blankers-Koen arrived her first impression was: 'Well it looked all right. We didn't think too much of it, really. I never expected to achieve anything big there.'

The 30-year-old mother of two was not alone in considering herself an outsider. 'The British team manager Jack Crump had written me off in a magazine article, said I was too old,' says Blankers-Koen, now 82. 'It didn't bother me. I thought that he might be right!' she laughs. But he could not have been more wrong.

She won the 100m by a distance and followed up in the 80m hurdles, the 200m and the 4x100m relay- still the only female athlete to have won four gold medals at one Games. She recently travelled to Monte Carlo to receive the Female Athlete of the Century award. 'I'd never expected them to choose an old git like me', she says.

BOXING

The final round of the fight at Wembley Stadium in September 1995 was one of the most memorable in modern boxing history. In the ring in the middle of the turf were Frank Bruno and the American, Oliver McCall, and with one round left Bruno was three minutes away from winning the world heavyweight title. He was exhausted, though, and the crowd of 30,000 was standing, willing the British man to victory.

Bruno had been at Wembley before - in 1986 - when he failed to take the world title from Tim Witherspoon. There had been no boxing on the pitch at Wembley for 23 years before then. The previous fight was the 1963 non-title meeting between Henry Cooper and the then Cassius Clay in which Cooper connected with a left hook that dropped Clay. Sadly, Our 'Enery was cut and the fight was stopped, yet Cooper's solitary success has remained a talking point.

But the mood of the fans in the stadium when Bruno was raised from his stool at the start of round 12 and sent to successfully survive the final three minutes is the ultimate Wembley boxing moment. For everybody knew that Bruno was just one punch from defeat.

SPEEDWAY

Wembley became a big stage for speedway - much to the irritation of Walter Winterbottom, England's first football manager. He said 'that motorbike stuff' damaged the flanks of the pitch. But it is fondly recalled by one great champion,Ole Olsen. He won two world titles at Wembley - in 1975 and again three years later - when he triumphed before 93,000 fans at the Golden Jubilee world championship.

'I loved Wembley,' says Olsen who heads the Speedway Grand Prix Association in his native Copenhagen. 'It was extremely narrow coming out of the corners so you had to hit the right spot. What I remember best is coming out of that tunnel - a tremendous feeling when there were a lot of people there. And there usually were.'

But it was different when, aged 24, Olsen made his first visit to Wembley for the 1971 European Championship.

'My bike broke and I ended up on the ground. I was very upset and some bastard came to me and said it didn't matter because it was more important to win at the World Championships. I did win at the Worlds - but I just wanted to win at Wembley.'

GREYHOUNDS

Many of the outstanding dogs in the history of greyhound racing were trained and raced at Wembley but undoubtedly the sport's greatest moment at the stadium was the legendary Mick The Miller's triumph in the 1931 St Leger.

Mick the Miller, winner of the Greyhound Derby over 525 yards at the White City in both 1929 and 1930 was prevented from claiming an amazing hat-trick in that classic the following year when he was first past post in the final, only for the race to be declared void. He could finish only fourth in the re-run. By 1931 he was five years old and clearly past his best and it was thought he would be retired when beaten in several subsequent races.

But it was decided to give him one last classic outing in the Leger over 700 yards, a longer distance than he had ever attempted. Mick the Miller ran unbeaten throughout the event, winning by a length in the final to the thunderous cheers of a packed stadium - big race events often attracted close to 100,000 - and it was the great dog's last race.

THERE ARE SOME PEOPLE ON THE PITCH...

Seconds before Hurst shot his third goal in 1966, the BBC commentator Ken Wolstenholme memorably observed: 'Some people are on the pitch... they think it's all over...'

One of those pitch invaders wasMichael Richardson, a Londoner who was 17 at the time and a drummer with a rock group. 'I had a seat near the front opposite the Royal Box and I clambered on to the pitch. It was sheer elation. I wasn't a hooligan or anything. I didn't get very far, no farther than the touchline before I was dragged off by six policemen. I wasn't thrown out - they just dropped me back in the crowd. There was a real carnival atmosphere.' That night he played at Tiffany's in central London. 'Everybody was buzzing. Great days.'

Richardson, still drumming, for singer Elkie Brooks, is not impressed with what they're doing to the old stadium. 'Nostalgia isn't what it used to be,' he says gloomily. And if he thinks it's all over for the stage where he briefly achieved fame... it is now.

Reports by Bill Bradshaw, Peter White, Andy Wilson, Michael Aylwin, Marie-Jose Kleef, Oliver Owen, Ruud Hunt, Steve Bunce, Jon Henderson
