I ask him, and I think he does. I'm starting to pass out again. Fillebrown asks me, very slowly and loudly, bending down into my face, if my wife is at the big house on the lake. I can't remember. I can't remember where any of my family is, but I'm able to give him the telephone numbers of both our big house and the cottage on the far side of the lake where my daughter sometimes stays. Hell, I could give him my Social Security number, if he asked. I've got all my numbers. It's just everything else that's gone. Other people are arriving now. Somewhere a radio is crackling out police calls. I'm put on a stretcher. It hurts, and I scream. I'm lifted into the back of the EMT truck, and the police calls are closer. The doors shut and someone up front says, 'You want to really hammer it.' Then we're rolling. Paul Fillebrown sits down beside me. He has a pair of clippers and tells me he's going to have to cut the ring off the third finger of my right hand - it's a wedding ring Tabby gave me in 1983, 12 years after we were actually married. I try to tell Fillebrown that I wear it on my right hand because the real wedding ring is still on the third finger of my left - the original two-ring set cost me $15.95 at Day's Jewelers in Bangor. That first ring only cost eight bucks, in other words, but it seems to have worked. Some garbled version of this comes out, probably nothing Paul Fillebrown can actually understand, but he keeps nodding and smiling as he cuts that second, more expensive, wedding ring off my swollen right hand. Two months or so later, I call Fillebrown to thank him; by then I understand that he probably saved my life by administering the correct on-scene medical aid and then getting me to the hospital at a speed of roughly 110mph, over patched and bumpy back roads. Fillebrown assures me that I'm more than welcome, then suggests that perhaps someone was watching out for me. 'I've been doing this for 20 years,' he tells me over the phone, 'and when I saw the way you were lying in the ditch, plus the extent of the impact injuries, I didn't think you'd make it to the hospital. You're a lucky camper to still be with the program.' The extent of the impact injuries is such that the doctors at Northern Cumberland Hospital decide they cannot treat me there; someone summons a LifeFlight helicopter to take me to Central Maine Medical Center in Lewiston. At this point my wife, older son, and daughter arrive. The kids are allowed a brief visit; my wife is allowed to stay longer. The doctors have assured her that I'm banged up, but I'll make it. The lower half of my body has been covered. She isn't allowed to look at the interesting way my lap has shifted around to the right, but she is allowed to wash the blood off my face and pick some of the glass out of my hair. There's a long gash in my scalp, the result of my collision with Bryan Smith's windshield. This impact came at a point less than two inches from the steel, driver's-side support post. Had I struck that, I likely would have been killed or rendered permanently comatose, a vegetable with legs. Had I struck the rocks jutting out of the ground beyond the shoulder of Route 5, I likely also would have been killed or permanently paralysed. I didn't hit them; I was thrown over the van and 14ft in the air, but landed just shy of the rocks. 'You must have pivoted to the left just a little at the last second,' Dr David Brown tells me later. 'If you hadn't, we wouldn't be having this conversation.' The LifeFlight helicopter lands in the parking lot of Northern Cumberland Hospital, and I am wheeled out to it. The sky is very bright, very blue. The clatter of the helicopter's rotors is very loud. Someone shouts into my ear, 'Ever been in a helicopter before, Stephen?' The speaker sounds jolly, all excited for me. I try to answer yes, I've been in a helicopter before - twice, in fact - but I can't. All at once, it's very tough to breathe. They load me into the helicopter. I can see one brilliant wedge of blue sky as we lift off; not a cloud in it. Beautiful. There are more radio voices. This is my afternoon for hearing voices, it seems. Meanwhile, it's getting even harder to breathe. I gesture at someone, or try to, and a face bends upside down into my field of vision. 'Feel like I'm drowning,' I whisper. Somebody checks something, and someone else says, 'His lung has collapsed.' There's a rattle of paper as something is unwrapped, and then the someone else speaks into my ear, loudly so as to be heard over the rotors. 'We're going to put a chest tube in you, Stephen. You'll feel some pain, a little pinch. Hold on.' It's like being thumped very high up on the right side of the chest by someone holding a short sharp object. Then there's an alarming whistle in my chest, as if I've sprung a leak. In fact, I suppose I have. A moment later, the soft in-out of normal respiration, which I've listened to my whole life (mostly without being aware of it, thank God), has been replaced by an unpleasant shloop-shloop-shloop sound. The air I'm taking in is very cold, but it's air, at least, air, and I keep breathing it. I don't want to die. I love my wife, my kids, my afternoon walks by the lake. I also love to write. I don't want to die, and as I lie in the helicopter looking out at the bright blue summer sky, I realise that I am actually lying in death's doorway. Someone is going to pull me one way or the other pretty soon; it's mostly out of my hands. All I can do is lie there, look at the sky, and listen to my thin, leaky breathing: shloop-shloop-shloop. Ten minutes later, we set down on the concrete landing pad at CMMC. To me, it seems to be at the bottom of a concrete well. The blue sky is blotted out and the whap-whap-whap of the helicopter rotors becomes magnified and echoey, like the clapping of giant hands. Still breathing in great leaky gulps, I am lifted out of the helicopter. Someone bumps the stretcher and I scream. 'Sorry, sorry, you're okay, Stephen,' someone says - when you're badly hurt, everyone calls you by your first name, everyone is your pal. 'Tell Tabby I love her very much,' I say as I am first lifted and then wheeled, very fast, down some sort of descending concrete walkway. All at once I feel like crying. 'You can tell her that yourself,' the someone says. We go through a door; there is air-conditioning and lights flowing past overhead. Speakers issue pages. It occurs to me, in a muddled sort of way, that an hour before I was taking a walk and planning to pick some berries in a field that overlooks Lake Kezar. I wouldn't pick for long, though; I'd have to be home by 5.30 because we were all going to the movies. The General's Daughter , starring John Travolta. Travolta was in the movie made out of Carrie , my first novel. He played the bad guy. That was a long time ago. 'When?' I ask. 'When can I tell her?' 'Soon,' the voice says, and then I pass out again. This time it's no splice but a great big whack taken out of the memory-film; there are a few flashes, confused glimpses of faces and operating rooms and looming X-ray machinery; there are delusions and hallucinations fed by the morphine and Dilaudid being dripped into me; there are echoing voices and hands that reach down to paint my dry lips with swabs that taste of peppermint. Mostly, though, there is darkness. Bryan Smith's estimate of my injuries turned out to be conservative. My lower leg was broken in at least nine places - the orthopaedic surgeon who put me together again, the formidable David Brown, said that the region below my right knee had been reduced to 'so many marbles in a sock.' The extent of those lower-leg injuries necessitated two deep incisions - they're called medial and lateral fasciatomies - to release the pressure caused by the exploded tibia and also to allow blood to flow back into the lower leg. Without the fasciatomies (or if the fasciatomies had been delayed), it probably would have been necessary to amputate the leg. My right knee itself was split almost directly down the middle; the technical term for the injury is 'comminuted intra-articular tibial fracture'. I also suffered an acetabular cup fracture of the right hip - a serious derailment, in other words - and an open femoral intertrochanteric fracture in the same area. My spine was chipped in eight places. Four ribs were broken. My right collarbone held, but the flesh above it was stripped raw. The laceration in my scalp took 20 or 30 stitches. Yeah, on the whole, I'd say Bryan Smith was a tad conservative. Mr Smith's driving behaviour in this case was eventually examined by a grand jury, who indicted him on two counts: driving to endanger (pretty serious) and aggravated assault (very serious, the kind of thing that means jail time). After due consideration, the District Attorney responsible for prosecuting such cases in my little corner of the world allowed Smith to plead out to the lesser charge of driving to endanger. He received six months of county jail time (sentence suspended) and a year's suspension of his privilege to drive. He was also put on probation for a year with restrictions on other motor vehicles, such as snowmobiles and ATVs. It is conceivable that Bryan Smith could be legally back on the road in the fall or winter of 2001. David Brown put my leg back together in five marathon surgical procedures that left me thin, weak and nearly at the end of my endurance. They also left me with at least a fighting chance to walk again. A large steel and carbon-fibre apparatus called an external fixator was clamped to my leg. Eight large steel pegs called Schanz pins run through the fixator and into the bones above and below my knee. Five smaller steel rods radiate out from the knee. These look sort of like a child's drawing of sunrays. The knee itself was locked in place. I entered the hospital on 19 June. Around the 25th, I got up for the first time, staggering three steps to a commode, where I sat with my hospital johnny in my lap and my head down, trying not to weep and failing. You try to tell yourself that you've been lucky, most incredibly lucky, and usually that works because it's true. Sometimes it doesn't work, that's all. Then you cry. A day or two after those initial steps, I started physical therapy. During my first session, I managed 10 steps in a downstairs corridor, lurching along with the help of a walker. One other patient was learning to walk again at the same time, a wispy 80-year-old woman named Alice who was recovering from a stroke. We cheered each other on when we had enough breath to do so. On our third day in the downstairs hall, I told Alice that her slip was showing. 'Your ass is showing, sonnyboy,' she wheezed, and kept going. I came home to Bangor on 9 July, after a hospital stay of three weeks. I began a daily rehab program which includes stretching, bending, and crutch-walking. I tried to keep my courage and my spirits up. On 4 August, I went back to CMMC for another operation. When I woke up this time, the Schanz pins in my upper thigh were gone. I could bend my knee again. Dr Brown pronounced my recovery 'on course' and sent me home for more rehab and physical therapy. And in the midst of all this, something else happened. On 24 July, five weeks after Bryan Smith hit me with his Dodge van, I began to write again. © 2000 Stephen King. Extracted from On Writing, £16.99, published by Hodder and Stoughton on 3 October.

fields.headline: Killing time in Britain's jails
fields.standfirst: Suicide is rising among prison's young offenders, and it's our Dickensian system that's to blame
fields.trailText: Next month Feltham Young Offenders' Institute will proudly open its new wing to the media. They would have opened it earlier this month had it not been for what, in the careful language of the Prison Service, might well have been described as a little local difficulty. In the early hours of 6 September, the very day before the press was due to arrive, 17-year-old Kevin Henson from Ruislip ripped up his bed sheets, slung them over an exposed pipe high up on his cell wall and hanged himself. He was the 12th person under 20 to kill themself in a British prison since the beginning of this year. We are well on course to beat the record of 13 such deaths in 12 months set in 1999, a dubious achievement by anybody's standards.
fields.body:
Next month Feltham Young Offenders' Institute will proudly open its new wing to the media. They would have opened it earlier this month had it not been for what, in the careful language of the Prison Service, might well have been described as a little local difficulty. In the early hours of 6 September, the very day before the press was due to arrive, 17-year-old Kevin Henson from Ruislip ripped up his bed sheets, slung them over an exposed pipe high up on his cell wall and hanged himself. He was the 12th person under 20 to kill themself in a British prison since the beginning of this year. We are well on course to beat the record of 13 such deaths in 12 months set in 1999, a dubious achievement by anybody's standards.

A former civil servant called Ian Thomas would doubtless have been as horrified as us all by Kevin's death, but he couldn't exactly have claimed to be surprised. Three weeks before the suicide, Thomas resigned as Deputy Governor of Feltham in protest at what he described as the 'Dickensian' conditions there. They were, he said, 'dangerous and anti-social', a direct result of appalling over-crowding. Because of a shortage of suitable beds, more than 100 young offenders aged 15 to 17 were being locked away for up to 22 hours a day in cells designed for older inmates.

Reacting to Thomas's resignation Martin Narey, Director General of the Prison Service, told Radio 4's Today programme that his decision to go didn't make sense given that they were about to open the new £6 million unit. What Narey didn't say during his sudden bout of exasperated hand-wringing is that the new unit is not an accommodation block. It houses an education and reception centre. People don't commit suicide in education centres. They do it in their cells at dead of night when they are alone - and nothing about those cells at Feltham has changed at all.

Last week Kevin Henson's dad - also called Kevin - was given the chance to see the cell where his son died. 'You could see the pipes that he was able to hang himself from,' he said after the visit. 'How much work would it take to sink those pipes into the wall? The authorities say well, if they want to do they'll find a way, but please, take away the bloody obvious. You might as well hang a noose in each cell.'

Kevin Henson Snr now knows, however, that the architecture at Feltham is only a part of the problem. It's the way the place works - or doesn't - that does the serious damage. He is under no illusions about his son; Kevin Jnr had a major drink problem, which developed after the death of his mother when he was 14, and a long criminal record for one so young, most of the offences committed under the influence of alcohol. When Kevin was remanded to Feltham for a malicious wounding charge his dad saw it as, potentially, a good thing. 'We thought it might be a blessing in disguise,' he says now, 'because it would keep him away from the drink.'

Very soon it became clear it was anything but. Indeed, the regime was exactly as Ian Thomas had alleged when he resigned. Kevin wrote from Feltham about being banged up in his cell for almost the entire day with nothing to do and nothing for company but his own dark thoughts. His phone card had run out and Feltham would not allow his dad to send in another one so he had no way of contacting anybody. Inmates are forced to wait five days until postal orders clear and even then they can't buy anything unless it's a Thursday; as a result he was destined to sit, barred from contact with anybody who might be able to give him any kind of emotional support, for up to 10 days.

'It was his first time there, he was withdrawing from the drink and from the cigarettes plus there was no way he could talk to anyone. Why the big deal about letting us get phone cards to him? He was only on remand.'

The prison padre later told Kevin Snr that he has phone cards for emergencies but he doesn't tell the boys about them. 'He said they would just abuse the service. They might as well not have any emergency phone cards at all.' Kevin had previously been diagnosed with depression but, for reasons that remain unclear, that had not been passed on when he went inside. Instead it would have been up to Kevin himself to inform the authorities of his own declining mental state if he was to be put on any kind of suicide watch. But, in a classic Catch 22, it is a recognised and common symptom of the illness that sufferers don't easily or quickly open up about it. He was, in short, left completely on his own.

The bottom line is that Kevin, like so many of the 400 other children locked up in Britain's secure units - up from 200 just a year ago - was not best served by being there. After years of pushing and pleading, his dad had managed to get him help from social services to beat the drink problem, which Kevin himself knew was his undoing, and a probation officer had developed a complex support and rehabilitation plan for him. The Children's Society, which works with young offenders, has found that such plans have a 70 per cent success rate. Nevertheless, at a remand hearing on 5 September, bail was refused. He realised that he would not be able to visit his mother's grave, as he had done every year on her birthday. And that night he killed himself.

This is not just an issue for the governors of individual prisons. It's a matter of Government having to decide it is bad policy to send kids like Kevin to prisons which are ill-equipped to care for them. But at the moment Jack Straw's Home Office doesn't seem to give a damn. 'We keep raising the issue with Ministers but they are just not interested,' says Deborah Coles of Inquest, the organisation which supports the families of people who die in custody. 'At the end of day, it seems dead children are not an important electoral issue.'

That's the problem. People like Kevin Henson do not make for sexy politics. 'Kevin was no angel,' his dad says. 'He was no help to himself. But he didn't deserve to die.' What he hopes now is that nobody else will have to go through what he and the remainder of his family is going through. 'And I don't want to hear anyone saying we're going to learn the lessons from Kevin's death when it's happened so many times before. It's an insult to the other families and it's an insult to us.'

As the combined forces of the British media traipse about Feltham's new wing next month, the smell of fresh paint in their nostrils, they might like to ask the management of the prison exactly what they are going to do to stop other people like Kevin Henson being turned from difficult and troubled teenagers into gruesome statistics.

fields.headline: Drabble and strife
fields.standfirst: The little skit by Margaret Drabble, the editor of The Oxford Companion to English Literature, has been exposed. And soon there will be another airing for Eng Lit's long-running family feud
fields.trailText: 'PYCLETIUS [c116-c163], Graeco-Spanish geographer and traveller, trading ambassador in Spain for Antoninus Pius. His wise and subversive Histories record with unflinching though unreliable authority details of Mediterranean life under the Romans in the second century AD. Amongst his discoveries were lands "where citizens were as dexterous with their toes as with their fingers".'
fields.body:
'PYCLETIUS [c116-c163], Graeco-Spanish geographer and traveller, trading ambassador in Spain for Antoninus Pius. His wise and subversive Histories record with unflinching though unreliable authority details of Mediterranean life under the Romans in the second century AD. Amongst his discoveries were lands "where citizens were as dexterous with their toes as with their fingers".'

Okay, it's not exactly a side-splitter, but it's a joke nevertheless - a fake author buried among the thousands of diligently researched, lucidly written, real-author entries in the new, 1,100-page Oxford Companion to English Literature; a witty little curlicue in the otherwise respectful work of scholarship.

The entry was written by 'CRACE, Jim [1946], novelist born in Hertfordshire', but the Companion is edited by 'DRABBLE, Margaret [1939], novelist born in Sheffield and educated at the Mount School, York, and Newnham College, Cambridge.'

Margaret Drabble says that she included it in the Companion as a joke and to 'make sure people look closely at the text and pay attention'. But to many, the second, teacherly reason seems more typical of Drabble than the first. For she is not generally thought of as a joker, but as calm, diligent, sensible, stoical, decent; an uncorrupted and unswerving writer standing for stalwart, old-fashioned, northern values; Old Labour, not New; traditional literature, not modernist or postmodernist.

With her shrewd and pleasant expression, her no-nonsense fringe, her self-confident and assertive manner, she doesn't exactly come across as playful.

Appearances can deceive. As her friend, 'TOMALIN, Claire, [1933-], biographer, born in London, educated at Newnham College, Cambridge', says: 'While she is superlatively intelligent and warm-hearted, like an ideal head-girl of the literary world of her generation, I suspect she is a good deal more complicated underneath the surface.'

Indeed, she seems rather like one of her nineteenth-century fictional heroines, like a Jane Eyre or an Elizabeth Bennett, whose passions surge beneath the decorous surface. Drabble says of herself that 'she lives in a state of acute anxiety'. She talks of things 'festering inside' and of the need to 'find peace'.

She comes from a family of depressives and has struggled through dark periods herself (she says that reports that she contemplated suicide are 'not quite right'). She had a tormented relationship with her mother, has an uncomfortable one with her sister ('BYATT, Dame A[ntonia] S[usan] [1936-], novelist and critic') and an often painful one with her critics, who swung from admiration in her early, glamorous years to hostility and derision later.

Once she was acclaimed for writing about women's lives in a way that was new and vastly influential; about the experience of abortion, childbirth or maternity. Later, however, she was labelled a middle-class 'Hampstead novelist' and her thoughtful and ironic books were held up as models of a doomed literature. She is unapologetic about her uncompromising realism: she has written a biography of old-fashioned Arnold Bennett, championed the ignored Angus Wilson, loved Hardy and Wordsworth. Her heart seems to lie with the past. As early as 1967, she was saying: 'I'd rather be at the end of a dying tradition, which I admire, than at the beginning of a tradition which I deplore.'

Margaret Drabble was born just before the Second World War. Her father was a QC and a Labour candidate in the 1945 and 1950 elections. Her mother, Kathleen, who died 18 years ago, was a teacher and a depressive. She dominated her two daughters and her son. When she died, Byatt said it was as if the 'blue sky' had opened. Drabble, her mother's favourite, went to school in Sheffield until the age of 13, and then to the Quaker Mount School in York, which she loved. Always top of the class, just as Byatt was top of hers, she won a scholarship to Newnham, as Byatt had done before her, and left with a first-class degree. She says that at school she worked, but at university she 'played'. She did a lot of acting, apparently specialising in 'tragic heroines', alongside Ian McKellen, Derek Jacobi, Eleanor Bron and Clive Swift, whom she later married.

After Cambridge, the two sisters' paths diverged, but not for long. Drabble, aged 23, married and she followed her husband to Stratford. Here, she had some minor roles, but during this period she thought of herself, bleakly, as 'just a wife'. She didn't know how to cook and she didn't know about contraception; nine-and-a-half months after the couple married, she was pregnant.

She published her first novel, A Summer Birdcage, in 1962, on an advance of £50. It came out a few months before Byatt's first novel and is about two sisters (sisters feature in both sisters' works - in Byatt's The Game, one sister kills another) and was an immediate success. The novels that followed, including The Garrick Year, The Millstone, Jerusalem the Golden, The Waterfall and The Needle's Eye, all examine what it is to be a woman in contemporary society.

The female protagonists, however, are both modern and not: they are placed in an emphatically contemporary setting, but they all have nineteenth-century names (Rosamund, Clara, Emma, Lucy, Jane). They discuss classic literature with each other as often as mundane concerns. As the critic Elaine Showalter says, many of them eventually submit to female limitations. Children are the compensation for surrender. At the same time as she was bearing and looking after three children of her own, Drabble becomes the novelist of maternity and female boundaries.

In 1975, Drabble and Swift divorced. By now, she was living in a large house in north-west London and was a successful novelist. She entered what critics called her 'Hampstead period', writing her trilogy - The Radiant Way, A Natural Curiosity, The Gates of Ivory - which followed the fortunes of three women friends through the social and political changes in Britain in the 1980s. She also worked hard for the British Council and for Pen. She fought against the closure of the libraries. She stood by the school gates of the local state school (she has always believed in 'redistribution and non-selective education'). Claire Tomalin believes that 'she is one of the few modern novelists who has actually changed government policy, by what she wrote in The Millstone about visiting children in hospital'.

In 1981, she became involved with the biographer 'HOLROYD, Michael de Courcy Fraser [1935-], born in London and educated at Eton'. In 1982, they married, but for a while they kept their separate houses. Now that they live together, they still maintain a careful, writerly distance - he works upstairs, she works in the basement; they meet in the middle and at the end of their working days.

The woman who was 'best man' when Drabble married Holroyd, 'BAINBRIDGE, Beryl [1934-], novelist, born in Liverpool', says that Drabble is a woman of great, unswerving loyalty to her friends. Drabble, talking about the Companion, talks of the bond between women: 'Women are not exempt from rivalry and ambition but there is something in the circumstances of their lives that gives them a common bond.'

The Companion is a work of generosity towards other writers, and particularly to women writers, whose entries have risen considerably since she first became the editor in 1985. The sisters seemed to have achieved some kind of reconciliation recently - Byatt won the Booker Prize for Possession and was made a dame, and Drabble commented ruefully: 'Now she's way out ahead in public opinion, and feels better, and I feel OK.'

There were (very grudging) statements of support. Byatt said that 'at the last ditch' they would help each other, although maybe, she qualified, not at the first ditch.

That will change with her novel to be published in January, The Peppered Moth, which is based on the tormented and tormenting life of her mother, the most 'enraged housewife' ever. The novel relies on family documents, local newspapers, even her mother's old school reports. She wants, she says, to 'exorcise all the old ghosts which have festered inside'. Byatt says of the novel that it will be 'one-sided. I would rather people didn't read someone else's version of my mother'. Drabble responded with: 'It's got nothing to do with her.'

Educated: The Mount School, York; Newnham College, Cambridge

Status: Married to biographer Michael Holroyd

Publications: Arnold Bennett: a Biography; For Queen and Country; A Writer's Britain; Angus Wilson: a Biography; editor Oxford Companion to English Literature

His wise and subversive Histories record with unflinching though unreliable authority details of Mediterranean life under the Romans in the second century AD. Amongst his discoveries were lands "where citizens were as dexterous with their toes as with their fingers".' Okay, it's not exactly a side-splitter, but it's a joke nevertheless - a fake author buried among the thousands of diligently researched, lucidly written, real-author entries in the new, 1,100-page Oxford Companion to English Literature; a witty little curlicue in the otherwise respectful work of scholarship. The entry was written by 'CRACE, Jim [1946], novelist born in Hertfordshire', but the Companion is edited by 'DRABBLE, Margaret [1939], novelist born in Sheffield and educated at the Mount School, York, and Newnham College, Cambridge.' Margaret Drabble says that she included it in the Companion as a joke and to 'make sure people look closely at the text and pay attention'. But to many, the second, teacherly reason seems more typical of Drabble than the first. For she is not generally thought of as a joker, but as calm, diligent, sensible, stoical, decent; an uncorrupted and unswerving writer standing for stalwart, old-fashioned, northern values; Old Labour, not New; traditional literature, not modernist or postmodernist. With her shrewd and pleasant expression, her no-nonsense fringe, her self-confident and assertive manner, she doesn't exactly come across as playful. Appearances can deceive. As her friend, 'TOMALIN, Claire, [1933-], biographer, born in London, educated at Newnham College, Cambridge', says: 'While she is superlatively intelligent and warm-hearted, like an ideal head-girl of the literary world of her generation, I suspect she is a good deal more complicated underneath the surface.' Indeed, she seems rather like one of her nineteenth-century fictional heroines, like a Jane Eyre or an Elizabeth Bennett, whose passions surge beneath the decorous surface. Drabble says of herself that 'she lives in a state of acute anxiety'. She talks of things 'festering inside' and of the need to 'find peace'. She comes from a family of depressives and has struggled through dark periods herself (she says that reports that she contemplated suicide are 'not quite right'). She had a tormented relationship with her mother, has an uncomfortable one with her sister ('BYATT, Dame A[ntonia] S[usan] [1936-], novelist and critic') and an often painful one with her critics, who swung from admiration in her early, glamorous years to hostility and derision later. Once she was acclaimed for writing about women's lives in a way that was new and vastly influential; about the experience of abortion, childbirth or maternity. Later, however, she was labelled a middle-class 'Hampstead novelist' and her thoughtful and ironic books were held up as models of a doomed literature. She is unapologetic about her uncompromising realism: she has written a biography of old-fashioned Arnold Bennett, championed the ignored Angus Wilson, loved Hardy and Wordsworth. Her heart seems to lie with the past. As early as 1967, she was saying: 'I'd rather be at the end of a dying tradition, which I admire, than at the beginning of a tradition which I deplore.' Her mother, Kathleen, who died 18 years ago, was a teacher and a depressive. She dominated her two daughters and her son. When she died, Byatt said it was as if the 'blue sky' had opened. Drabble, her mother's favourite, went to school in Sheffield until the age of 13, and then to the Quaker Mount School in York, which she loved. Always top of the class, just as Byatt was top of hers, she won a scholarship to Newnham, as Byatt had done before her, and left with a first-class degree. She says that at school she worked, but at university she 'played'. After Cambridge, the two sisters' paths diverged, but not for long. Drabble, aged 23, married and she followed her husband to Stratford. She didn't know how to cook and she didn't know about contraception; nine-and-a-half months after the couple married, she was pregnant. They discuss classic literature with each other as often as mundane concerns. As the critic Elaine Showalter says, many of them eventually submit to female limitations. fields.headline: Silver service
fields.standfirst: Clean, sharp and bright... when it comes to garden colour schemes, silver needn't be second best
fields.trailText: Clean, sharp and bright... when it comes to garden colour schemes, silver needn't be second best.
fields.body:
There is a problem with silver if you are trying to introduce it as part of a controlled colour theme in the garden. There are no silver flowers. Nature doesn't do silver petals. It mimics gold via yellow and does some good imitations of copper and bronze, but that silvery sheen, which you might think would be well suited to the satiny texture of many petals, simply is not found. When we started our Jewel-garden project, we thought that we could get round this by using suitable shades of white. But it doesn't work. White can, sort of, serve as diamond or, even diamanté. But if you are making a garden dedicated to jewels and our ill-spent 80s, then silver is a must. It is the setting.

In fact, for silver you have to forget flowers and look to foliage and bark, hunting among the blues and greens. There is no silver foilage either, just shades of grey, at its most silvery when polished with moisture. This effect is not accidental. Many plants attain silveryness via tiny hairs on the surface of the leaves, which trap both light and moisture. So, as a general rule silvery, hairy leaves indicate a plant that is adapted to cope with drought. The most obvious examples of this are the felted leaves of Verbascums or Stachys byzantina. Of course, desert plants such as cacti use the opposite technique of having smooth, succulent leaves but also have that silvery bloom.

Walking round the Jewel garden in mid-September, there is surprisingly little silver to be seen. I suppose that we could have incorporated water into the garden as a silver foil (ho! ho!) and there is an attractive logic to that, but it would have been quite a radical, expensive development. For the moment, all the silver must come from plants and the season has no use for silver's coolness or sophistication. This is a time of year when the colours tumble softly from their perch, richly jaded, and with none of the clean hardness of silver. There are the leaves of the weeping pear, Pyrus salicifolia 'Pendula', and the silvery blue stems of Knautia macedonica perfectly setting off its burgundy flowers. The leaves of the annual Salvia viridis - which has been fantastic this year - fade to a lavender-veined silver before turning into straw. Silver for just a week or so, but the phase adds much to balance the garden. The blue grasses, such as Festuca glauca and Miscanthus sinensis 'Morning Light', are still going strong, although to get a decent silver blue from the Festuca at this time of year, you must cut it back in early August.

Miscanthus sinensis 'Silberfeder' has silver-pink plumes that look very good next to the plume poppy, Macleaya cordata. The blue oat grass, Helictotrichon sempervirens, has glaucous leaves and silvery plumes and is evergreen, so it lasts all year. 'Morning Light' is my favourite grass at the moment, with very long, languid leaves holding an exaggerated arch of grey-blue. Not silver at all really but, in this never-never land of the garden, it works well.

There is a serious point here. You must use and judge colours in the garden in context and not by some objective colour wheel or household indicator. Evening light will always make colours seem richer and bring out the yellows, browns and reds, whereas morning light is cooler and best for pale colours. It follows that gardens which catch the morning sun will be inclined to be silvery and gardens that look best in the evening - which is the case with our Jewel garden - must use silver as more of a matte colour, an interval between other colours, rather than as an overall effect. Traditionally, silver is used to cool down and harmonise colours that would otherwise jar. Inevitably, silver foliage judiciously spaced out among the border will do this, but I like to think of it having a more positive role, focusing attention on itself rather than just being a neutral buffer.

From early spring to early August cardoons do this with huge panache. Although most books simple refer to Cynara cardunculus as if it were the only type of cardoon, we have three quite distinct strains in the garden, one dwarfer than the other two, one with very deeply cut leaves and one with much wider, less cut and greyer leaves. The latter is planted as a separate long avenue, between pleached limes and underplanted with wallflowers, tulips and Allium giganteum. I like them best at the end of April, when the blood-red wallflowers contrast against the silvery grey of the cardoon leaves. We have more cardoons in the borders, although by now they are great, gaunt skeletons of their silvery selves, supported by posts and turning tawny.

Another silver thistle that also needs support is the Onopordum acanthium, or Scotch thistle. Like the cardoon, it is a ghost of its former self and is so top heavy that it is best cut down now. Unlike the cardoon, it is biennial, and there are many young plants growing in the borders with rosettes of fresh, silver leaves. They are modest enough now to be moved to a suitable spacing at the back of a border, but if left until spring they will have developed tap roots and are less likely to survive transference. I would always want some Onopordums in my garden and in June they are top of the silver league, by far.

Running a close second is the equally prickly, equally biennial Eryngium giganteum, or Miss Wilmott's Ghost. It got its vernacular name from Miss Wilmott's habit of dropping its seeds in every garden she visited. Miss Wilmott was from Essex, lived about 100 years ago, was very rich and sounds a bit of a pain. But it is a fantastic plant. All the Eryngium s are good, and we also have E. agavifolium, which is doing well but has a tendency to rot off. This is also true of E. bourgatii, which has vivid blue stems. I gave it lots of grit when planted, to mimic dry conditions. I also like the look of E. alpinum, which is the nearest thing to a silver flower that I have seen.

Thinking about it, we could easily have an area of silver-blue leaves and white flowers. We tried white and green and it merely looked like a copy of Sissinghurst's white garden. No good - though the silver-blue would make the white pearly, and the foliage more silver. It also might temper the intensity of the existing planting and give it a cooler, more measured edge. We could have white tulips growing through the young Onopordums, or Artemisia 'Powis Castle' and then later add the Artemisa ludoviciana 'Valerie Finnis'. Shrubs such as Elaeagnus 'Quicksilver', Dusty Miller ( Senecio viravara ), or even Rosa glauca could be used, although we would have to cut the pink flowers off as they arrived. Seems a bit unkind. Certainly Tanacetum argenteum , the Dianthus 'Mrs Sinkins' and the white dead nettle Lamium maculatum 'White Nancy'. Yes to Salvia argentea and Ballota pseudodictamnus, although I don't know how much it would like our heavy clay. And so the game goes on. The real horticultural secret, to paraphrase the Incredible String Band, is to be a joyful player.

My roots: A week in Monty's garden

We have had our winter supply of mushroom compost delivered. This is exciting for all sorts of reasons. First, there's the performance of getting it here via two big lorryloads driven across the water meadows, which is the only way to get anything larger than a barrow to the end of the garden. These could flood at any time and then access will be impossible - the ground freezes hard and doesn't get dry until summer.

The compost makes one hell of a heap - 16-odd tons of lovely, jet-black, crumbly stuff. I would love to be able to say that we don't buy in anything and use just our own garden compost, but I guess that this delivery is as much as 20 times the finished compost we create each calendar year. We use it to dig into the vegetable garden - finding that it works better than anything to lighten and open out the soil - and to mulch the flower gardens. I keep the garden compost as a component of potting compost for mulching trees, hedges and shrubs, and for adding to planting holes.

I turned the compost the other day, or rather did half a heap and then hurt my shoulder so, rather ignominiously, had to ask Gareth to finish the job while I pottered to the raspberries and pruned the summer ones. I love this job, cutting out all the old canes and thinning the new, tying them into a rhythmic row against the wires. I will give them a thick mulch after a decent amount of rain, but not with the mushroom compost, as it is too alkaline. Well-rotted cow manure would be ideal, as that is fairly acidic, but our garden compost will have to do.

The raspberry prunings generate a lot of uncompostable canes and they go onto the heap to be shredded, along with the cardoon stems, artichokes, sweetcorn, summer-cabbage stems and masses of orache. When I last wrote about shredders, I received more mail than on any other subject - all of it saying how great shredders were. In principle I agree, but I have never used one that was robust or fast enough to be viable. Instead, we hire a commercial one every few months and have a day of it. I like having the piles of shredded stuff, mushroom compost, garden compost, grass from the orchard and leaf mould, all ordered and shipshape ready for winter. Then when the rain does finally come the ensuing mud will mean that it will be the end of wheelbarrows on the grass, let alone lorries across the field.

Your roots: Getting your garden ready for autumn

It is time to plant out wallflowers into their flowering positions so that they can grow and get established this autumn, ready to flower next spring. If any are straggly, pinch off the tops to make good, bushy plants. Keep busy with planting spring bulbs. I find this very tedious but it will pay handsome dividends next spring.

Low light levels mean that tomato ripening has been very erratic and poor this summer. Any green tomatoes are unlikely to ripen now, so bring them in and store, on the vine, in a shed or in a drawer indoors. Many will ripen and the rest will make very good chutney. Or green- tomato soup.

Check pears and apples daily, collecting windfalls and gently twisting fruit still on the tree to see if ready. Store unripe fruit on a window sill and ripe ones in a cool, airy, dark place.

webTitle: It's time to pay the price of being in Europe

fields.headline: It's time to pay the price of being in Europe
fields.standfirst: Special report: Economic and Monetary Union
fields.trailText: Is Ireland's long love affair with Europe beginning to turn sour? A speech made in Boston last week by Síle de Valera, granddaughter of Eamon de Valera and herself a minister in Bertie Ahern's government, has sparked off a debate on Ireland's future role as the European Union prepares for enlargement which will mean that its membership will be almost doubled.
fields.body:
Is Ireland's long love affair with Europe beginning to turn sour? A speech made in Boston last week by Síle de Valera, granddaughter of Eamon de Valera and herself a minister in Bertie Ahern's government, has sparked off a debate on Ireland's future role as the European Union prepares for enlargement which will mean that its membership will be almost doubled.

Ms De Valera, who is Minister for Arts, Culture and the Gaeltacht, was speaking at the launch of a book on the Irish in America. She referred to the close links between Ireland and the United States and argued that, while membership of the European Union had been good for Ireland, 'It is not the cornerstone of what our nation is and should be.'

The bureaucracy in Brussels, the Minister claimed, does not always respect the sensitivities of member states. Directives and regulations agreed centrally by the European Union can often 'seriously impinge on our identity, culture and traditions.'

The speech caused some surprise in Dublin and Brussels. It has been an article of faith that the decision to join the EEC in 1973 has been wholly good for Ireland and that the current success of the economy would never have been possible without the huge sums of money handed out by Brussels.

This has led to an almost total lack of debate on the issue. Any questioning of big decisions - for example on the move to accept the euro - has been quickly silenced by pointing to the largesse Ireland has received.

Historians point to other, less tangible but equally important benefits. Membership of the European Union had a dramatic effect on Ireland's national self-confidence, particularly in the early years. The historic dependence and sense of inferiority in relation to Britain was broken. But there are signs that after nearly 30 years Ireland's relationship with the European Union is beginning to change. The reasons, not surprisingly, are mainly economic. The move towards enlargement which will draw in poorer countries from Central and Eastern Europe will mean that Ireland can no longer expect to be on the receiving end of large funds.

In the next few years this country can expect to become a net contributor to the European Union. Very few people have taken in what this will mean. At a meeting of the Council of Ministers in July, when yet more funds were allocated to Ireland it was pointed out that this country's per capita GDP is now second only to that of Luxembourg within the European Union.

Enlargement will also mean that Ireland's political clout will be much reduced. Ireland will hope to keep its own EU Commissioner, but the voting system in the Council of Ministers will almost certainly be changed in a way that will have far reaching implications.

In theory, Ireland remains committed to enlargement and to the movement towards integration. Of course, we say piously, we want to help less fortunate countries to have the benefits which we have enjoyed. But there is an ugly subtext to this debate if up to 13 countries, many of them still relatively poor, join the European Union their citizens will have an automatic right to work here. Ireland has already experienced great difficulty in absorbing immigrants from Eastern Europe and other countries, as shown by a shocking rise in the number of racist attacks.

De Valera is not the only member of the government to have expressed concern about aspects of Ireland's relationship to Brussels. Mary Harney, the Deputy Prime Minister, has spoken against proposals for tax harmonisation and what she has described as 'job destroying policies.' Miss Harney argues that Ireland's ability to attract foreign investment, particularly from large US companies has been dependent on favourable tax incentives. Her critics see this as a code for favouring low taxes over public spending. They point to the fact that Ireland's expenditure on health and welfare services is close to the bottom of the European League.

The call for a debate on Europe comes at a time when Ireland's decision to join the euro is being blamed for a sharp rise in inflation. This now threatens the strategy of agreed wage restraint between employers and trade unions.

The decision by the world's most powerful banks to come to the rescue of the euro may solve this problem in the short term. But the debate about Ireland's relationship with the European Union seems set to continue. In essence it is about how this country dazzled by its recent economic success sees the future.

Should Ireland be prepared to accept more responsibility to help the less fortunate at home and abroad, thus repaying some of the debt we owe to Europe, or will we retreat into the 'I'm alright Jack' mentality which has grown up alongside the Celtic Tiger economy?

webTitle: G7 bets $6bn to shore up ailing euro

fields.headline: G7 bets $6bn to shore up ailing euro
fields.standfirst: Special report: Economic and Monetary Union
fields.trailText: The world's most powerful industrial nations have launched a two-pronged attack to cut the price of oil and revive the ailing euro.
fields.byline: William Keegan, Prague and Ed Vulliamy, New York
fields.body:
The world's most powerful industrial nations have launched a two-pronged attack to cut the price of oil and revive the ailing euro.

Up to $5 billion is understood to have been spent by the Group of Seven countries - the United States, Japan, Germany, France, Italy, the UK and Canada - in an attempt to stabilise the European single currency last Friday.

It is the first time that the British Government has intervened in the market for sterling since Black Wednesday on 16 September, 1992.

At a press conference here yesterday the Chancellor, Gordon Brown - in remarkably robust form after a week of 'little local difficulties' - dismissed questions about if he would resign with the quip: 'I'm far too busy.'

Brown recalled that he had said in May that the value of the pound against the euro 'cannot be justified by any view of long-term economic fundamentals'. That was when a pound was worth 3.33 deutschmarks. On the eve of Friday's intervention, in which the Treasury apparently told the Bank of England to sell at least $70 million worth of sterling, the rate was DM3.27.

It appears that the Chan cellor was not prepared alone to reduce the over-valued exchange rate, but responded swiftly to a request from the European Central Bank last Thursday.

Brown said yesterday: 'I've always said I understood people's concern [about the pound] but I've also said they would not have thanked me if we had moved back to the policies of boom and bust.'

The Chancellor rejected Opec's suggestions that Western governments could help by lowering fuel taxes. He emphasised that the oil cartel had already committed itself to the view that the sustainable oil price was between $22 and $28 a barrel and its member states would increase production to bring the price down to that level.

In Washington, President Bill Clinton yesterday defended his decision to tap US oil reserves to help the price fall. He coupled it with a major heating aid programme to poor families.

Clinton said his release of 30 million barrels at the request of the Democratic Party's presidential candidate, Vice-President Al Gore, was 'good energy policy, good national security and good family policy'.

He coupled it to a four-point crisis plan, allocating $400m of oil heating allowances to poor families facing big winter bills.

webTitle: Denmark on the brink of rejecting euro

fields.headline: Denmark on the brink of rejecting euro
fields.standfirst: Special report: Economic and Monetary Union
fields.trailText: Denmark, the country that likes to say nej, is on the brink of rejecting membership of the ailing euro. A campaign saw supporters of the single currency commit serious errors, but the nay- sayers should not break out the champagne just yet.
fields.body:
Denmark, the country that likes to say nej, is on the brink of rejecting membership of the ailing euro. A campaign saw supporters of the single currency commit serious errors, but the nay- sayers should not break out the champagne just yet.

As Danes prepare to cast their votes on Thursday, opinion polls give the noes a lead of up to six per cent - but the gap is closing.

The yes side is beginning to claw its way back into contention, and the Europhile Prime Minister Poul Nyrup Rasmussen believes that things could still go his way.

The yes camp is hoping that the large number of floating voters - the polls show that 14 per cent of voters are undecided - will turn the tide in their favour. But analysts believe the 'don't knows' are more likely finally to plump for the no camp.

The government, 80 percent of MPs, 46 out of 48 newspapers, big business and the trade union movement are all recommending a yes vote. The no camp is an unholy alliance of the far-right and the far-left.

The polls tell a different story. A Gallup survey out last Friday gave the nay-sayers 47 per cent, and the yes side 41 percent. A Vilstrup poll the same day put support for the sceptics at 45 per cent, against 41 per cent for the euro enthusiasts.

Defeatism has already crept into the yes camp, recriminations are flying and backbiting has started. Last week the Prime Minister was criticised by pro-euro parties for suggestion his side should ask European leaders to guarantee that Denmark's pensions system would not be watered down if his country joined the euro. Rasmussen was forced to back down.

According to Anders Panum Jensen, who heads the Danish European Movement, the episode helped the no camp. A leading no campaigner, Jens Peter Bonde, agreed.'It's not us who have won it, it's the yes side that have lost it,' he said.

The Danish krone is already pegged to the euro. So, ask the Europhiles, what difference would formal membership make? The no camp, however, points to the big fall in its value against the dollar and warn against deeper involvement in'a junk currency'.

webTitle: Serried ranks of central banks force forex dealers to about face

fields.headline: Serried ranks of central banks force forex dealers to about face
fields.standfirst:
Textbook timing caught the markets by surprise and shored up the ailing euro. But will it have the desired effect? Paul Farrelly reports
Special report: Economic and Monetary Union
fields.trailText: Textbook timing caught the markets by surprise and shored up the ailing euro. But will it have the desired effect?
fields.body:
The scent of fear percolated the foreign exchange markets from dawn on Friday. The sharp-suited traders, banking goliaths and multinational corporations deal in trillions daily.

But on this morning, 24 hours before the annual G7 summit in Prague, the dealers drew in their horns. Fearful of being caught short this week by central bank intervention to help the euro, sellers of the drowning currency were for once few and far between.

On Wednesday, the euro had fallen to its lowest ebb, worth just 84.4 cents to the dollar. Barely 21 months after its launch, the totem of European union had lost 30 per cent of its value. But now, rare buying dragged the currency off the floor. By 11am it perked up a percentage point or two. It was the signal for the most concerted action to prop up a currency the world has seen since the Eighties.

Shortly after midday, one by one the European Central Bank (ECB), the US Federal Reserve, Japan's Ministry of Finance and the Bank of England waded in on a euro-buying spree. The timing was textbook, catching the markets totally by surprise. The euro surged above 90 cents as, not to miss out, traders shouted 'buy, buy, buy'.

'To be effective, these operations have to be a surprise, a concerted and co-ordinated effort,' UK Treasury sources said. 'You need to have everyone, the ECB, the US and Japan all working together.'

The sighting shot had already been fired a fortnight ago, when the ECB - headed by veteran Dutch banker Wim Duisenberg - sold 2.5 billion euros' worth of dollars and yen. But the battle lines hardened at the International Monetary Fund's annual gathering, also in Prague last week.

The IMF, indeed, stirred things up early in the week when it pronounced intervention not to be 'taboo'.

And Tony Blair was consulted before - at the Chancellor's behest - the soldiers of the Bank of England waded in to sell part of the UK's $42bn of currency reserves.

On this battleground, one familiar enemy was entirely absent. Before Black Wednesday in 1992, hedge funds spearheaded by billionaire speculator George Soros picked off weaker European currencies one by one before turfing mighty sterling ignominiously out of the euro's precursor, the European exchange rate mechanism. Soros's Quantum Fund made a reputed $1bn profit. And it was a nadir from which the Tory government, like Labour with its Seventies IMF debacle, never recovered.

Today, however, the hedge funds are out of the running. True, the one-time buccaneers of capitalist markets can still call on $200bn of finance. But they were fleeced by the Asian currency crisis in 1998 and the US collapse of Long Term Capital Management, the biggest of all the funds. Most now steer clear of the big 'macro-plays': big currency gambles to, literally, break the bank.

'They're busted flushes,' said John Hatherley, head of research at City fund manager M&G. 'Last time round when we saw a currency crisis, they could make a difference. But most of them have disappeared. Soros has given up the ghost. They're no longer influential players.'

This weekend, however, there's a paradox for policymakers still smarting from the likes of Soros. Their exit means there's no one that the central banks, acting together for once, can really burn. And because it's not the speculators that have driven the euro to despair, their action is unlikely to push it anywhere near the $1.17 at which it made its debut on New Year's Day in 1999.

'The biggest problem with this round of intervention is that you haven't got traders really saying "ouch",' said David Bloom, foreign currency strategist at HSBC, one of the world's biggest banks. 'You're talking instead about affecting huge capital flows of investment into the US.'

The reason for the euro's plight - and the dollar's strength - is the headlong plunge by corporations, pension fund managers and individual investors into the buoyant North American economy. Everyone with any financial clout has bought into the longest unbroken boom on record, investing in factories, snapping up shares, bidding for US corporations.

That flood means foreign exchange markets turn over $1.3 trillion a day, nearly $500 trillion a year. And against that, between them the big four central banks in action on Friday can muster reserves of just $600bn.

That is not to say governments are powerless. 'Rather than swimming against the tide, intervention works best, like on Friday, when it is moving in the right direction,' said Jonathan Loynes, chief UK economist at Capital Economics. Crucial, too, is reputation and credibility. The big surprise on Friday was the willingness of the powerful US Federal Reserve to weaken the dollar during a US presidential campaign.

But consistency is also crucial. Tough words, like those at the G7 yesterday, have been heard before. In 1987, the Louvre Accord pulled the dollar up, and in 1985 the Plaza Accord pushed it down. This weekend, remarks by US Treasury Secretary Larry Summers leave the markets unsure whether Prague really wants the dollar up or down. And that hardly makes for a flourishing future for the euro.

'I don't think they have a hope of reversing the euro's sustained slide,' said economic strategist Jose Luis Alzola at banker Schroders Salomon Smith Barney. 'The aim is more humble - to stabilise it and avoid a freefall. They had to give a signal, because that danger was really developing. We'll see over the next few weeks what difference they've made.'

webTitle: Run-up to Thursday's euro vote in Denmark

fields.headline: Not so wonderful in Copenhagen
fields.standfirst:
A bruised pro-euro campaign faces political battles in the run-up to Thursday's vote. Oliver Morgan reports from Denmark
Special report: Economic and Monetary Union
fields.trailText: A bruised pro-euro campaign faces political battles in the run-up to Thursday's vote.
fields.body:
Tony Blair may have had a tough time last week. But if he wants to know how much worse it could get, he should look across the North Sea to Denmark. There, his opposite number Poul Nyrup Rasmussen is fighting for his life over the defining issue of the age still clouding the UK horizon - Europe and, more specifically, its single currency.

It is not just Rasmussen whose credibility is at stake. Employer and union leaders have together invested significant time and money in trying to persuade their people to accept something about which they are famously sceptical.

The Danes are making them sweat. Daily Gallup polls published by the Berlingske Tidende newspaper ahead of this week's referendum on adopting the euro resemble a jagged pair of scissors - with Yes voters pointing down, and an eight point gap with the ascendant nay-sayers.

The outcome of Thursday's plebiscite has profound consequences for the shape and direction of the European project. A No vote could not only knock the credibility of the juddering currency further; it will also make negative results in future referendums, due in Sweden as well as in Britain, far more likely.

This would throw the heart of the project into doubt just as it is moving from consolidation to expansion. And it could place a new economic and political curtain between the far north-east of Europe and the teutonic mainland.

But the notoriously independent Danes take a delicious pleasure in watching their leaders writhe.

From the island-capital Copenhagen to the remote industrial towns of Jutland, 'Ja' and 'Nej' voters alike reserve their scorn for Rasmussen, their employers and the unions.

Poul Nyrup has blundered, they say. The beleaguered yes coalition is 'ridiculous', 'panic-stricken', 'pathetic'.

For business and unions, the situation could not be worse. Jorgen Hansen, deputy director-general of the employers' group Dansk Industri, says: 'It is important we get a Yes. In Denmark we have almost 100 per cent support for the euro among both big and small business. The unions are the same.'

For their part, unions have warned of 35,000 job losses if there is a No. That represents 1.5 per cent of the workforce.

But while industrial leaders may be convinced, their employees - particularly female workers and those in the public sector - are not. 'As we learnt in the 1992 referendum on Maastricht, they are suspicious of the elite,' says Hansen.

The pro-euro coalition has been using its impeccable network to fight back. Rasmussen has been invited by companies far and wide to meet Denmark's workers and put the case for the single currency.

On Tuesday morning, for example, he was speaking in an industrial estate in the Copenhagen suburb of Brondby, home to Denmark's stock market star, NKT holdings.

This is the kind of business politicians like to be connected with. Founded in the nineteenth century, NKT now employs 6,500 people and is Denmark's foremost provider of telecommunications. Its shares rose 600 per cent after it spun off a chip designer to Intel earlier this year for $1.25 billion.

Managing director Tom Knutzen represents the views of the frustrated majority of Europhile businessmen who are desperate to see a Yes vote on Thursday. 'This morning the Prime Minister in person was extremely dedicated and strongly believed in his arguments,' he says. 'In the Danish press it has been more difficult.'

Similar concerns are found away from the Copenhagen media melée. Grundfos has been making domestic and industrial pumps in the town of Bjerringbro in Jutland since 1945, and now has about 10 per cent of the global market.

This is another Danish success story. Investment has made the huge factories which dominate Bjerringbro - including an inhouse chip plant - into some of the most highly automated and modern facilities in Denmark. Rasmussen has taken his roadshow there too.

Executive vice president Jens Jorgen Madsen says: 'We can't imagine that anyone can dream of saying No to the euro.' But he adds: 'The campaigning and debate have been at an ignorant level.'

NKT and Grundfos have similar economic and commercial reasons for wanting to join - some of which will be familiar to UK businessmen: lower transaction costs, ease of trading, the attraction for domestic and inward investment. NKT does some 50 per cent of its business in the euro zone; for Grundfos the figure is 60 per cent.

Madsen says: 'We do most of our trade there. We simply cannot understand how it would be better to be outside.'

But they also point to specifically Danish factors - chief of which is that since 1982 the Danish krone has been linked first to the deutschmark and now to the euro.

Hansen says this means there are major disadvantages to staying out: 'We must follow what the ECB does. But we have no influence at the committees.'

And, as Knutzen points out, Danish businesses and taxpayers have to put up with higher debt costs while the krone is outside the euro. Base rates are half a percentage point higher than the ECB's. 'You will always pay a premium while you are outside.'

Niels Meyer, a professor of physics and spokesman for the leftish June movement, says: 'Because we have referendums, the Danish people are very well informed. webTitle: In my view: Oil crisis? What oil crisis?

fields.headline: Oil crisis? What oil crisis?
fields.standfirst: Special report: The petrol war
fields.trailText: Every third year the World Bank and International Monetary Fund conduct their annual general meetings well away from Washington.
fields.body:
Every third year the World Bank and International Monetary Fund conduct their annual general meetings well away from Washington. The 1988 meetings in West Berlin were memorable for the first appearance of protesters: one recalls an orderly procession, followed rapidly by street cleaners picking up rubbish with Teutonic thoroughness. The 1988 meetings were especially notable for the fact that, amid all the forecasts unveiled, nobody, but nobody, predicted the fall of the Berlin Wall in 1989.

The 1991 meetings in Bangkok were dominated by the attempt to deal with the collapse of the Soviet Union. The 1994 meetings in Madrid featured a more agile form of protest, with members of Greenpeace disrupting the proceedings by performing acrobatics amid the rafters of the conference hall. The 1997 meetings in Hong Kong were held against the background of the Asian financial crisis.

One has to hark back to the Seventies and early Eighties for meetings such as this one in Prague held against the background of an oil crisis. Those oil crises had been diagnosed as both inflationary, because they raised the price of oil sharply and gave rise to a price-wage spiral in many countries, and deflationary, because higher import bills removed purchasing power from consumers of oil to producers.

It was generally agreed that the oil producers had such primitive economies that they could not possibly spend all their new-found wealth at once. The vogue term in those days was 'recycling' - the process by which the Opec countries deposited huge quantities of money with the western financial system, and these funds were 'lent on' to other countries.

Before becoming an oil producer proper, even Britain itself had to borrow, in somewhat humiliating circumstances, from Iran, suffering a lecture from the Shah on how to run its economy. But many Opec funds were lent to - indeed almost forced on - developing countries, and there lay the origins of the Third World debt crisis. With the encouragement of the official international agencies, sound banking principles were abandoned and , after a routine series of questions about their economies, governments were asked: 'How much do you want?'

A sudden increase in the price of oil is a classic example of what economists have in mind when they mutter darkly about 'external shocks'. Britain, as a net exporter of oil, gains extra revenues from such a shock, which is why the Treasury's initial reaction to demands for a reduction in fuel duty was somewhat disingenuous. The Chancellor has the money, if he so chooses, to make concessions without revising his plans for the building of a single hospital or the purchase of a single schoolbook.

The fact that this is an external shock also gives the Bank of England's monetary policy committee some leeway, if necessary, in interpreting the need to raise interest rates to meet its infla tion target. An escape-clause is written into the legislation. As it happens, the course of UK inflation is well within the official 2.5 per cent target. Much depends on whether, as happened during the much bigger oil shocks of the Seventies, higher wage demands drive the general price level up, in circumstances where we are closer to full employment than we have been for many years. (Although forecourt competition produced a drop in petrol prices in August, during the past year, the rise in the price index, excluding oil has been negligible.)

There is also the question whether, as David Rough of Legal & General indicated last week, the Chancellor's ambitious public spending plans will act as a separate factor in stoking up inflationary pressures and interest rates. On the other hand, one of the reasons for the continuing budget surplus is that the public sector seems to have become so accustomed to 'cuts' that it cannot get its new spending act together.

But Britain is highly dependent on developments in the world economy - indeed we have gained enormously from the prolonged world boom for which the US is principally responsible. And a sudden change of gear on this front - despite rather optimistic forecasts from the IMF - could mean the MPC worrying less about inflation than deflation.

The big questions are: when and to what degree does the US boom come to its long-predicted end? And how serious is this latest oil crisis?

The Bank of International Settlements - the central bankers' bank in Basle - has been issuing largely unheeded warnings for some time about the fragility of the US boom. And the latest Trade and Development Report (2000) from the United Nations raises the question: how long can the US economy continue being 'buyer of last resort' when it is borrowing more than $1bn a day from the rest of the world to do so?

Keynes' classic insight was the danger of 'hoarding'. This applies within economies - hence the need, at appropriate times, for expansionary demand management - and between economies. A main cause of the 1997 Asian financial crisis was that western investors removed their money from East Asia.

Indeed, as Unctad econo mist Yilmaz Akuz pointed out last week, money from Asia and elsewhere - not least the Eurozone - has been pouring into the US and fuelling a boom that has already had plenty of encouragement from the Federal Reserve.

Nobody can accuse the American consumer of hoarding. He and she spend as if there were no tomorrow. But international policymakers are mildly concerned in public and very concerned in private about what happens when the US is finally forced to live within its means. It is partly for this reason that there has been so much concern about the eurozone: growth appears to be slowing in Europe, yet Europe is seen as the obvious locomotive to fuel world demand when the US has had enough.

Which brings us back to fuel. One of the reasons this oil crisis is not considered as bad as previous ones is that, because government fuel taxes (outside the US) account for some 60 to 70 per cent of the final price, a tripling of the world oil price raises petrol prices by only around 20 per cent.

Akyuz argues that there is even a case, in terms of demand management, for governments to lower such taxes if the present oil crisis does prove deflationary. In other words, the protesters might have an economic case.

webTitle: G7 puts the heat on Opec to bring down oil prices

fields.headline: G7 puts the heat on Opec to bring down oil prices
fields.standfirst: Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: The world's most powerful industrial nations yesterday decided to put concerted pressure on the oil-producing countries to cut the price of oil by pumping more of it on to the market.
fields.byline: William Keegan, Prague and Ed Vulliamy, New York
fields.body:
The world's most powerful industrial nations yesterday decided to put concerted pressure on the oil-producing countries to cut the price of oil by pumping more of it on to the market.

Finance Ministers of the Group of Seven, meeting in Prague, decided that higher output was a better solution than cutting taxes.

Chancellor Gordon Brown said that a G7 statement announcing the decision was 'the strongest yet'. The Organisation of Oil Producing Countries (Opec), he added, should 'now take action, as they promised, to get the price of oil down'.

But beyond making clear their concerns to the Opec nations, Brown refused to specify what action the G7 could take.

He said: 'We are taking co-ordinated action because of our concern about world oil prices, our desire to get the price down and our desire to make Opec aware that when the oil price goes from $11 to over $30, that does create conditions that are difficult for all countries.'

The G7 Ministers' move follows their decision to try to revive the flagging value of the euro by intervening on the currency markets. Up to $5 billion is understood to have been spent by the seven countries - the United States, Japan, Germany, France, Italy, the UK and Canada - in an attempt to stabilise the European single currency last Friday.

It is the first time that the British Government has intervened in the market for sterling since Black Wednesday on 16 September, 1992.

At a press conference in Prague Brown - who was in remarkably robust form after a week of 'little local difficulties' - dismissed questions about if he would resign with the quip: 'I'm far too busy.'

It appears that the Chancellor was not prepared to act alone to reduce the over-valued exchange rate, but responded swiftly to a request from the European Central Bank last Thursday.

In Washington, President Bill Clinton yesterday defended his decision to release millions of gallons of oil from US reserves to encourage a fall in the world price. He coupled it with a major heating aid programme to help poorer families cope with their winter heating bills.
