webTitle: Will Buckley: Measuring up as a father

fields.headline: Measuring up as a father
fields.trailText: No fuel, flash floods, power cuts. It's been a tough week for being a parent.
fields.body:
No fuel, flash floods, power cuts, kids' first week at big school, a couple of hundred boxes still needing to be unpacked, video machine banjaxed in the move, Little Mo toddling around carrying her Winnie the Pooh video, bawling her eyes out day after day after day. It's been a tough week for being a parent.

But not, it has to be admitted, quite so tough for the parent who has had to deal with these crises from a grandstand seat on Bondi beach while chugging on a stubbie and watching a pair of Bulgarian sisters taking on a couple of leggy Cubans at beach volleyball.

Naturally, I feel an element of guilt - I wouldn't be human if I didn't - but there isn't too much time for guilt when you are professionally employed to have a view on a crucial line call which might determine whether the Bulgarian sisters make it into round 16. And, let's face it, sport doesn't come much better, or certainly funnier, than four women in bikinis gesturing hysterically at a mark in the sand.

Having to take on such assignments is in part responsible for me having been burdened with the nickname Long Leash. This is occasionally used by Grainne - 'That's your lot, Mr Long Leash' - but far more by certain fellow fathers.

It is a sad indicator of these deranged times that fathering has become a competitive sport. All over the country, keen young men are putting in the hours in a bid to be Britain's Top Dad. And it would surprise me not a jot were it to be elevated to an Olympic Sport. 'Over now to the pool for some live fathering. Look out for the strongly fancied American dad, Lennie Spock, attempting to guide his quadruplets into the deep end for the first time without armbands - an Olympic first. And Britain's very own Peter Leach, who has been struggling in the changing room in practice but if he gets to grips with his nappy wipes, must have an outside squeak of a medal.'

When this happens, a couple of people who insist on calling me Long Leash will undoubtedly be in the British squad. They are the kind of dads other dads fear. The kind of dads who, while finessing a Caesar salad they have brought round with them for supper in your house, will say loud enough for everyone to hear, 'Hey, Long Leash, why don't we give the girls a surprise break. Let's book them into a health resort for a fortnight and we'll take the seven kids on a two-week barge holiday. Next Tuesday, OK with you?' The kind of dads who ask you, without apparent irony, whether you'll be attending antenatal classes. The kind of dads who eat the placenta.

Inevitably, they are married to the kind of women who like to gab on the phone to Grainne. Therefore, even if I don't invite them round, I can't can't avoid their exploits. 'Y tells me that last night X put the kids to bed, cooked her dinner, made love to her. Twice. And brought her a cup of coffee in the morning.' Thanks for sharing that with us, X and Y.

I was confident, however, that by the simple but scary device of spending 27 hours on an Air Malaysia plane I would escape such nonsenses. Sydney is, after all, the home of the larrikin. A macho town where guys such as Cookie, Douggo and The Ledge can derive six hours of quality entertainment from making disparaging comments about a lone Brit's haircut. Where people accost you on the beach to say, 'Oi, Hair! What are you doing reading a book. Books are for school. Put it down.'

I've had lessons in childcare from surprising people in surprising places - a two-hour lecture from an international darts player during a dinner dance for Fish O'Mania V springs to mind - but in Sydney, surely, I'd be safe.

Of course not. There I was minding my own business quietly watching the swimming when a bug-eyed born-again Christian from Coff's Harbour drained his 18th schooner of Toohey's New and turned to me: 'You got kids?'

'Un huh.'

'You look after them?'

'Un huh.'

'I'll tell you what makes a good father_ Oi, mate, why are you looking over my shoulder?'

'Sorry, you were saying...'

It's not all Beach Volleyball .

 Phil Hogan will back next week

webTitle: The cost of... driving a cab

fields.headline: The cost of...
fields.standfirst: ... driving a cab
fields.trailText: ... driving a cab
fields.body:
Perhaps the best way to avoid being caught short the next time the unholy alliance of farmers and hauliers decides to starve the country of its unleaded lifeblood is to become part of the network. Taxi drivers are on the fuel-protest grapevine and as a bonus, unlike hauliers (probably), have an apparently steady stream of celebs passing through the back of their cabs. All you really need is a MOT'd car, a Hackney Carriage licence and insurance (£1,300 per year). Purists will want a black cab (under no circumstances call them cars). And they are a sound choice: a top-of-the-range Hooper TX1 (the anodyne new model) might cost £30,620 but comes with front and rear air-conditioning, CD player, metallic paint, and does about 26mpg. Alternatively, classic Fairway cabs go for about £15,000 secondhand, or you could rent one for £150 per week.

To drive a black cab in London you'll have to pass the Knowledge, which means memorising not only all the streets on 400 routes, but also the restaurants, offices, pubs and so on. It usually takes prospective cabbies two years to finish, but at least there are no fees.

Taxi licences outside London can cost £137 per car (plus £20 deposit for the plates) and £52 per driver (£103 inside London). Radios are handy: £250 will buy a basic CB radio kit with a range of about 10 miles (CB radio licence £15) or a flashier two-way radio will be £200 per set (plus Home Office licence). Fuel, obviously, won't be cheap. Let's say, for the sake of a simple calculation, you do 26,000 miles per year (although it is likely to be closer to 40,000). With diesel at £3.70 per gallon, you'll be spending at least £3,700.

And, yes, it is easy to stereotype cabbies as, shall we say, brimming with populist opinions, but you should feel obliged to inform and entertain your passengers, so keep abreast of current affairs with a daily tabloid (20p). Don't worry - most taxi drivers also quickly pick up the defensive driving techniques worthy of a Mossad agent and the highly selective vision displayed at pub-closing time.

Hooper TX1 SE £30,620
(secondhand Fairway £15,000)
Insurance £1,300 a year
Fuel £3,700 a year
Licences £209
CB radio £250
CB licence £15 a year
Daily newspaper 20p
Total £36,094.20

webTitle: Moneywrites: A disabled child, and no home

fields.headline: A disabled child, and no home
fields.standfirst: Has your bank, building society or insurer treated you badly? We seek justice for our readers
fields.trailText: Has your bank, building society or insurer treated you badly? We seek justice for our readers.
fields.body:
My single-parent daughter has a severely disabled child. She has been renting a house from a private landlord through a letting agent. The landlord's mortgage lender, Abbey National, has informed her that it is repossessing the property because the landlord is in arrears with his repayments, and it has given her notice to quit.

The letting agent denies responsibility for the landlord's conduct. The tenancy is only five months old and my daughter has incurred the expense of a deposit, an agency fee, a credit rating investigation charge, removal costs and making the house suitable for a disabled child. She has no resources left to rent again and feels she is due compensation for a situation outside her control. Her local authority should rehouse her, but there is nothing suitable in Walthamstow, where she lives. She needs to be able to park near the house because she has to carry oxygen around for her daughter. What can she do?
DH, Glastonbury

Your daughter will not be able to stay in her home if Abbey National repossesses it. Lenders can throw tenants out before the end of their leases because they must sell the property for the best price. Your daughter should contact her local authority immediately, because it has a duty to rehouse her once she is homeless. She should insist on a long-term assessment of her daughter's needs, so she is not just reacting to her current crisis but planning ahead.

The problem is always shortage of property, so there is no guarantee there will be a home available, but the council is in touch with housing associations who might have more suitable accommodation. She can ask to be nominated to a housing association, giving her the advantage of a landlord experienced in housing tenants with disabilities. Habinteg is one housing association in the area that designates a quarter of its homes for wheelchair users.

A price in ticking the wrong box

Many Scottish Widows' policyholders seem to have 'ticked the wrong box' in ignorance of their likely payouts and are now looking at big capital gains tax bills. In my case, the loss is £15,000, a third of my compensation. If I had known how large the windfall would be, I could have taken the loan note option offered specifically to avoid this problem. It is frustrating that Scottish Widows provided inadequate information to support this choice and doubly frustrating that they are now refusing to make changes.
TR, London

Scottish Widows admits to being 'prudent' in its estimates of the windfalls which led you to believe the cash payment would be below the £7,200 annual capital gains tax allowance. But the insurer says you could have picked the option that hedged your bets, allowing you to take cash unless the windfall exceeded the tax allowance, in which case you would get loan notes. But you ticked the 'cash' box, and, says Scottish Widows, the form you signed was 'irrevocable and binding'. It says the cut-off point is permanent.

Over the top bill for over-70s

I phoned Liverpool Victoria to insure a three-week holiday to the US for me and my wife. I was quoted £172. I then contacted the Retired Insurance Advisory Service (RIAS), which quoted £92. I assume actuaries work out the cost of covering the risks involved, add a reasonable profit and then come up with a price. How can two insurers come up with such wildly different figures?
WJ, Llanbadarn Fynydd

Underwriters forecast how many people are likely to claim on a policy, so insurers can pitch premiums to make a profit. But insurers make their own decisions about how much profit they want. Then, these two policies might not have been identical: one might pay more for, say, medical expenses. But the main difference is that Liverpool Victoria, like most insurers, weights the price of holiday policies against older travellers believing the over-seventies are more likely to claim. RIAS does not.

Simple question, taxing answer

Premiums on my Sun Life of Canada endowment policy have been paid up, although it does not mature until December 2001. Recently I asked about cashing it in, and the company warned that I might incur tax. My tax office said the proceeds would be tax free. I asked for the Inland Revenue's written confirmation and received eight pages of incomprehensible tax-speak with a covering letter stating that the Revenue is in fact 'unable to confirm that proceeds from an early surrender would be tax free'. Is there a straightforward answer to this simple question?
JV, London

Yours was originally a qualifying life insurance policy, which means there is no tax to pay on the proceeds. But it lost its special tax status because you had it made paid up (stopped paying premiums but kept the policy) when it had been running for fewer than 10 years. You face tax whether you cash it in early or on maturity, but you will pay tax only if you are a higher-rate taxpayer when you get the money or the payout itself pushes you into the higher-rate band.

Dial up help with pensions sums

I have been corresponding with the DSS for months about the value of my additional state pension. Where can I get information to enable me to calculate my entitlement?
LT, Solihull

The DSS calculates additional pension by taking the difference between the lower earnings limit (the point at which you start paying National Insurance contributions) and the upper earnings limit, revalued at today's prices. It takes 24 per cent of that figure and divides by the number of years in your working life.

Ring the helpline on 0191 218 7585 for help filling in the application form, BR19.

What's the catch?

The Australian Lottery Office has been offering readers a 'guaranteed unique method to potentially collect millions of dollars each week'.

The company claims that, by using sophisticated computer software and years of lottery data, it has identified specific sets of numbers that stand a greater chance of winning the Australian 6/45 Lottery. A letter to readers in the UK includes a set of 'approved 10 numbers' to enable them to 'cash in'.

The letter goes on to describe how the Australian 6/45 Lottery, shown live on television in Australia every Saturday night, draws six main numbers and two bonus numbers from balls marked 1 to 45. This gives players a better chance of winning than in the UK Lottery.

To play one game for 12 weeks, three games for four weeks, or six games for two weeks, a recipient must pay the Australian Lottery Office £5. Alternatively the 'All-options savings plan' costs £10.

The letter gives the impression of being official - a non-Australian could easily believe it was a letter from the Australian Lottery itself. But a spokeswoman for the Australian High Commission in Lon don says there is no connection: 'We advise people to save their money.'

The Australian Lottery Office has been investigated by the Australian Federal Police, and the Commission's spokeswoman points out that there is no real way of knowing whether you have won a prize. You have no idea what combination of six out of the 10 approved numbers were entered on your behalf. She says: 'The scheme has been in existence for at least five years and we have no knowledge of anyone in the UK winning.'

Worse still, people who have responded to the offer have found themselves bombarded with a stream of unsolicited mailshots.

 Write to Margaret Dibben, Money Writes, The Observer, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, and include a telephone number. Do not enclose SAEs or original documents. Letters are selected for publication and we cannot give personal replies. The newspaper accepts no legal responsibility for advice. Seen an advertisement or mailshot that looks too good to be true? Write to What's the Catch, Observer Business, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER.

fields.headline: A wheeler, a dealer, but he's not really thinking of the cash
fields.standfirst: Martin Miller has business flair but takes four years off now and then, writes Neasa MacErlean
fields.trailText: Martin Miller has business flair but takes four years off now and then, writes Neasa MacErlean.
fields.body:
Entrepreneur Martin Miller could be described as the Richard Branson of the antiques world. A man with a natural flair for business, he has had his difficult times (though never run out of money) as well as good ones and branched out into other areas where he spots a gap - running hotels, publishing diaries, owning commercial property and (next year) running a Sky TV channel.

Like Branson, he did not put much store by his formal education ('it was crap') and - again like the famous hot air balloonist - he knows that there are many other things in the world beyond work and money.

Like the son of a vicar who embraces atheism, Miller rejected all the encouragement he got from his insurance salesman father to save for the long term. 'I have absolutely no interest in looking to the future,' he says from Miller's Hotel in West London, which he owns and now lives in. 'I have always had this belief that I would never run out of money. But if you get yourself insurance policies, the last thing you can do is get your hands on the money.' Now 53, he has no pension and no plans to get one. In reality, his business assets will be his pension.

But ever since his early years in Worthing, he has had a practical attitude to money. He started off photographing babies and weddings. Doing a shoot on period costumes one day, he got into conversation about antiques and started publishing antiques guides. The Lyle Official Antiques Review became a big seller in 1970. Along the way there were other books, including Miller's Antiques Price Guide , and now he has just brought out the first edition of Martin Miller: Antiques Source Book. Next March he plans to produce a Saturday and Sunday antiques and collectibles Sky TV channel aimed at the young as well as the traditional collector.

Once a collector of antique furniture himself ('wood is such a fascinating material'), he is not one of the modern brand of collectors who go for three-year-old Harry Potter first editions worth £10,000, phone cards and beany babies. 'Lots of people are losing interest in real antiques - so many antiques are now very cheap indeed. Collecting newer items is becoming popular, but we haven't got to the stage the Americans have, where you can buy books on barbed-wire collecting.'

Twice in his life, he has put business to one side and lived a quiet existence. In the late 70s, he had four years of walking the dog, running a B&B, going to the pub at lunch and living with his then partner in Petworth. After his divorce, he had another four years out which ended just a couple of years ago.

'I got caught up in a lazy lifestyle, held lots of parties, had very long lunches, played masses of games of chess and led a very unstressful life. But it can be very expensive.' So two years ago he got busy again. But although he enjoys the wheeling-and-dealing world, he is not very interested in making money or even in possessions. He no longer has any antiques collections, for instance.

His five daughters seem to have inherited his lack of interest in cash. None took him up on a very lucrative offer he made them: if they went to a state school, he would give them two-thirds of the money he would otherwise spend on education. They chose private schools.

'They probably never believed that I meant it,' he says, smiling.

 Martin Miller: Antiques Source Book 2000-2001, is published by Carlton, price £16.99

fields.headline: Water, water all around...
fields.standfirst: ... is the last thing you want at home. But the risk of floods is rising fast.  Jill Insley reports
fields.trailText: ... is the last thing you want at home. But the risk of floods is rising fast. Jill Insley reports.
fields.body:
Homeowners face a tenfold increase in the risk of flooding and other weather- related damage to their property, the Environment Agency is warning.

The Government body launched a new flood warning system last week with the prediction that Britain could become a flood 'hot spot', with 5 million people already living in flood risk areas. The agency says changing UK climate patterns will result in a 10 per cent increase in annual rainfall, wetter winters and more summer storms - all of which could cause flooding.

Chairman Sir John Harman said: 'Flood risk is now a fact of daily life. Reports of flooding are now on average nearly twice as frequent as they were 100 years ago. More worryingly, with climate change, we could see up to a tenfold increase inrisk over the next century.'

Even if your home has never previously been affected, there is no guarantee that you will remain safe. Last year, only one in eight people whose homes were flooded had experienced anything like it before. The agency fears that Government plans to build 23 million new homes in the next 15 years could exacerbate the problem. It is working with the Department of the Environment, Transport and Regions to introduce tougher guidance for plan ning authorities to curb development in flood plains.

Properties with 'river frontage', 'lake' or 'sea views' are in great demand, yet they are particularly at risk.

Harman warns: 'Flood risk will not automatically be included in the property search when you are buying a new home. You must request it from your solicitor or do your own homework.'

You can ring the agency's new Floodline on 0845 988 1188, or request a personal call-back by clicking the 'phone-me' option on its website, www.environmentagency.gov.uk to find out if your home is at risk. It also offers practical hints on how to minimise the financial and emotional impact of a flood.

Portsmouth residents had first-hand experience of the new warning system last week. Torrential downpours and the breakdown of a local pumping station sent a tide of raw sewage pouring through 115 homes. The damage will take months, if not years, to repair fully.

So what can you do to protect yourself and your property? The first step is to make sure you have adequate home and contents insurance. The Association of British Insurers says nearly 40 per cent of UK homes have no buildings insurance, and 25 per cent of homes at risk of flooding have no contents cover.

Paul Charles of online broker Screentrade says even those who have cover may find they are under-insured: 'Flooding is classed as a "standard peril", and all buildings and contents poli cies include it, but you don't want to guess that your contents are worth £20,000 when they are actually worth £40,000.' The average claim for flood damage is £6,000 to £7,000.

If your home has been flooded before, you may find your insurance premiums are raised, but don't be tempted to mislead the insurance company.

Charles says: 'Insurers check the information you give them with your previous insurer, and they will discover if you try to conceal a previous claim. If you are found out, your policy could become null and void.'

It is a good idea to make a record of the damage done to your home as soon as possible. Make a video or take photographs while the water is still inside, if possible.

Some policies provide immediate assistance for flood victims. However to ensure that you can contact your insurer quickly, Charles recommends keeping your policy documents (and all other important documents, passports and valuables) on the first floor or higher.

Many victims say the worst aspects of flooding come during the recovery period. After the flood, it's vital to clean the property as soon as possible to minimise problems caused by damp. The longer a home spends under water, the greater the damage to its fabric.

'The dog barked, then we were walking in water'

John and Jeanette Taylor have been flooded twice in the past two weeks. Although they live on the Ridge - which is high up, as its name suggests - in Hastings, they suffered from overflowing drains two Fridays running.

'The first time we were asleep in bed, and the dog woke us up by barking. My wife got out of bed and found she was walking in water,' says John.

The second time, after it had rained heavily for 10 minutes, water started coming in under the door.

'There was very little warning,' John says.

On both occasions, sudden thunderstorms sent water flooding through their roof and overwhelmed both their mains drainage - only 4in in diameter - and the sewerage system, which are just outside the couple's front door. Luckily the house has an upside-down design, with the bedrooms on the ground floor and the living room and kitchen on the first floor. This meant that their documents and valuables were safe on the first floor.

However, the flooding has ruined the Taylors' downstairs carpet, their wiring and the decoration in their bathroom.

Eagle Star, their contents insurer, has arranged for a company to start work on drying out the house. Although the couple have not yet received estimates of how much the repair work will cost, John expects a replacement carpet alone to cost about £500.

He also believes work will be needed to widen the drainage system to prevent future flooding.

How to stay safe

You can't prevent flooding, but you can be ready. The Environment Agency suggests these steps:

 Check with the agency's Floodline, on 0845 988 1188, whether your property is at risk and ask about local warning arrangements.
 Keep a list of useful numbers: your council, emergency services, insurance company and Floodline.
 Find out where to turn off your gas and electricity. If you are unsure, ask the person who checks your meter when they next visit.
 Make up a flood kit, including a torch, blankets, waterproof clothing, wellington boots, a portable radio, first aid kit, rubber gloves and key personal documents. Keep it upstairs if possible.
 Buy a few sandbags or floor boards to block doors and airbricks, but ensure there is still adequate ventilation.
 Get into the habit of storing valuables upstairs.

When you hear a flood warning:

 Move people, pets and valuables upstairs or to higher ground.
 Drive your car to higher ground. It would take only 2ft of fast-flowing water to wash it away.
 Check on your neighbours - do they need help?
 Keep warm and dry. A flood can last longer than you think, and it can get cold. Take warm clothes and blankets, a Thermos and food.
 Make sure you have any medication you need to take regularly.
 Don't walk in floodwater above knee level. It can easily knock you over, and may hide hazards.

After the deluge:

 Call your insurance company and report what has happened.
 Check Yellow Pages under Flood Damage for cleaning materials or equipment to dry out your house.
 Check drainage systems.
 Ask gas, electricity and water companies to check your supplies before you turn them back on.
 Open doors and windows to ventilate your home. A brick dries out at the rate of an inch a month. Unblock airbricks and doorways.
 Wash taps and run them for a few minutes before use.
 Remove wet carpets and furniture.
 Don't touch items that have been in contact with the water, which may may be contaminated and contain sewage. Disinfect and clean thoroughly everything that got wet.

The Environment Agency suggests these steps:  Check with the agency's Floodline, on 0845 988 1188, whether your property is at risk and ask about local warning arrangements.  Keep a list of useful numbers: your council, emergency services, insurance company and Floodline.  Find out where to turn off your gas and electricity. If you are unsure, ask the person who checks your meter when they next visit.  Make up a flood kit, including a torch, blankets, waterproof clothing, wellington boots, a portable radio, first aid kit, rubber gloves and key personal documents. Keep it upstairs if possible.  Buy a few sandbags or floor boards to block doors and airbricks, but ensure there is still adequate ventilation.  Get into the habit of storing valuables upstairs. When you hear a flood warning:  Move people, pets and valuables upstairs or to higher ground.  Drive your car to higher ground. It would take only 2ft of fast-flowing water to wash it away.  Check on your neighbours - do they need help?  Keep warm and dry. A flood can last longer than you think, and it can get cold. Take warm clothes and blankets, a Thermos and food.  Make sure you have any medication you need to take regularly.  Don't walk in floodwater above knee level. It can easily knock you over, and may hide hazards. After the deluge:  Call your insurance company and report what has happened.  Check Yellow Pages under Flood Damage for cleaning materials or equipment to dry out your house.  Check drainage systems.  Ask gas, electricity and water companies to check your supplies before you turn them back on.  Open doors and windows to ventilate your home. A brick dries out at the rate of an inch a month. Unblock airbricks and doorways.  Wash taps and run them for a few minutes before use.  Remove wet carpets and furniture.  Don't touch items that have been in contact with the water, which may may be contaminated and contain sewage. Disinfect and clean thoroughly everything that got wet.

fields.headline: On the market
fields.standfirst: Cazenove European Smaller Companies Fund
fields.trailText: Cazenove European Smaller Companies Fund
fields.body:
Contact 0207 606 0708 (ask for Kate Bower)

Aim Capital growth by investing in small, fast-growing companies whose business is derived primarily from Europe.

Bells & whistles The fund is designed to capitalise on Cazenove's success with its European and pan-European funds. The former has grown by 811 per cent and outperformed the FTSE Europe ex UK by 380 per cent since its launch in April 1989; the latter has risen by 163 per cent and beaten the FTSE Eurotop 300 index by 122 per cent since its launch in January 1999. Fund manager Adrian Bignell says: 'European smaller companies benefit from a number of long-term trends: a growing equity culture; improving market liquidity; deregulation; and fiscal reform.'

How it works The fund will buy shares in companies with a market capitalisation of up to 1.5bn euros (£900m). Cazenove has a bottom-up investment style, meaning that it places more emphasis on picking individual companies based on financial data than on asset allocation (allocating chunks of money to different sectors or geographical areas) based on macro-economic influences. That said, the fund is likely to be biased towards technology, media and service companies, and underweight in financials, utilities, basic industries, raw materials and cyclicals. The fund will use the HSBC Europe ex UK Smaller Companies Index as a benchmark.

Minimum £5,000

Charges Initial 5 per cent, annual 1.25 per cent

Tax Cazenove does not offer an Isa, but says investors could use a self-select Isa to protect their returns from tax.

Risk High

Should you buy it? Nick Holmes of London independent financial adviser Brooks Macdonald Gayer says: 'Cazenove are a one-region house. They live and die by their European performance, and it has been strong. It is very aggressive - not for widows and orphans - but we will be buying it.'

Michael Aaron of Milton Keynes firm David Aaron Partnership says: 'It is a sector of the market that we like very much - both Europe and smaller companies. Cazenove has a very good track record in Europe and should be well placed for the future. Not our first choice, but likely to be on the shortlist.'

Points out of 10 Holmes - 7, Aaron - 8.

fields.headline: Cashpoints
fields.trailText: Click for new money facts | Cheapest cards | Taking cover
fields.body:
Click for new money facts

Moneyfacts, the specialist data provider that supplies information for Cash's data page each week, is extending its service to provide information through its new website. The site will include a range of 'best buy' charts, covering mortgages, savings, credit and other types of plastic cards, loans and overdrafts, annuities, offshore accounts, investments, life insurance and pensions.

The site will also include a rolling news service, an interactive mortgage sourcing system to help you find the best mortgage for your circumstances (providing illustrations showing APRs, exact fees, monthly repayments, and true costs), and a credit card and savings search option.

Information on the site will be updated daily, and the service is completely independent - MoneyFacts will receive no commission for introducing customers to product providers.

Cheapest cards

If you tend to carry debt from one month to the next on your credit cards, you should switch to one with as low an interest rate as possi ble. Capital One's Zero Percent card charges no interest at all on purchases for the first six months, rising to a reasonable variable rate of 12.9 per cent APR; it also has no annual fee. The card is slightly less competitive for balance transfers, charging 7.9 per cent indefinitely.

For the cheapest deal on balance transfers, try Egg, which charges 2.5 per cent APR for six months, or try RBS Advanta, which charges 2.9 per cent until June 2001.

Capital One: 0800 9525252
, Egg
RBS Advanta: 0800 077770.

Taking cover I

If you travel more than once a year, annual travel policies can work out much cheaper than buying individual policies each time you go abroad. Club Direct has cut the cost of insurance further by lopping 20 per cent off the price of its annual policy, Prima.

This covers any number of trips a year provided they do not exceed 31 days each. European cover costs £39.20 for an adult, £63.20 for couples, £55.20 for families of one adult and unlimited children, or £71.20 for a two-parent family.

Worldwide cover costs £60 for individuals, £79.20 for couples, £72 for single-parent families, and £92 for two-parent families.

All the policies include £10 million cover for medical expenses, £3,000 cover for cancellation, £2,000 baggage, £500 money and documents, and up to £2m personal liability cover. Call 0800 074 4556 for further information.

Taking cover, II

However, most travel policies will not include cover against accidents resulting from extreme sports such as bungee-jumping or parascending. Students who want to risk life and limb on holiday may find that the Student Travel Cover from Marcus Hearn offers a better all-round deal.

Cover costs from £23 for 31 days to £215 for a full gap year, and provides medical expenses cover of £2m, personal liability cover of £1m, £10,000 for personal acci dents and £5,000 for death. The policy covers against a wide range of extreme sports, as well as many team games which are excluded from standard policies. Call 020 7739 3444 for further information.

Car loan choice

E-loan - the online loans introducer - has launched a car finance service helps motorists choose from a range of car loans to get the best deal for buying a new or second-hand car.

The service offers car loans from six lenders - AA Financial Services, Alliance & Leicester, Bank of Scotland's Freeway, Finax, Online Finance and Paragon - and provides four different ways to repay: personal loans, hire purchase, contract purchase (covering personal contract purchase and lease purchase) and deferred loans. Interest rates range from 8.9 per cent APR to 19 per cent APR, depending on size and type of loan.

The site provides a range of price calculators including one to help company car owners compare tax charges against the alternative extra salary.

Insurance soars

Further grim news for motorists - they face an average insurance premium increase of 35 per cent this year. A report from consulting actuary Tillinghast-Towers Perrin says that drivers aged 17-24 have had to pay up to 50 per cent more since August 1999, regardless of where they live or their no-claims bonus. And drivers aged between 17 and 20 have seen their premiums soar by more than 60 per cent.

Beg, steal and burrow

Today is International Rabbit Day, and to mark the occasion pet insurer Pet Plan has published a free guide to owning and caring for rabbits. It shows you how to choose one, how to accommodate it indoors and outdoors, how to feed it, how to train it against chewing and digging, and advises on health and grooming.

Bunny lovers (there are at least 1.8 million in the UK) who want a copy of the guide should call 0208 580 8196.

Pet Plan is also offering free cover for one month to pet owners who apply online for pet insurance.

webTitle: Wealthcheck: Volunteering for a mountain of debt

fields.headline: Volunteering for a mountain of debt
fields.standfirst: Isobel Parker explains to Helen Pridham how helping rural communities in Romania left her owing £8,000
fields.trailText: Isobel Parker explains to Helen Pridham how helping rural communities in Romania left her owing £8,000.
fields.body:
Isobel Parker
Age: 40
Lives in: Chichester, West Sussex
Occupation: Community health development officer
Earns: £27,000
Mortgage: £63,000
Debts: Credit card and other debts totalling about £8,000
Investments: £200 in a Tessa
Pension: Member of occupational scheme
Aim: To clear her debts in the best way and start saving

Earlier this year, Isobel Parker returned from Romania, where she had spent 12 months working with Voluntary Service Overseas (VSO), helping develop community health services for women and children. Although she had experience in a similar field here, working with rural communities who had, among other things, no access to running water, provided a very different set of challenges.

Now back home, she faces the next challenge: sorting out her finances.

'When you work for VSO you are paid at the local rate, which in my case was £120 a month. Although I had let my house in Chichester while I was away to help cover expenses in the UK such as my mortgage, the rent did not cover everything. So I ran up a fair amount of debt. I would now like to find out the best way to clear it.'

The bulk of her debts - £6,000 - went on two credit cards, with First Direct and RBS Advanta. Currently she is making only the minimum monthly repayments on these. In addition, she has an agreed £1,200 bank overdraft and an informal loan of £1,000 from friends.

She is wondering whether to consolidate her debts by taking out a personal loan, or to add them to her mortgage - £63,000 with Halifax. It is a fixed-rate loan with a redemption penalty period expiring in 2003. She is repaying it through a mixture of an endowment (£44,000), an Isa (£15,000) and an ordinary repayment loan (£4,000).

She says she has enough spare equity in the property to increase her mortgage if necessary and estimates it is now worth around £95,000.

She took a sabbatical from her job with a Health Authority when she decided to go to Romania, but has now decided to move on to a new position with a local authority, for which she needs a car. Fortunately her new employer is providing her with a loan for this purpose. She has also become a member of the local government pension scheme, to which she is transferring the benefits she had built up with the NHS scheme.

Her pension scheme pro vides her with some life assurance and she also has £13,000 of critical illness cover. She has two bank accounts, with the Halifax and with First Direct.

Her only savings are just less than £200 in a Tessa, which she opened with First Direct just before the tax-free accounts were abolished in April 1999. Once she has sorted her debts out, she would like to save more for the future.

Adviser 1: Sharon Linnard

VSO work can be very rewarding but not financially, as Isobel has discovered. She is right in making debt repayment her first priority because, although minimum payments on credit cards seem acceptable, the underlying interest rate is surprisingly high. First Direct's rate is 18.9 per cent a year, with RBS Advanta not far behind at 17.9 per cent.

One way of containing this is to make an application to a different provider where for a limited period a much lower rate is charged on debts transferred. A good example is the Nationwide Building Society whose Visa Card.

However, this only buys time. Isobel should try to reduce the amount outstanding as much as she can in that period. Were there more in her Tessa, it would be tempting to use that to reduce borrowing, but she may prefer to keep the account open so that once her debts are repaid, she can resurrect a very tax-efficient account.

She could talk to the Halifax about suspending payments under the Isa for a period and converting the whole of her loan to interest-only for the time being, though the endowment should be maintained. This would allow her to reduce her credit card borrowings.

On the positive side, Isobel is a member of an excellent occupational pension scheme which, to some extent, reduces the urgency over increasing her savings.

 Sharon Linnard works for chartered accountant Blick Rothenberg.

Adviser 2: Gordon Wilson

The key to clearing debt is to focus on the rate of interest being paid and find the cheapest rate possible. Overdrafts are generally expensive. In addition to high interest rates, there are often transaction charges. I would also steer clear of personal loans. Rates tend to be high and they are inflexible, although this can suit people who need the discipline of fixed repayments.

Isobel does not really have the option of increasing her mortgage, due to the redemption penalties. She could review the position in 2003. Depending on how much debt she has cleared, increasing the mortgage could be useful.

I would suggest that Isobel considers consolidating her debt to a low cost credit card. Very low introductory rates are currently available. Isobel could then establish how much she can afford to repay each month and set up a direct debit to the card company.

This means Isobel is in control and the debt can be cleared more quickly if funds become available. One catch is that many credit card companies offer the introductory rate for only six months; after that it could increase substantially. Isobel would need to transfer her balance before the rate increased.

Once the debt is clear, Isobel's thoughts should turn to her retirement. She could consider Additional Voluntary Contributions, Stakeholder Pensions and Isas.

 Gordon Wilson works for financial adviser Aitchison & Colegrave.

Advice is for guidance only.

You must be prepared to be interviewed and photographed.

webTitle: Rich pickings lie within golden age of guitars

fields.headline: Rich pickings lie within golden age of guitars
fields.standfirst: Jacqui MacDermott on the spell cast   by Strats and Gibsons
fields.trailText: Jacqui MacDermott on the spell cast by Strats and Gibsons.
fields.body:
There is just a certain something about guitars. More than almost any musical instruments, with the possible exception of saxophones, they are the epitome of cool. At school guys who played the violin or flute were seen as swotty and dull, but if they could bash out a couple of chords on a beaten-up old Fender, that was a different matter.

Guitars are also aesthetic objects: their basic curves may be found in violins and cellos, but only 'axes' can pull off cherry sunburst, cardinal red, or even silver sparkle finishes with aplomb, and as a result they've become increasingly desirable. This means that many are great investments, appreciating by 10 to 20 per cent a year - far better returns than you'll find in a building society or Isa.

The good news is that you don't have to earn a rock star's wages to afford such an asset. Noel Gallagher of Oasis used his Switch card to buy a guitar for less than £500 just before he hit the big time and has now, apparently, developed quite an eye for collectables. However, you need to know what to look for because, as in any market, there are duds and fakes.

Rick Zsigmond is a partner in London's Vintage Guitar Emporium and has sold instruments to some of the biggest names in the business. His shop's toilet walls are covered in autographs and read like a 'Who's Who' of rock and pop - Holly Johnson, Jon Bon Jovi, Gary Moore, Bryan Adams and Rory Gallagher. Loyd Grossman's name also appears among them; it seems the Masterchef presenter is an avid collector (yes, really).

'The first rule about buying a guitar is that you have to love it,' says Zsigmond. 'Go for a sound you like and admire. For instance, if you're a fan of Buddy Holly, or indeed Jimi Hendrix, you might choose a Fender Stratocaster.' Both of these rock legends had their Strats engraved on their headstones.

Paul Alcantara, a London-based writer and guitar teacher with around 30 instruments in his collection, echoes this sentiment: 'When you buy a vintage guitar, a little magic comes with it. It should be something that interests you and you shouldn't be afraid to play it. For those of us who grew up in the postwar years, electric guitars have become potent icons of the rock 'n' roll era. That's why products of the mid-Fifties to mid-Sixties are the most sought after.'

At the top of the price scale are US manufacturers such as Fender, Gibson, Epiphone, Martin and Rickenbacker. One of these makes from the peak era would be a serious investment, setting you back thousands of pounds. The price rises further with the 'Cor' factor: clean, original and rare. A 1958 Gibson Flying V in natural korina finish was recently on sale for £55,000, and prices can reach £80,000 for a really desirable instrument.

But if your means are modest there is still a variety of good guitars around. Alcantara is a fan of the US brand Paul Reed Smith, among others. He bought a 1987 model for £900 last year. The same model in similar condition would now cost around £1,500. He says: 'It is just a lovely quality guitar, with Brazilian rosewood fretboard, a material not used any more [for ecological reasons].' Other makes he rates are Musicman and Tom Anderson, in electric, and Santa Cruz, Collings and Taylor acoustic guitars.

He believes that, unless you're an expert, it is often safer to buy an instrument for £700 rather than £7,000. 'Who's going to bother to fake it for a few hundred? Higher up the scale, there's a bigger incentive.'

His success has come from trying to stay one step ahead, buying instruments that appeal to him as a player and often choosing 'sleepers', makes which have yet to reach their potential on the market.

'Guitars produced in the Eighties, such as Jackson, often came with lurid graphic finishes and can be found for a fraction of their original retail price. Who knows? A heavy metal revival and these could become highly desirable.'

He has already scored from this approach. 'I bought some Danelectros, made of masonite [hardboard to us] with lipstick tubes for pick-ups, which stopped being produced in 1968. Some cost as little as £150. I've sold some now and done quite well, but I've also held on to a few.'

Zsigmond believes that, if you are just starting out, re-issues of classics such as Fenders and Gibson Les Pauls can be a good buy. He says: 'They may depreciate briefly, but then you can watch the value start to climb back up.'

Alcantara, though, strikes a note of caution: 'Some of the limited edition reissues are made in greater quantity than a maker such as Rickenbacker would produce its originals.'

Both agree that the best advice is to follow your nose. 'Some people just have a feel for the right guitar,' says Zsigmond.

Once you have an idea of what you want, what should you look out for? 'Restoration,' says Zsigmond, 'can render a guitar virtually worthless. If you suspect an instrument has had major repairs or a change to the finish, walk away.'

Small repairs or knocks, though, are generally not too serious: they won't affect the value too much and they can give the guitar character. Other repairs, such as changing the frets, are essential - but in some of the older, rarer guitars, this can affect the value.

'Then you find owners who are afraid to play their instru ments, which seems a shame,' says Alcantara.

The finish can also make a big difference to the price. A good condition 1966 Gibson Firebird in a wood finish, for instance, is now worth around £3,000, says Zsigmond, but in cardinal red it's worth £7,000.

Other popular or 'custom' finishes go under such evocative names as candy apple red, seafoam green, shoreline gold, blue sparkle and aqua pearl. However, take care in this area: the premium price asked for a rare colour means they are susceptible to faking.

If the collecting bug takes hold, there are several ways of adding to or upgrading your collection without breaking the bank. You could pool resources with like-minded friends, for instance. Zsigmond sells to a group of five City workers, whose primary motive is investment, but who take it in turns to take their jointly owned guitars home to play.

As values rise, they upgrade their instruments, often by part-exchanging. This is a route taken by single collectors as well, starting small and building up gradually.

Another option is swapping with other enthusiasts. 'People develop different tastes,' says Alcantara. 'Collectors meet and swap regularly.'

The most important thing, however, is to enjoy what you collect. You don't have to be Eric Clapton to appreciate the quality of what you've bought, even if all you do is 'noodle' away in your sitting room.

As Alcantara says: 'You can play an old guitar, but you can't post an old stamp, can you?'

How to ensure your 'axe' keeps its cutting edge

Avoid storage where temperatures fluctuate, such as near radiators or heating pipes. For acoustics, it might be worth buying a humidifier.

If you move your guitar through different temperatures, leave it in its case for a couple of hours to acclimatise or the finish could crack.

When cleaning your guitar, do not use polishes that are:

 paraffin-based; they will dull the finish.

 waxy; they may leave the instrument greasy for weeks.

 made with silicone.

Wipe your guitar with a damp cloth and replace the strings regularly.
fields.bodyText: There is just a certain something about guitars. More than almost any musical instruments, with the possible exception of saxophones, they are the epitome of cool. At school guys who played the violin or flute were seen as swotty and dull, but if they could bash out a couple of chords on a beaten-up old Fender, that was a different matter. Guitars are also aesthetic objects: their basic curves may be found in violins and cellos, but only 'axes' can pull off cherry sunburst, cardinal red, or even silver sparkle finishes with aplomb, and as a result they've become increasingly desirable. This means that many are great investments, appreciating by 10 to 20 per cent a year - far better returns than you'll find in a building society or Isa. The good news is that you don't have to earn a rock star's wages to afford such an asset. Noel Gallagher of Oasis used his Switch card to buy a guitar for less than £500 just before he hit the big time and has now, apparently, developed quite an eye for collectables. However, you need to know what to look for because, as in any market, there are duds and fakes. Rick Zsigmond is a partner in London's Vintage Guitar Emporium and has sold instruments to some of the biggest names in the business. His shop's toilet walls are covered in autographs and read like a 'Who's Who' of rock and pop - Holly Johnson, Jon Bon Jovi, Gary Moore, Bryan Adams and Rory Gallagher. Loyd Grossman's name also appears among them; it seems the Masterchef presenter is an avid collector (yes, really). 'The first rule about buying a guitar is that you have to love it,' says Zsigmond. 'Go for a sound you like and admire. For instance, if you're a fan of Buddy Holly, or indeed Jimi Hendrix, you might choose a Fender Stratocaster.' Both of these rock legends had their Strats engraved on their headstones. fields.headline: Media diary
fields.trailText: Mischief making with lists
fields.body:
Mischief making with lists

Worried faces at the Evening Standard. The Press Complaints Council has received an angry missive from Martin Bowley QC, objecting to a recent article by high church atheist AN Wilson. Wilson, in one of his columns, had admitted to cross-referring two articles in the Sunday newspapers to see if the same names cropped up. And the two articles were? The Sindie's 50 famous gays list and none other than the Screws cut-out-and-keep paedophile register. Guy Black, director of the PCC and one of those mentioned in the Sindie's article, is likely to take a very dim view of Wilson's scribblings.

Sport at a leisurely pace

Reassuring to know that under sport-mad Greg Dyke, BBC sports marketing is stepping up a gear. Requests for interviews with Peter Salmon, the new head of Sport, are being met with a terse reply from 'Room 5020, Television Centre'. 'Thanks your email re Peter Salmon,' the BBC's image makers write. 'I've added you to the list. Peter is not physically available for three or four weeks (Sydney, holiday etc). Then he will be gathering his forces in BBC Sport, so realistically we're looking at post-Christmas.' January 2001? The suspense is killing us.

Free, but for how long?

Perhaps the most pointless reaction to the petrol crisis last week was the press release the Wall Street Journal sent out on Friday for WSJ.com: 'WSJ.com comes to the rescue of stranded newspaper readers.' How? By allowing free access to its subscription site for a limited time. When asked how long 'limited time' meant, a spokeswoman said: 'We're monitoring the situation closely and will review it on a daily basis. Basically, it will last as long as newspaper distribution is affected by the crisis.' But in the end, the whole distribution thing turned out to be a storm in a teacup and no papers were affected. Strangely enough, WSJ.com is still offering free access. Get it while it's free at wsj.com/fuelcrisis.

Breaking in is not hard to do

If you thought you were finally free of Big Brother and its attendant mania, think again. The producers of Big Brother 's mutant sibling, Channel 5's Jailbreak, have had to increase the number of guards at its Potters Bar 'prison'. You may think the calibre of contestant was higher than suspected, but apparently not. The guards are there to stop people from breaking in, not breaking out. Could it be that testing the security of the Jailbreak compound after a night down the pub is the latest 'in thing' to do in Hertfordshire. Monkey can't wait to have a go!

fields.headline: Stockwatch
fields.trailText: Bright at the end of the tunnel
fields.body:
Bright at the end of the tunnel

Now the firm has cast off its 'Dial-a-dog' label, perhaps it is finally time to take a serious look at Bright Station, entrepreneur Dan Wagner's latest reincarnation.

Wagner's firm Dialog sold off its troublesome Knight Ridder database arm for £190 million before changing its name in May. Shorn of its debt, Bright Station has £30m to invest in its remaining ventures.

The main activity now is Smartlogik, an Autonomy in the making, which combines the firm's Muscat and Infosort data search and indexing technology for the internet and company intranets. It has been starved of investment, but now has a motivated new chief executive, Stephen Hill.

Bright Station also emerged as the surprise buyer for Boo.com's website technology, which has beefed up its Sparza e-commerce arm. The firm paid £250,000 for Boo's platform but Wagner also picked up £4m of computer kit for about £1m.

Wagner remains a deal-maker at heart. Given his record of promising much and delivering far less, even at 54p Bright Station shares are a leap of faith. But if he can hide under a bushel and quietly notch up a few sales, it may now be worth a punt.

Vimto's new fizz

Nichols, the maker of Vimto, has had a miserable summer despite delivering interim results bang in line with expectations. The shares, now at 102p, have slipped from nearly 125p in June. House broker Henry Cooke, however, believes the stock is a good recovery buy.

The broker may well have a point. Demand for Vimto has been strong, supported by an increased marketing spend, and the new citrus Vimto has been well received. Going forward, reorganisation at Cabana drinks dispensing should cut costs, and capital expenditure at Nichols Foods should also bear fruit. The shares are trading at just six times prospective earnings, and are well-supported by a net yield of 9 per cent.

Bitter sweet

At the opposite end of the spectrum, Cadbury Schweppes has shelled out a pretty penny for Snapple. At $1.45 billion, the price is nearly five times the amount Triarc paid to take it off Quaker Oats' hands. Quaker, of course, originally paid $1.7 billion in 1994, but made a complete bodge of the deal. Triarc has since turned the soft drinks maker around.

Cadbury will always labour under concerns that it is competing with two of the strongest names around, Coca Cola and Pepsi. But the Snapple deal is earnings enhancing and shows Cadbury can still deliver growth.

Broker Schroder Salomon Smith Barney has set a new target price of 480p for Cadbury shares, against just 394p now.

Fairey's magic

Fairey, the engineering group, has amassed a tidy set of focused electronic and instrumentation businesses. And an upcoming analysts' visit to Fairey's hi-tech US operations in October should raise awareness of its exposure to growth sectors.

Fairey's £170m buy of Spectris in July and the sale of Imaging Technology lift the critical mass of all its operating units. Sales are also up.

Broker Charterhouse has now increased its profits forecast, and rates the shares, at 566p, a buy.

Glynwed simmers

At 186p, Midlands engineer Glynwed is very firmly out of favour in a fashion-driven market. But keep the faith: Aga oven sales are accelerating, and plastic pipe systems offer prospects for expansion. Here Glynwed has just 8 per cent of an £11bn global market. Buy for recovery.

webTitle: Thames Water boss set to make £1.2m from RWE takeover

fields.headline: Thames Water boss set to make £1.2m from RWE takeover
fields.trailText: Bill Alexander, chief executive of Thames Water, stands to make almost £1.2 million profit on his shares in the company if German group RWE makes its expected £4.3 billion bid tomorrow.
fields.body:
Bill Alexander, chief executive of Thames Water, stands to make almost £1.2 million profit on his shares in the company if German group RWE makes its expected £4.3 billion bid tomorrow.

Alexander, who was paid £396,000 in salary and bonuses last year, holds 13,545 shares directly and another 108,400 in options and various long-term bonus plans. Assuming, as is usual, that these all come up for grabs following a takeover, they would be worth almost £1.5m.

Exercising the options - some of them at prices as low as a third of the 1215p-a- share RWE is expected to offer - will cost him just over £300,000, leaving £1.2m profit.

Company secretary David Badcock will make almost £400,000 on the same basis.

Alexander and his team are expected to stay on to head RWE's international division. RWE wants to build a water business abroad, but its overseas interests are negligible.

By contrast Thames has 12 million customers overseas, the same number as in Britain, with operations in countries such as China, Turkey and the US, where it is acquiring a water company in New Jersey. Its international business has grown rapidly, but it is still at an early stage. Its overseas profits doubled in the year to March, but were still only £44m of the Thames total of more than £700m.

Thames, like other water companies, has become disillusioned with the lack of interest from British investors. Its shares have underperformed the rest of the stock market by more than 15 per cent over the past year and, before its talks with RWE were revealed, were languishing at just 867p.

The British firm's management is believed to be attracted by the prospect of using RWE's resources - it is valued at more than £13bn - to accelerate Thames's international expansion.

fields.headline: Bosses face safety crackdown
fields.standfirst: Prescott to unveil harsher fines and criminal proceedings - New Act planned for next parliament
fields.trailText: Deputy Prime Minister John Prescott will tomorrow launch a renewed crackdown on company directors who neglect health and safety regulations in their businesses.
fields.body:
Deputy Prime Minister John Prescott will tomorrow launch a renewed crackdown on company directors who neglect health and safety regulations in their businesses.

In the first of two speeches to Labour's conference in Brighton this week, Prescott will unveil a package of measures including harsher fines for safety breaches; a clearer definition of directors' responsibilities for health and safety; and measures to 'recycle' proceeds from financial penalties paid by directors and companies into strengthened regulation. An enhanced role for trade union safety representatives will also be included.

Officials at the Department for the Environment, Transport and the Regions are also working with the Home Office to strengthen the role of the Director of Public Prosecutions in securing convictions for health and safety breaches, and are co-operating on Jack Straw's plans for a new charge of corporate manslaughter.

Figures in the most recent Health and Safety Executive annual report indicate that fatal injuries at work fell from 274 in 1998 to 257 in 1999, and that there were falls of 5 per cent in major non-fatal accidents and those which kept people away from work for at least three days.

However, trade unions have argued that not enough is being done to reduce these levels faster, and have mounted a high-profile campaign spotlighting the continuation of dangerous practices by many firms and the need for clearer and more effective regulations.

Prescott believes that directors do not take health and safety issues seriously enough, and that the only way of focusing attention on the issue is to come down hard with a major review of fines and the introduction of new methods of preventing bad practice.

The Government does not simply want to raise penalties; it wants to overhaul health and safety regulations. There are also plans to 'fast track' certain offences where there is a feeling that the directors are guilty of gross negligence.

A government source said: 'We think the penalties for putting workers' safety at risk are not tough enough. In health and safety law the punishment does not fit the crime Higher fines are a certainty.'

The measures will form part of a new Safety Bill which is likely to be put on to the legislative programme early in the next parliament if Labour wins the general election. Sources say the DETR is already pushing for early parliamentary time for such a bill.

The Deputy Prime Ministers will also use his speech to announce that he will accept the conclusions of Lord Cullen's report into the Ladbroke Grove rail disaster when they emerge.

The anniversary of the tragedy falls at the beginning of next month. Prescott will also outline in his speech a new series of targets aiming to reduce the numbers of deaths and serious injuries in road accidents.

'As far as Cullen goes, without wanting to pre-empt anything, there is a full commitment to implementing what he comes up with at the end of his inquiry,' a Whitehall source said.

Any of Cullen's recommendations which require primary legislation can go into the Safety Bill.

webTitle: BT in Oftel inquiry over blocking hi-tech rivals

fields.headline: BT in Oftel inquiry over blocking hi-tech rivals
fields.trailText: Telecoms watchdog Oftel is attempting to stem criticism that it is too soft on BT by setting up a major inquiry into the way the former monopoly treats rivals wanting access to its local exchanges.
fields.body:
Telecoms watchdog Oftel is attempting to stem criticism that it is too soft on BT by setting up a major inquiry into the way the former monopoly treats rivals wanting access to its local exchanges.

The rivals want to be allowed into BT's buildings in order to introduce new technologies that would transform normal phone lines into state-of-the-art networks capable of carrying video signals and large amounts of data.

But BT has said that some of the exchanges are already so full that they have no room for other firms - a claim that has not yet been verified independently. This means that telecoms customers have no choice but to take BT's own new range of services.

Oftel, which has listened to the rivals' concerns, is to consult with telecom firms this month and then randomly select exchanges from the 5,500 sites across the UK.

So far BT has 'blacklisted' more than 400 of them: it says it is unable to open them up to its competitors for a number of reasons, including lack of space and problems with power supply.

A BT spokeswoman said: 'We are discussing an independent verification process with Oftel.' However, she added: 'We have said from the beginning that if anyone wants to look at them then they can.'

A spokesman for Oftel said: 'We will inspect the exchanges. We are not going to take BT's word for it. We will push them hard.'

But industry sources are angry that Oftel did not initiate the survey sooner.

'This should have started back in January. I don't think Oftel thought it through,' one source said.
fields.bodyText: Telecoms watchdog Oftel is attempting to stem criticism that it is too soft on BT by setting up a major inquiry into the way the former monopoly treats rivals wanting access to its local exchanges. The rivals want to be allowed into BT's buildings in order to introduce new technologies that would transform normal phone lines into state-of-the-art networks capable of carrying video signals and large amounts of data. But BT has said that some of the exchanges are already so full that they have no room for other firms - a claim that has not yet been verified independently. This means that telecoms customers have no choice but to take BT's own new range of services. Oftel, which has listened to the rivals' concerns, is to consult with telecom firms this month and then randomly select exchanges from the 5,500 sites across the UK. So far BT has 'blacklisted' more than 400 of them: it says it is unable to open them up to its competitors for a number of reasons, including lack of space and problems with power supply. A BT spokeswoman said: 'We are discussing an independent verification process with Oftel.' However, she added: 'We have said from the beginning that if anyone wants to look at them then they can.' A spokesman for Oftel said: 'We will inspect the exchanges. We are not going to take BT's word for it. We will push them hard.' But industry sources are angry that Oftel did not initiate the survey sooner. 'This should have started back in January. I don't think Oftel thought it through,' one source said.

fields.headline: Marital arts
fields.standfirst: It's been a week when you watched people squirm on screen and thought: 'There but for the grace of God...'
fields.trailText: Break Up | Sperm Wars | Love Is Not Enough | My Family
fields.body:
Break Up C4
Sperm Wars BBC2
Love Is Not Enough BBC1
My Family BBC1

On the wall of Graham's parents' house, where he was staying temporarily following the break-up of his marriage to Jane, there was a copy of the couple's 1991 wedding portrait. The camera homed in on Jane's fabulous legs. 'Very pretty girl... Could have been a model... Obviously, that was nine years ago...' said Graham with a tiny sigh of resignation before the shot switched to an unforgiving close-up of an impassive Jane now: arms crossed, eyes tired, not looking much like a model and subjecting herself to the apparently passive and ineffectual ministrations of the family mediation service as she and Graham negotiated the terms of their divorce.

If one was being kind, one could say that Graham, anti-hero of Break Up, was in the throes of a classic midlife crisis, even though there was an enormous amount of evidence to suggest that he hadn't grown up enough to justify one. Blandly good-looking and tautly muscled, Graham was an aerobics instructor but Jane (rather naively by her own admission) hadn't really thought too much about the fact that her husband spent his working days urging a roomful of Lycra-clad young women to go for the burn, or whatever it is that happens at aerobics classes. For a while she even believed that Graham's new girlfriend had been acquired after their split, though it had only been a few weeks since he'd fled the marital home. Then she found the notes - 'Thank you for the personal services. Love, Me' - hidden in the garage.

Graham, patently a bit of a body fascist, was obviously fairly disappointed by the fact that Jane, the mother of his three children, wasn't quite the looker she had been. He had consoled himself, however, by running up close to £20,000 of debt and now, on top of all this, had suddenly acquired a new house. Not a one-bedroom flat, mind, but a whole house, costing more than the family home.

As he moved in, he gave us a tour, while his mum vacuumed in the background. 'Do you expect me to live on the street?!' Graham had demanded of Jane. Compromise was clearly not on his agenda, but the maths didn't add up: a reluctantly revealed monthly income of £1,600 wasn't enough to support his wife, three small children, two mortgages and all that debt which, as the mediators pointed out, amounted to £3,400 a month. While Graham insisted that the State pick up the tab for Jane and their kids ('I've paid taxes!'), his wife's restraint was saintly. I wanted to punch his lights out.

Wednesday night was good for 'there but for the grace of...' documentaries. At the same time as Jane and Graham were tussling with the horrible banality of their divorce, on BBC2 in Sperm Wars, a cocktail waitress called, confusingly, Pamela Reno, from Reno, Nevada, was trying to persuade us that it was perfectly acceptable to harvest the sperm of her dead 19-year-old son, Jeremy (Russian roulette at a party, if you're interested), acquire an egg donor (ideally one of Jeremy's ex-girlfriends, so she could show the putative offspring pictures of 'mommy and daddy together') and a surrogate mother, and create herself a lovely little 'souvenir' grandchild, or preferably two ('I'd like twins!').

This modern gothic horror story was, however, counterbalanced by the slightly less ethically clear-cut tale of the Vernoffs, whose son Bruce had died of an (apparently accidental, though this was a bit vague) overdose after a car crash, and whose wife, Gaby, had been planning to start a family shortly before he died. Here there was at least a loving, close-knit family for the (very much alive and now cutely toddling) result of Bruce's posthumous sperm harvest, but once you start relieving even a happily married - albeit undeniably dead - man of his sperm, where does it end?

In the cases of Graham and Pamela it is so very easy easy to judge. They invariably set themselves up and the selective directing and the editing merely helped us despise them, even though one recognises that the 'truth' we are presented with can never be the whole truth. It was also very easy to judge the participants in the week's other big curtain-twitching documentary - the first in the series Love Is Not Enough, which follows a handful of British couples through the harrowing year-long process of attempting to adopt a child.

Caught up in this particularly sneaky parlour game, I found myself thinking that moneyed and middle-class Mark and Sarah (looking for a Chinese baby and with one Romanian adoption already under their belts) really ought to clear away those three empty morning-after-the-night-before wine bottles from the kitchen table at which little Josh was eating his Rice Krispies while they all waited for the social worker to arrive. And if Linda and Tony seriously thought they could persuade their social worker that the cluttered and claustrophobic spare-room-cum-cupboard in the eaves was really suitable for a new child, then they probably ought to be employed doing makeovers on Changing Rooms .

And surely Paula and Al could see that talking about hearing 'voices from God' and belonging to a happy-clappy charismatic church called The Frontline made them appear, in these godless times, more like weird cultists than staunch upholders of Christian values. Nope, on the evidence of the first episode in this series I don't think I'd let any of this lot take on even one of the 7,000 children a year who need adopting - but that was surely the point of the exercise: from the viewer's sofa, this was only a gameshow. Ooh... now there's an idea!

My Family has been touted as the first British sitcom to be created in the collaborative American mode, even including a writer with Seinfeld on his CV. Which is amusing mostly because the result is like an updated Butterflies, with Zoe Wanamaker in the good-mum-bad-cook Wendy Craig role and Robert Lindsay doing a slightly less lugubrious, though no less put-upon version of Geoffrey Palmer's dentist. It is full of those cheery, stagey, wacky one-liners that one can spot several miles away waiting patiently in a drivetime jam on the M25 ('Does the phrase "pull the other one" mean anything to you?', 'Ah! You think she's got a sister?' And for toad-in-the-hole sans sausages, try 'toad-en-vacances'... except that these people would never eat toad in the hole any more).

My Family is never less than relentlessly and unfashionably middle-class, but while the sofas are even bigger and squashier and the artful arrangement of objets even more contrived than those you'll find in a Judi Denchcom, I still enjoyed it because I loved Butterflies , which sort of attempted to grapple with the rising tide of Seventies feminism in a defi antly British (and therefore utterly woolly and suburban) context. Perhaps future storylines could push the sitcom envelope a wee bit further: adopting Chinese babies, say, or harvesting gold fillings from the bodies of patients who have died under Lindsay's local anaesthetic. That might just about turn today's mild titters into tomorrow's big belly laughs.

webTitle: Dance: Can We Afford This | Bejart Ballet

fields.headline: Athletic support
fields.standfirst: DV8 go too far in their new show about perfect and imperfect bodies
fields.trailText: Dance: Can We Afford This | Bejart Ballet
fields.body:
Can We Afford This DV8, QEH, London SE1

Bejart Ballet Sadler's Wells, London EC1

Pre-Olympic spectacle has finally spluttered into London, like a spent wave from Bondi Beach. We can now catch up with performances from the Olympic Arts Festival in Sydney last month: Sylvie Guillem gyrating on a table in Maurice Bejart's Bolero and DV8's Can We Afford This, commissioned by the festival.

DV8's show, directed by Lloyd Newson, tackles issues raised by Olympic media coverage and coincidentally also by Bejart's company (Guillem guests tonight and tomorrow). What price the body beautiful? Are elite athletes worthy role models or fairground freaks? Students looking for dissertation topics will find plenty on DV8's website (www.dv8.co.uk.) Can We Afford This purports to be 'a piece about perfection and pretence, of how society measures individuals and how we, in turn, value ourselves'. Actually, it's less of a heavyweight event, more of a variety show.

The set is a masterpiece of theatrical illusion. Greensward covers a steep, people-eating slope: 'Keep Off the Grass' warns a sign. Transgressing bodies are swallowed by a sappy quagmire - but when David Toole pulls himself free by his powerful arms, we realise he has no bottom half. A passing performer assaults him with taboo questions about his truncated body: does he have an anus, can he have sex? Toole preserves his mystery by staring silently, quizzically, at the audience. His recompense for the offence is a series of duets more entrancing and disturbing than anything he danced with Candoco, the wheelchair-abled company.

A cast of 17 performers materialises from trenches and pillars. Some sport funfair props - balloons, hoops, comic masks; others expose their bodies and souls. Interspersed with turns, 'true' confessions and interrogations come sections of pure dance. 'Blessed are the Average' proclaims a neon sign - but DV8's performers are anything but average. They are professionals, used to an audience's gaze: obese Larry Goldhuber, old Diana Payne-Myers and camp compere Paul Capsis, as well as the legless Toole.

So we should not trust them when they present themselves as needy, abashed or boastful. Newson is not really confronting us with our voyeurism, as he has done in previous, harsher shows. He is playing games with bodies, words and images. He makes his troupe literally and metaphorically clown around, jump through hoops, put a spin on relationships, question the cost of living and of dancing.

One man proposes to charge £5 for graceful arm movements, with a surcharge for graceful arms with emotion. Another offers to pay stork-legged Kate Coyne to 'do that leg thing' - a virtuoso rond de jambe. A piece of tape is used to measure the length of an arm, a penis, a love affair. A suicide reckons that the price is too high and ends the show with a bang instead of a whimper.

The rag-bag assembly of themes has not justified such a conclusion, nor the abrupt introduction of child abuse in the closing moments. In this rambling piece, Newson hasn't earned the right to go too far. He has also trespassed into Pina Bausch territory, which he can't afford to do if DV8 is to preserve its reputation for originality. Perhaps he should have waited until the Olympics fired his imagination - or indignation - before creating a piece about perfection.

Sad to see Bejart Ballet in less than medal-winning form, recycling works that have been better danced in the past. Bejart's ballet-based choreography specialises in graceful arms with emotion and lots of 'that leg thing'. Themes tend to be inspirational; steps, like costumes, are minimal but arresting. Men go topless, with the better-honed torsos displayed in the front line.

In Bolero (1961), the solo spot can be taken by a man or a woman: the predatory horde that closes in on the Chosen One, however, is invariably male. Today's athletic physiques mean that a gaunt girl on the table, whether she is Sylvie Guillem or Elisabet Ros, is much less sexy than the bare-chested man with leonine hair, Jorge Donne, on whom it was made.

The brand-new work in the opening programme, Elton-Berg , posed some peculiar questions. An acrobatic woman, Karline Marion, was folded, origami-style, by two partners. The trio could qualify as a new Olympic gymnastic discipline, with points for spotting the difference in artistic interpretation when the same routine is performed first to music by Alban Berg and then by Elton John. What are we looking at when a woman is spatchcocked between two men, with or without emotion? What value do we place on the music that accompanies such contortions?
