webTitle: Art: Apocalypse: Beauty and Horror in Contemporary Art

fields.headline: It's just hell, darling...
fields.standfirst: The most horrifying thing about the Royal Academy's Apocalypse is the bottleneck on the way in
fields.trailText: Art: The most horrifying thing about the Royal Academy's Apocalypse is the bottleneck on the way in.
fields.body:
Apocalypse: Beauty and Horror in Contemporary Art Royal Academy, London SW1 until 15 December

This was the glum prospect, as hyped by an alarmist press: a couple of porn stars grinding away, a meteorite felling the Pope, and 10,000 jackbooted Nazis tearing each other apart. A German artist was going to frighten the life out of us with a dark and dripping cellar. There would be X-rated rooms, bus stops from Auschwitz and all manner of mind-jolting shocks.

Norman Rosenthal, the show's co-curator, made the traditional pre-emptive statement in which he criticised the public's reluctance to square up to the brutalities of life. Dare you face the horror, the horror? The gauntlet was thrown down with a thwack.

If it's true horror you seek, then Apocalypse isn't your show. Cod horror, Hollywood horror, ghost-train horror, maybe, but nothing that isn't several prophylactic stages removed from life's brutalities. The porn stars in Chris Cunningham's video are slick with Vaseline and panstick, their sex-and-violence routine, for all its furious spilling of blood, aims for Francis Bacon but falls somewhere between a Nike ad and the twitchy rhythms of Lara Croft. The Pope beneath his meteorite is too much of a waxwork to give up the ghost. As for Jake and Dinos Chapman's Nazis - well, we'll come to them in a moment. So 'Apocalypse' is hardly the seven-headed beast of Revelation, rising from the waves to smite you with dread. Don't trust the hyperbole of that subtitle, either. Horror and beauty in contemporary art are like Gilbert and Sullivan in light opera. They go together - and they always have, like the butchered hare and the peaches in a Dutch still-life. Some of the best works in this show, by Luc Tuymans, for example, have something to say about both. But the more obvious contrast here is between the very good and the mediocre.

The staging of the show is a spectacle in itself. I've never seen the Royal Academy more superbly transformed. To enter 'Apocalypse', you have to squeeze through a door no bigger than the trap to a coalhole and creep down the narrow staircase into Gregor Schneider's cellar. This shunts you out into a sequence of disconnected scenes - a red-carpet sacristy for the Pope, a sepulchral museum for the Chapman vitrines, cool, clear space for Mariko Mori's pagoda, wedding-cake décor for Jeff Koons's kitsch.

Schneider's cellar is supposed to be authentic, a maze of dark, clammy corridors removed in its entirety from the artist's Rhineland home. In fact, it feels exactly like what it is - a stage set that he built inside the basement walls. It feels distinctly theatrical, with its creaking doors and Hammer effects.

The denouement comes with a short film projected in the garish gloom in which a camera haunts this space, nosing its way past radiators and down corridors - think of The Shining and, come to that, Eraserhead . All of them are rather more potent than Schneider's installation, although there is a sharp frisson on exit when you look back and discover how cramped the place really was, what a tiny distance you actually travelled.

Maurizio Catellan's Pope has celluloid forebears, too, in this case the face-down prelate in Un chien Andalou, burdened with a piano containing a donkey's corpse. But the prostration of John Paul II is hardly so savage or surreal. The fake meteorite that has supposedly plunged through the ceiling - a hole has been engineered in the skylight - rests upon a waxwork with its vestments still in perfect order. The Pope has his eyes closed and frowns as if in prayer. He is down, but not out; indeed, he looks a sight more robust than the pontiff himself. Catellan has a genuine gift for tragi-comedy, but his latest piece makes no headway in either direction. It feels like a punchline without the joke. You can't get close to the Pope - he's yards away behind the barrier ropes. Crowds strain to see what's going on through the scrummage of shoulders. It's a tactical measure, consistent with the governing principle of this show, which is that you should always be aware that you're having the Apocalypse Experience.

There is the bottleneck at the cellar door, the traffic jam hoping to get into Cunningham's 18-Only video, the massive tailback queueing for Mori's pagoda. The pagoda is a completely entrancing construction. Made of many different kinds of glass, it has doors of liquid crystal that fluctuate in colour at any human approach. The whole effect is of a fairytale mirage, the aurora borealis momentarily frozen. But if you're thinking of queuing for the film inside - one person at a time, special slippers provided, phone bookings taken - then let me tell you that it's a spacey reel of pretty raindrops and swirly planets. More fun to be had at your local Imax.

Only two seats are available for Mike Kelley's LA movie, which is a pity because it's a lot more substantial than his usual sorry offering of discarded toys. A Domestic Scene is filmed in one continuous take, a bit like Hitchcock's Rope , which it more than resembles with its histrionic couple threatening each other in a claustrophobic flat. The premise is absurd - one has no idea how he got there, the other claims he's sullied their love nest. This is an art farce - 'let's make an abstract expressionist painting of our passion' - but it's also an un-American satire with a mordant punchline.

Kelley's compatriot, Jeff Koons, is showing a gigantic steel cast of one of those squeaky little balloon-dogs that adults make for children's parties. The surface is gorgeous, the metallic red of a Christmas-tree bauble. And a strange transformation has occurred - the twisted knots now look like navels, the ears like polished missiles. But compared to Luc Tuymans's transfixingly eerie paintings, with their ghostly rooms and dematerialising faces, Koons's hot dog is atrium art.

Tuymans is better known for painting diseased and injured bodies. But the RA doesn't go for these; in fact, it's pretty cavalier about the whole idea of an apocalypse, taking it to mean anything that adds voltage to its switchback ride. That ride has its dips and highs, masterfully choreographed. It sends you from the thundering Aphex Twin soundtrack of Cunningham's video straight into the pastoral quiet of Tim Noble and Sue Webster's captivating shadowplay. Backlit with a simple yellow bulb, a tottering heap of rubbish casts its silhouette against the wall: two figures sit peacefully on a summit, a breeze stirring the grass at sunset. The grass is a tangled skein of cassette tape, the breeze created by the movement of visitors through the gallery. I'd guess that this will be many people's favourite piece and not just because it's beautiful - which it is - or because it reveals its own low-tech artistry. That part is simple: junk into gold. But the silhouette allows your mind to roam - summers past, high vistas, maybe Beckett's Happy Days with its sunset at the end of the world.

None of the art in 'Apocalypse' was made especially for this show. Two generations are represented and six different nations, so you couldn't feasibly elaborate some definition of art as it's happening. But there is a presiding taste here - Rosenthal has claimed it as his own - and it's reflected in the staging of the show. So much of this art is filtered through Hollywood, the box and the ad trade - from Koons's cereal-packet paintings to the sci-fi spacemen ushering you into Mori's pagoda - that it would be surprising if the experience wasn't brash and exciting. In these conditions, artists like Tuymans, Kelley, Noble and Webster are bound to stand out in the shallows.

There is an apocalyptic work in this show, the only one that tries to envisage human horror as a never-ending cycle played out in the afterlife as it already has been on earth. This is the Chapman brothers' diorama, a vast scale-model of Hell, fulsomely detailed, baroque in its excess. Thousands of inch-high Nazis are being flayed, disembowelled, crucified and torched - by other Nazis as by those mutant mannequins that have become the Chapman trademark. History is there in the camps and gas chambers, in the jungle landscapes that echo Korea and Vietnam, in the idea of an endless loop - so painstakingly realised. But it's boxed history, with an easy target and a model-shop aesthetic of spongy furze, Humbrol paint and indestructible soldiers. More than that, it is Indiana Jones, Nightmare Freddie and Francis Ford Coppola, assembling another row of severed heads on spikes. Hell as mediated through multiple media. Small apocalypse, nobody hurt.
fields.bodyText: Apocalypse: Beauty and Horror in Contemporary Art Royal Academy, London SW1 until 15 December This was the glum prospect, as hyped by an alarmist press: a couple of porn stars grinding away, a meteorite felling the Pope, and 10,000 jackbooted Nazis tearing each other apart. A German artist was going to frighten the life out of us with a dark and dripping cellar. There would be X-rated rooms, bus stops from Auschwitz and all manner of mind-jolting shocks. Norman Rosenthal, the show's co-curator, made the traditional pre-emptive statement in which he criticised the public's reluctance to square up to the brutalities of life. Dare you face the horror, the horror? The gauntlet was thrown down with a thwack. If it's true horror you seek, then Apocalypse isn't your show. Cod horror, Hollywood horror, ghost-train horror, maybe, but nothing that isn't several prophylactic stages removed from life's brutalities. The porn stars in Chris Cunningham's video are slick with Vaseline and panstick, their sex-and-violence routine, for all its furious spilling of blood, aims for Francis Bacon but falls somewhere between a Nike ad and the twitchy rhythms of Lara Croft. The Pope beneath his meteorite is too much of a waxwork to give up the ghost. As for Jake and Dinos Chapman's Nazis - well, we'll come to them in a moment. So 'Apocalypse' is hardly the seven-headed beast of Revelation, rising from the waves to smite you with dread. Don't trust the hyperbole of that subtitle, either. Horror and beauty in contemporary art are like Gilbert and Sullivan in light opera. They go together - and they always have, like the butchered hare and the peaches in a Dutch still-life. Some of the best works in this show, by Luc Tuymans, for example, have something to say about both. But the more obvious contrast here is between the very good and the mediocre. The staging of the show is a spectacle in itself. I've never seen the Royal Academy more superbly transformed. To enter 'Apocalypse', you have to squeeze through a door no bigger than the trap to a coalhole and creep down the narrow staircase into Gregor Schneider's cellar. This shunts you out into a sequence of disconnected scenes - a red-carpet sacristy for the Pope, a sepulchral museum for the Chapman vitrines, cool, clear space for Mariko Mori's pagoda, wedding-cake décor for Jeff Koons's kitsch. Schneider's cellar is supposed to be authentic, a maze of dark, clammy corridors removed in its entirety from the artist's Rhineland home. In fact, it feels exactly like what it is - a stage set that he built inside the basement walls. It feels distinctly theatrical, with its creaking doors and Hammer effects. The denouement comes with a short film projected in the garish gloom in which a camera haunts this space, nosing its way past radiators and down corridors - think of The Shining and, come to that, Eraserhead . All of them are rather more potent than Schneider's installation, although there is a sharp frisson on exit when you look back and discover how cramped the place really was, what a tiny distance you actually travelled. Maurizio Catellan's Pope has celluloid forebears, too, in this case the face-down prelate in Un chien Andalou, burdened with a piano containing a donkey's corpse. But the prostration of John Paul II is hardly so savage or surreal. The fake meteorite that has supposedly plunged through the ceiling - a hole has been engineered in the skylight - rests upon a waxwork with its vestments still in perfect order. The Pope has his eyes closed and frowns as if in prayer. He is down, but not out; indeed, he looks a sight more robust than the pontiff himself. Catellan has a genuine gift for tragi-comedy, but his latest piece makes no headway in either direction. It feels like a punchline without the joke. You can't get close to the Pope - he's yards away behind the barrier ropes. Crowds strain to see what's going on through the scrummage of shoulders. It's a tactical measure, consistent with the governing principle of this show, which is that you should always be aware that you're having the Apocalypse Experience. There is the bottleneck at the cellar door, the traffic jam hoping to get into Cunningham's 18-Only video, the massive tailback queueing for Mori's pagoda. The pagoda is a completely entrancing construction. Made of many different kinds of glass, it has doors of liquid crystal that fluctuate in colour at any human approach. The whole effect is of a fairytale mirage, the aurora borealis momentarily frozen. But if you're thinking of queuing for the film inside - one person at a time, special slippers provided, phone bookings taken - then let me tell you that it's a spacey reel of pretty raindrops and swirly planets. More fun to be had at your local Imax. Only two seats are available for Mike Kelley's LA movie, which is a pity because it's a lot more substantial than his usual sorry offering of discarded toys. A Domestic Scene is filmed in one continuous take, a bit like Hitchcock's Rope , which it more than resembles with its histrionic couple threatening each other in a claustrophobic flat. The premise is absurd - one has no idea how he got there, the other claims he's sullied their love nest. This is an art farce - 'let's make an abstract expressionist painting of our passion' - but it's also an un-American satire with a mordant punchline. Kelley's compatriot, Jeff Koons, is showing a gigantic steel cast of one of those squeaky little balloon-dogs that adults make for children's parties. The surface is gorgeous, the metallic red of a Christmas-tree bauble. And a strange transformation has occurred - the twisted knots now look like navels, the ears like polished missiles. But compared to Luc Tuymans's transfixingly eerie paintings, with their ghostly rooms and dematerialising faces, Koons's hot dog is atrium art. Tuymans is better known for painting diseased and injured bodies. But the RA doesn't go for these; in fact, it's pretty cavalier about the whole idea of an apocalypse, taking it to mean anything that adds voltage to its switchback ride. That ride has its dips and highs, masterfully choreographed. It sends you from the thundering Aphex Twin soundtrack of Cunningham's video straight into the pastoral quiet of Tim Noble and Sue Webster's captivating shadowplay. Backlit with a simple yellow bulb, a tottering heap of rubbish casts its silhouette against the wall: two figures sit peacefully on a summit, a breeze stirring the grass at sunset. The grass is a tangled skein of cassette tape, the breeze created by the movement of visitors through the gallery. I'd guess that this will be many people's favourite piece and not just because it's beautiful - which it is - or because it reveals its own low-tech artistry. That part is simple: junk into gold. But the silhouette allows your mind to roam - summers past, high vistas, maybe Beckett's Happy Days with its sunset at the end of the world. None of the art in 'Apocalypse' was made especially for this show. Two generations are represented and six different nations, so you couldn't feasibly elaborate some definition of art as it's happening. But there is a presiding taste here - Rosenthal has claimed it as his own - and it's reflected in the staging of the show. So much of this art is filtered through Hollywood, the box and the ad trade - from Koons's cereal-packet paintings to the sci-fi spacemen ushering you into Mori's pagoda - that it would be surprising if the experience wasn't brash and exciting. In these conditions, artists like Tuymans, Kelley, Noble and Webster are bound to stand out in the shallows. There is an apocalyptic work in this show, the only one that tries to envisage human horror as a never-ending cycle played out in the afterlife as it already has been on earth. This is the Chapman brothers' diorama, a vast scale-model of Hell, fulsomely detailed, baroque in its excess. Thousands of inch-high Nazis are being flayed, disembowelled, crucified and torched - by other Nazis as by those mutant mannequins that have become the Chapman trademark. History is there in the camps and gas chambers, in the jungle landscapes that echo Korea and Vietnam, in the idea of an endless loop - so painstakingly realised. But it's boxed history, with an easy target and a model-shop aesthetic of spongy furze, Humbrol paint and indestructible soldiers. More than that, it is Indiana Jones, Nightmare Freddie and Francis Ford Coppola, assembling another row of severed heads on spikes. Hell as mediated through multiple media. Small apocalypse, nobody hurt.

webTitle: Moral muse: How do I protect my little girl?

fields.headline: Moral muse
fields.standfirst: How do I protect my little girl?
fields.trailText: How do I protect my little girl?
fields.body:
My friend and I both have girls aged 18 months. We always meet on a Monday afternoon for a coffee and to let the children play. However, I am becoming reluctant to visit her as her child is always unwell with a cold or a cough. Recently her little girl caught thrush of the mouth but she didn't tell me until we were already there and the kids were playing. together - sharing toys, putting things in their mouths. She has also visited me when her daughter had a stomach bug and exposed my family to it.

Although I understand that children will catch ailments from each other, I don't want to expose my daughter (or myself) to unnecessary infections. However, it would seem rude to terminate the visit on learning her daughter was ill. How do I tell her that I don't want the children to mix if they are ill?
A.S. of Oxfordshire

The degree of protectiveness mothers show towards their children varies widely, but each one is convinced that she alone has got it right, and of course it's a highly emotive area, relatively inaccessible to logic. The problem resolves into how to manage your different attitudes without injuring your friendship and the children's opportunity to socialise.

First, accept that different points of view are legitimate and don't get too prescriptive about your own. You feel strongly about this friend's (in your view) lax manners, so it becomes an issue with moral overtones. She is careless, selfish - from your perspective. You disapprove. Your child might be contaminated by hers, physically and metaphorically.

It's unlikely that your annoyance has gone unnoticed. She is probably feeling similar resentment, arguing to herself that you are over-protective, narrow-minded, that you will have a stultifying, repressive effect on your child and, by extension, on hers too. Maybe there is already a letter from her, winging its way to me...

Let loose your sense of humour and reduce it to its proper perspective. We are not talking cholera or typhoid here. We are concerned with minor, brief social inconveniences which will have the beneficial effect of adding to the sum of your child's immune defences (and yours). One realises how effective those defences are when you see what happens to a child who has none.

Next, be more frank and open. You might telephone before the next meeting and say: 'We've an important event - birthday, granny-visit, trip to the seaside - this week and I want to avoid coughs and colds. Can you let me know if little Annabel gets any bugs? - in which case, maybe we could postpone our meeting.' And you should, of course, undertake to do the same for her.

Once your child starts at nursery or playgroup, you'll be horrified at how many infections she gets and hands round to all within sneezing distance. Maybe your friend's child does a lot of socialising on the toddler circuit, so that she is already blasé about perpetual runny noses, and sees it as the norm. So will you in two or three years' time.

Readers' response

Exposing your daughter to numerous ailments when young is probably one of the best things you could do for her. When my son was little, he seemed to be ill all winter. And as my husband and I had immigrated from abroad, we would catch everything too - our house was described by one of our friends as a 'plague house'. However, by the time he started school, we all had highly developed immune systems and managed to get through winter without so much as a cold.
D.C. of London

Next week's dilema

When I married my husband he was slim. In four years, he has put on about two stones. Although I still love him, I don't find him very attractive any more. I have tried to help him lose weight but he is not interested. I feel he is not taking my feelings into consideration and for the sake of our marriage he should try to do something about his weight. Should I give him some kind of ultimatum to make him diet? N.A. of Surrey

Write to Observer Review or email margaret.cook@observer.co.uk. Views on problems must reach us by Wednesday. Margaret Cook writes for Woman's Journal

webTitle: True confessions: She wanted a plumber. I wanted her. So I lied...

fields.headline: True confessions
fields.standfirst: She wanted a plumber. I wanted her. So I lied...
fields.trailText: She wanted a plumber. I wanted her. So I lied...
fields.body:
After six months as a single man I began to develop a relationship with a woman from the office called Emma. I was a low-ranking employee; Emma was in the company's top three. We started talking for the first time at one of my rare appearances at a work outing. I had noticed Emma at work but we had never spoken. She was, in effect, my boss and I assumed that she was far too good-looking and talented for me.

However, the look in her eye and the occasional smile led me to believe that we might get on well. After a shy 'hello' I began to chat to her. All I could think of was incidental conversation such as how loud the jukebox was, the smoky atmosphere of the pub. She didn't look particularly interested.

As I was about to give up she leaned across and shouted into my ear: 'You used to be a plumber didn't you?' Grasping the chance, I began to boast of my plumbing expertise. Her sudden enthusiasm for the subject was explained by her recent plans for decorating her new flat, in particular the bathroom. My confidence grew and with it my plumbing achievements and knowledge of the skill.

Gradually our workmates drifted away and time was called at the bar. Deep in our conversation about grouting we moved on to a late-night wine bar and continued to bond over the option of antique or modern taps.

Over the next couple of weeks I spent more and more time at her flat, and as our romance blossomed she started to return to the subject of her bathroom and her desire to have it redone.

I knew she was well paid and assumed she would get some top designing plumber to come and do it for her. But I was wrong. She asked me and I panicked.

The truth was that I had only been a plumber's mate and I had been sacked after three weeks, most of those spent lugging radiators and lengths of pipe up and down flights of stairs. In reality it was only a labouring job.

Emma wanted me to replace her suite with one similar to that in my own bathroom.Despite my desperate attempts to wriggle out of it with excuses of not having the right tools (she said she'd buy me new ones), the cost (she said no problem) or that I couldn't take money from her (we'd go on holiday and she'd pay), I could see no way out.

Over the next week I read more books on plumbing, central heating, tiling and tongue-and-grooving than Handy Andy. Just when I thought my fate was sealed and I was on the verge of turning her bathroom into a leaking building site, I broke my arm. Not wanting to wait until my arm had healed Emma paid a professional to do the job - much to my relief.

Her bathroom is finished and my arm is out of plaster but I still haven't confessed that I don't know one side of a washer from the other. I live in fear that one day she might want to change the bathroom or she'll get a leaky sink; for now I've got away with it.

 The author's name has been changed.

If you have a true confession, email it to kim.bunce@observer.co.uk

webTitle: Stewart Hennessey: Here are The Rules for the boys

fields.headline: Are you man or Martian?
fields.standfirst: For too long, men have been told to 'feel for women' when they should just feel them. So forget the dogma - here are The Rules for the boys
fields.trailText: For too long, men have been told to 'feel for women' when they should just feel them. So forget the dogma - here are The Rules for the boys.
fields.body:
From Samuel Richardson's instructive novel for young women, Clarissa (1747), to What A Young Woman Ought to Know (hot in the early 1900s), to the modern dating bible, The Rules, all the oh-so-earnest advice being dispensed to young women can be distilled into one dull command: don't put out.

This is not what men want to hear. Yet in recent centuries even they have taken to saying it. And this woefully acceptable statement of the joyless is the product of the feminisation of male culture, wherein men 'feel for women' when they should just be plain feeling them. It's wrecked the whole dating game. The fun battle of the sexes has been cancelled owing to men defecting.

Take the exquisite and tragically well-selling example of John Gray's sodden wet waffle for worriers, Men Are From Mars, Women are from Venus. Therein Uncle John tells our lost generation of lily-livered liberals that it's wrong to just expect a woman to put out. Apparently sex is all about intuition, timing and - naturellement - sensitivity (the much-favoured term of the self-obsessed and touchy). Well, do me with a porcupine on a bamboo stick! Be lost without you, John.

If you haven't got sexy qualities you are not going to acquire them from a man who has nothing better to do with his time than boast in print about his wonderful technique and respect for womenhood. All modern sex manuals trade on neurosis and fear of sex and they show that the repressed worriers have the upper hand. They are nag-presents, given to cowed, modern men by fretting, modern women on the desperate assumption that a self-satisfied book will change their lover's personality. And the prideless bloke even says thanks, on occasion. The worried and hormoneless have been buying these sex-as-problem books for too long. It falls to men to foil this conspiracy of neurotics. It falls to men to shark, shamelessly.

Instinct, taste and perhaps alcohol will decree when it is a good idea to have one's bones jumped. If you need a book to tell you then you're already doomed to eternal wetness (and I don't mean primed for fun). Reading a smug, worthy book about it is not going to help you judge. It's just going to make you smug and worthy. That PC culture seized the mantle of repression from Victorians, and kept us worrying about sex, is well-documented, especially by those who say we have moved beyond that and are now really sussed; postmodern or post-postmodern or postman-pat or whatever it is. But, like the Third Way, it's not a great fantasy.

Where we would call our attitude to dating and sex 'enlightened and sensitive' now, many of our more bawdy, ribaldrous and pre-Victorian forebears would call it touchy, self-obsessed, fearful and - perhaps the most important point in our narcissistic times - self-conscious. Most people would agree that one's sex life is nobody's business except one's lovers, so why are all these do-gooders writing self-satisfied books explaining (inexplicable) sexuality and turning it from a joyous and deeply personal mystery into a consciously comprehensible and very public social science project? Of course, in many cases they are just trying to say 'I'm a great lay', yet their dry analysis suggests nothing more than a strong will to prove they are a great lay, and we all know how tiresome that is between the sheets. In his follow-up bestseller, imaginatively entitled Mars and Venus in the Bedroom, Gray actually tells us of a particularly good seeing-to he gave his wife. And right riveting it isn't too.

There is a tragic dearth of self-help sages counterbalancing this supposedly sensitive attitude to sex. Most self-help manuals are of no practical use whatsoever except to make the uptight feel that their uptightness is 'understandable' (as opposed to amazingly dull at parties) and 'in hand' now that they've read Mr Great Lay's opus. But where is The Guide To How To Have Sex That May Or May Not Be A Really Bad Idea But Right Now I Don't Give A Monkeys ? That's the kind of book that would keep the species going, and make life interesting. There is no Put Outters Manual, no What A Young Shark Ought To Know, no Men Are From Mars They've Travelled Far So Please Give Them One. Until now...

After much consultation with the kind of men you wouldn't introduce your sister to, the compilation is under way for The Sacred Principles Of Counteracting Wet And Soul-Destroying Advice To Not Put Out, aka Sharking, aka A Young Man's Duty. So far we've got four sacred principles:-

1 Be happy. Nothing is more attractive than happiness. No jawline, moody pose, clothes, reputation or wealth; nothing beats looking like life's great.

2 Feign respect. If you can't develop any real respect - and they can make it tricky - feign it. No respect, no chance. Even the most drunken slapper wants to believe you respect her.

3 Diddley squat comes to he who waits. If you haven't got the guts, technique and charm to shark, you'll just get drunks, desperadoes and dullards, but mostly you'll get nothing. So don't bother leaving the house.

4 The whole art of chatting up is shutting up. It is entirely about getting them to do the talking - especially about themselves. Draw them out, crack jokes, be knowing, understanding, always listen carefully and look fascinated. Next thing they know, they feel intimate with you. Cross-refer to past comments; just listen to one minute, ignore the next 10 minutes and bring the one back up to show what an amazingly attentive guy you are.

Men, it is your duty to follow these rules. Shark first, worry later. The women will worry enough anyway without you telling them they're right to do so. Thus it always was until the world turned wet.

 Stewart Hennessey's debut novel, Drowning in the Shallows, an anti-PC satire on the immaturity of young adults, is out now, published by Review at £6.99.

That's the kind of book that would keep the species going, and make life interesting. There is no Put Outters Manual, no What A Young Shark Ought To Know, no Men Are From Mars They've Travelled Far So Please Give Them One. Until now... After much consultation with the kind of men you wouldn't introduce your sister to, the compilation is under way for The Sacred Principles Of Counteracting Wet And Soul-Destroying Advice To Not Put Out, aka Sharking, aka A Young Man's Duty. So far we've got four sacred principles:- 1 Be happy. Nothing is more attractive than happiness. No jawline, moody pose, clothes, reputation or wealth; nothing beats looking like life's great. 2 Feign respect. If you can't develop any real respect - and they can make it tricky - feign it. No respect, no chance. Even the most drunken slapper wants to believe you respect her. 3 Diddley squat comes to he who waits. If you haven't got the guts, technique and charm to shark, you'll just get drunks, desperadoes and dullards, but mostly you'll get nothing. So don't bother leaving the house. 4 The whole art of chatting up is shutting up. It is entirely about getting them to do the talking - especially about themselves. Draw them out, crack jokes, be knowing, understanding, always listen carefully and look fascinated. Next thing they know, they feel intimate with you. Cross-refer to past comments; just listen to one minute, ignore the next 10 minutes and bring the one back up to show what an amazingly attentive guy you are. Men, it is your duty to follow these rules. Shark first, worry later. The women will worry enough anyway without you telling them they're right to do so. Thus it always was until the world turned wet.  Stewart Hennessey's debut novel, Drowning in the Shallows, an anti-PC satire on the immaturity of young adults, is out now, published by Review at £6.99. webTitle: Interview: Salman Rushdie on his move to New York

fields.headline: Manhattan transfer
fields.standfirst: Salman Rushdie's comments in the New York Times about his move to America  triggered a furore in this country. Now, for the first time, you can read the interview with  D.T. Max  that caused the storm
fields.trailText: Salman Rushdie's comments in the New York Times about his move to America triggered a furore in this country. Now, for the first time, you can read the interview with D.T. Max that caused the storm.
fields.body:
In New York, Salman Rushdie may finally have found a city he likes as much as his home town. 'It's a Western rewrite of Bombay,' he says. 'There's a similar bustle and noise.' He is sitting in his agent's office in Midtown, genially ticking off the many ways Manhattan, to which he moved early this year, suits him. His tone is that of an excited tourist. He praises New York's 'famous electricity'. He loves 'being able to get lost' in Central Park and adores the fresh bread from the local bakeries. He says the city has a wonderful 'neighbourhoodliness'.

This is not the ending anyone expected, least of all Rushdie himself. In 1989, when Ayatollah Khomeini ordered the faithful to track down and kill him for the alleged blasphemies in The Satanic Verses, Rushdie, now 53, thought he would soon be dead. He went into hiding, protected by the British Government. In the intervening years, hit squads killed the Japanese translator of the book, wounded the Italian translator and the Norwegian publisher - but Rushdie survived. In 1998, under pressure from Britain, Iran said it would not carry out the fatwa. Rushdie was free to resume his life, but what sort of life was left?

There was resentment in England at the millions of pounds the Government had been spending to protect him. The British press dogged him, reinforcing its readership's sense that Rushdie had somehow brought his troubles on himself. Most of all, London had been the site of his captivity. He had lived in roughly 30 houses in nine years. It was time for something new. One choice for Rushdie might have been a small town where he could have written in relative anonymity. 'But what would I do in Iowa?' he asks. 'I'd commit suicide.'

Instead, he came to Manhattan. 'The thing that always attracted me to New York was the sense of being in a place where a lot of people had a lot of stories not unlike mine,' Rushdie says. 'Everybody comes from somewhere else. Everyone's got a Polish grandmother, some kind of metamorphosis in their family circumstances. That's a very big thing - the experience of not living where you started. It changes you in all kinds of ways.'

London did not spur his imagination. 'I think it speaks for itself that, for somebody who lived in England for as long as I did, relatively little of my work has dealt with it.' New York holds more promise. 'There's so much stuff just asking me to write it down here,' he says. 'You know, all the furniture on the street. What places are called. Everything has a different name. Toothpaste isn't called the same thing, coffee isn't called the same thing. I just walk into a supermarket here, and I'm having to look in a detailed way at stuff that everyone else would take for granted.'

In April of last year, Rushdie had an operation for ptosis, a condition in which the eyelids sag to the point of impeding vision. The metaphor is not hard to tease out: Rushdie wanted to meet Manhattan with wide-open eyes. 'Discovery is fun,' he says. 'I am incredibly open to everything.' Others have seen the surgery, which has given him a younger look, as an act of vanity, the sign of a man in midlife crisis. Rushdie's social life has done nothing to dispel that interpretation.

Though still married, he is dating a 29-year-old model. He seems to be everywhere. He is a regular at all the clubs of the moment; he was at the premiere of Madonna's latest movie. 'It just seems that the demarcations are less here,' he says. 'In London, you tend to find the actors are here and the artists are there and the writers are over here and there's not that much crossover between those worlds. Whereas here, I have very rapidly got to know people across all of those frontiers.'

He says he is relieved that New York has less of the 'backbiting and incestuous' literary culture of London. He had dinner in April with Thomas Pynchon and discussed baseball. He knew a bit about this, having already gone to both of the city's ballparks. With Don DeLillo he went to a Yankees game. 'I must say, going to the ballgame with Don was one of the great things, because he goes with his mitt. He's up there for every fly ball.' Paul Auster in turn took him to see the Mets, 'because that's his orientation'.

He also socialises with the British Empire's community of New York transplants, among them the Australian-born novelist Peter Carey, the Caribbean-born novelist Caryl Phillips and the Indian-born Sonny Mehta, the president of Knopf, who has published all of them. Rushdie remembers something Mehta said to him after his own first year in New York. 'He said, "You know, Salman, for people like you and me, it's a very good idea at some point to leave the British Empire." And I think he's absolutely right.'

I mention Padma Lakshmi, the Madras-born model he met last August at the inaugural party for Talk magazine. 'Things are very good as far as Padma and I are concerned,' he says. 'We're both happy.' Their outings make news in the gossip columns.

He looks at his watch on the table. He had been writing all morning and is eager to go home and get back to work. He is a new man, Ferdinand washed up on the fabulous island of The Tempest - or maybe Balzac's Lucien de Rubempre, who left the provinces to take on Paris. Except Rushdie's own novels show how hard it is to leave the past behind. When Rushdie came to New York, he left his wife Elizabeth West, and their three-year-old son, Milan. A 21-year-old son, Zafar, from an earlier marriage, and to whom he is close, also lives in England. He returns frequently to visit them.

The fatwa lives on, too, at least as a memory. He is subjected to comments by matre d's and bystanders. The comments are primarily joking, but no one, it seems, wants to be entirely safe around Rushdie. If people were, his celebrity might lose its currency.

He complains that the newspapers give a misleading picture of his life. He spends most of his time, he says, going to ordinary neighbourhoods, dining at small restaurants and going for long walks, absorbing the city in places where 'the gossip columnists and the paparazzi aren't'. Before him always is the writer's imperative to be open to new experience. 'Until you find stuff out, you can't know what you think about it,' he says. 'The more places you can put yourself in... the better.'

I point out that some writers are dismayed at his behaviour. People died because of his words. They think he owes the world gravitas. Is it proper for him to feel, as he says, 'lighter of heart' these days? After the fatwa, Martin Amis commented that his friend had disappeared on to the front page. Now he has reappeared on the gossip page. Fay Weldon says: 'Salman has made his home among the posers.' His friend Bill Buford, an editor at the New Yorker, points out that Rushdie has never done things by half measure. The paradox of the fatwa is that he was the last writer you could hide. 'Here's how Salman goes to a concert,' says Buford, who has been to several with him. 'He goes. He gets good seats. He gets up and boogies.'

Rushdie does not like to talk about what he should do differently. He is at his core a writer, a man who sees life through stories. If you try to dictate the story of his life, you make him angry. In a sense, that's what the Ayatollah did, and that's what those who object to his current lifestyle are now doing.

'My view is: to hell with that,' he says. 'This is my life, and I'll make my choices. I'm a big-city boy. What I like is big cities. It's not just what I like. It's what I write about.' He says his time in New York is all going into the grinder in preparation for literary production.

He recently signed a contract with Random House for five books. The first, the one he is working on, is a thriller about a man who may or may not have committed a murder. The old part, the 'back story', is in Bombay. The new, 'the present moment', is in New York.

This will be New York's second appearance in Rushdie's fiction. The city was also in The Ground Beneath Her Feet. In reviewing it, most critics focused on the story as a retelling of the myth of Orpheus and Eurydice. Rushdie says it was also a meditation on 'three great cities' - Bombay, London and New York.

In the novel, Bombay, where Rushdie was born to wealthy Muslim parents, comes in for extensive and loving handling. It is infused with the elegant magic with which he captured the city in his great second novel, Midnight's Children. London seems very much a place to get through, a transit port, just as it did in The Satanic Verses. New York, however, is the subject of adoration.

'Where this city leads,' Rushdie writes, 'this Rome, all the world's cities follow.' Yet the novel's portrayal of the city feels hazy. His New York is the New York of cliché, with the biggest, tallest and most beautiful of everything.

This first time around, he didn't find his New York,a New York special to him. He just recapitulated the New York that has long existed in the British literary mind, the New York of English literature from Fanny Trollope to Martin Amis. As a literary construct, it did not feel new. Rushdie wrote The Ground Beneath Her Feet while living in London and summering in East Hampton. He was just a visitor here. It was before those meandering walks in the park and those nights in nightclubs. As time goes by, he may see a different city, a sister city to Bombay with its polyglot culture and endless, fecund migrations. No one can foresee how the city will act on his imagination. Rushdie, the most imaginative and fractured of English-language novelists, says he is ready for whatever comes. 'I think the moment we're living in is a sort of a hinge moment in all sorts of ways - historically, technologically, socially. It's a moment of great transformation, and I intend to put a story in that moment.' The eyes are wide. 'If you want to live in a city in the world, you may as well live in this one.'

webTitle: Germain Greer: The spread of pornography is a poison in our culture

fields.headline: Gluttons for porn
fields.standfirst: The spread of pornography into the mainstream is not, as liberal voices argue, a victory for freedom of expression but a poison in our culture - and we develop a taste for it at our peril
fields.trailText: The spread of pornography into the mainstream is not, as liberal voices argue, a victory for freedom of expression but a poison in our culture - and we develop a taste for it at our peril.
fields.body:
On 5 March this year, Lolo Ferrari finally succeeded in dying, though most of the visitors to the 33,200 Lolo Ferrari websites neither know that nor care. The process of self-destruction had begun long before, when she was Eve Valois, of a good middle-class Breton family. She was 16 and had never been out with a boy when she caught the eye of a 38-year-old used-car dealer who was looking to change his line of business. They were barely married before, Svengali to her Trilby, he put her to work posing for photos de charme, as the French call them, and began designing the new body that would make her a porn superstar.

After 22 operations, Lolo Ferrari had a Michael Jackson nose so tiny that she couldn't breathe through it; bulging synthetic cheekbones; a mouth so swollen with collagen that she could hardly form intelligible words; and huge spherical breast implants that weighed 2.8 kilos apiece and compressed her ribcage so much that she was running on one-quarter of her lung capacity. Designing her breast cones had involved complex fleshly engineering which was carried out, as you would expect, by a surgeon who specialises in sex changes.

Lolo wanted to be buried under her huge breasts, in a white coffin, wearing her favourite pink ballgown with her teddy bear in her arms. Vigne said he was grief-stricken by her loss, but it will make no material difference to his life. By the time she died at 30 - half-crazy, incapable of leaving her house, living on a diet of cola, cabbage soup and prescription drugs - Lolo 2000 had already generated his stock-in-trade, the image bank that will provide a good income for the rest of his life.

The cool post-liberal consensus about pornography misses the point. Pornography has nothing to do with freedom of expression: it is primarily business, a ruthless impersonal industry based on the sound maxims that a) there is one born every minute; and b) you should never give a sucker an even break. It uses and abuses not only the boys and girls who provide the imagery, but also the fantasy-ridden sub-potent public, mostly male, that pays for its product.

New guidelines covering both mainstream movies and hard-core videos sold through sex shops mean we can now lawfully watch more pornography. There are virtually no constraints on the level of explicit sex in films now, and in R18 videos, close-up shots of penetration by penis, finger, tongue or sex toy, ejaculation, oral-genital contact and masturbation have become legal. But legal or illegal hardly matters, except that illegal, like all crime, pays better for less work. Can pornography go any further? Yes, it can. Can it go too far? No, it can't. As far as male sexual fantasy is concerned there is no too far.

Illicit porn is the trailblazer. Where it goes, legitimate media must follow if they are not to allow the unscrupulous to walk away with the lion's share of the profits, and ultimately the whole business. If cult movies can generate for nothing the kind of media interest that costs mainstream movies millions to pump up, mainstream movies will copy them - slowly, goodness knows, but inevitably. No matter how much froth and bubble there is around the question of what children may and may not be allowed to see, the real problem is what the parent generation demands to be shown. As long as there is demand, the porn industry will be there to serve it. As long as there are cigarettes, kids will smoke them. As long as daddy keeps tit mags and porn videos in his sock drawer, his kids will look at them. The notion that kids can exist in one world while their parents exist in another is a peculiarly English delusion.

Historically and etymologically, pornography is simply the advertising of prostitution. It is therefore distinct from obscenity. Obscenity is the depiction of what may not be seen. Some, but by no means all, pornography is obscene; a good deal of obscenity is not in the least pornographic. The spectacle of the hero pulling down his trousers and doing a dump on his next door neighbour's lawn in the Jim Carrey film Me Myself and Irene, released this week, is obscene but not pornographic. Likewise, the sight of his alter ego, the wicked Hank, sucking on one hugely engorged breast protruding from a lactating mother's nursing bra, while her baby feeds at the other, is revolting, but not pornographic - unless you are the kind of guy who cannot get an erection if he is not wearing nappies and being suckled.

A great deal of pornography caters for niche markets of just this kind, and is totally unarousing to people whose sexuality has not been kinked in that direction. Minority sexual preferences are usually classed as paraphilias and dubbed abnormal; the permissive society tended to accept paraphilias as an essential aspect of human sexual activity. 'Whatever turns you on' was what you were entitled to in the innocent Sixties, before the lid had been taken off and we had a sight of the can of worms that is human sexuality. What the sex reformers of the Sixties thought they were liberating was people's desire to pleasure each other; what they were not prepared for was the intensity of the need that many people have to hurt each other, and even to harm each other, if they are to get any closer to their own brain-sucking orgasm also known as 'great sex'.

The inbuilt problem in the 'whatever turns you on' creed is that what turns one person on does not necessarily turn on his partner. The prostitute who caters to the nappy-wearers might not herself get off on suckling stubbly men, but she was, is, happy to provide the service if, and only if, she is handsomely paid for it. (By the way, 'lolo' is the French baby word for mother's milk.) Very few women develop paraphiliac interests; some say this is because their sexuality is still repressed, and that as they begin to share power and to identify their own sexual interests, they too will begin to demand exotic sexual services. The reality is that most women participate in sex games because there is no other route by which they can enter into what passes for intimacy with the person they love. In the sex industry the customer calls the shots; the purveyor of sexual services, like the purveyor of food or entertainment, like anyone working in any service industry, is in it for the money, but to succeed must give the vivid impression that she really enjoys what she is doing, whether she is sucking a dildo or whipping a stockbroker. Many sex workers find the faking of pleasure a service too far, and draw the line at pretending to enjoy whatever it is the client wants them to do. In an unfree society, most of the activities called consensual represent the capitulation of the powerless to the demands of the powerful. Power comes in various guises, as money, status, patriarchy, and as emotional invulnerability.

The purpose of pornography is to arouse desire in the absence of desire, to raise appetite where no hunger exists, so as to provide a market in which the purveyors of pleasure can make their living and their profits. Where need exists, there is no necessity to stimulate demand; where no need exists, enticing imagery must be used to create demand. People who have no desire to eat a piece of bread and butter, because they are not hungry, can be stimulated to desire chocolate if the chocolate is presented to them as something more than food, as ecstasy, rhapsody or orgasm. Chocolate is a fattening comestible marketed as if it were a drug; when foodstuffs from apple pies to processed cheeses are presented as causing euphoria, it is the drug experience that is presented as the way to wellbeing. Commercially produced food is also fake food, not made principally of the substances mentioned on the label, but with chemical analogues and fillers, and laced with taste additives and excessive amounts of salt and sweeteners. Your healthy yoghurt-coated apricot pieces are mostly vegetable fat and sugar, neither of which is mentioned on the label. In a similar way, commercial fast sex is fake sex, divorced from both passion and reproduction. Food advertising sells fantasy food and sex advertising sells fantasy sex.

Just as the advertising of fast food and confectionery has eliminated appetite so that no one now knows what it is to work up an appetite, or that hunger is the best sauce to any food, pornography has eliminated desire. Food marketing has brought eating disorders upon us, and it is as likely that sex marketing will have the same consequences. We already gorge and starve on sex, so that love-making becomes displacement activity - fetishistic, obsessive-compulsive and deeply pointless. The analogy with sex and drugs soon became obvious; we began with alcoholics who abuse one kind of drug, and moved to chocoholics who abuse another, and from heroin addicts to sex addicts.

There was a time within living memory when for most people, fast food and fast sex were both unattainable. The nation had much less food and much less sex than it has now, but it is very possible that it enjoyed both food and sex more than it does now. Pleasure, like pain, is difficult to quantify; one could never prove that we are having more sex but of poorer quality in 2000 than in 1950, any more than we could prove that potatoes really did taste better 50 years ago, but enjoyment and rarity do seem to be connected in the human psyche, if in a curiously problematic way. An orgasm prolonged for more than a few minutes would soon begin to pall. Routine sex is just that. If you drink champagne once a year, are you more likely to find it delicious than if you drink it every day? Or are you more likely to be disappointed and think that it is not the drink it is cracked up to be? The pleasure principle takes intelligent management; we need to know what to expect from our champagne, how to judge good champagne from bad, and when and where and how fast to drink it.

Sex is much more complicated than champagne, especially if two people or more are involved. A wine buff has to learn his pleasure by experiment and also by study; pornography might be thought of as the information system that shows the sex buff how to enjoy sex. There are important differences; the literature of wine cannot give us the sensations of drinking or having drunk; gratification must be delayed. webTitle: Twins' parents seek a quarter million pounds for story

fields.headline: Twins' parents seek a quarter million pounds for story
fields.standfirst:
Conjoined twins information sites:
Twinstuff.com
Conjoined twins
fields.trailText: The parents of the Siamese twins at the centre of a bitter legal battle over whether doctors should have the right to separate the girls are in secret talks to sell their harrowing story for up to half a million pounds.
fields.body:
The parents of the Siamese twins at the centre of a bitter legal battle over whether doctors should have the right to separate the girls are in secret talks to sell their harrowing story for up to half a million pounds.

A family friend, who is supporting the parents while the courts decide the fate of Jodie and Mary, is negotiating on their behalf with tabloid newspapers. The parents are believed to be asking for up to £250,000, but it is thought they are only likely to receive half that sum.

The parents say they will give up their anonymity and agree to be photographed when the injunction imposed by the courts is lifted.

Sources close to the family say the fee would be put in a trust fund to pay medical bills and to support Jodie if the House of Lords upholds Friday's decision by three Appeal Court judges that surgeons should separate the twins, resulting in the death of Mary.

The Manchester firm of solicitors, Pannone and Partners, confirmed yesterday that negotiations concerning the rights to the story were under way.

A spokesman said the money could 'be extremely useful to the parents. I think that is why these discussions have raised their head at this stage'.

The family friend, who is acting as a middleman, cannot be named because of the injunction. He is 64 and a wealthy builder who lives with his wife and two grown-up children in a village in the Midlands.

He and his wife, aged 61, own a holiday flat in the parents' home village on the island of Gozo, Malta, and have known them for more than 10 years. Once he heard of the couple's plight, he offered to help and bought air tickets to fly them to Manchester to find treatment for the twins.

Friends say that he is distraught that his decision has ended in the court wrangle that is set to go on for months before the House of Lords, Britain's highest court, delivers its ruling.

Called upon to make the agonising choice between the surgeon's knife and 'the will of God', three Appeal Court judges ruled that the operation should go ahead.

The parents, who are devout Roman Catholics, believe that the girls should be allowed do die 'if that is the will of God'.

fields.headline: A blonde who isn't bland
fields.standfirst:
Special report: the future of the BBC
MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: So Panorama is being dumbed down because one solitary episode of it is being presented by a 37-year-old woman with a husky voice and blonde hair. If only Mariella Frostrup had had the sense to be born with testicles. But then, of course, she can't have any sense because she's a bit of a babe.
fields.body:
So Panorama is being dumbed down because one solitary episode of it is being presented by a 37-year-old woman with a husky voice and blonde hair. If only Mariella Frostrup had had the sense to be born with testicles. But then, of course, she can't have any sense because she's a bit of a babe.

She is reporting on the phenomenon of reality television in the light of the hugely successful Big Brother. I would suggest she is eminently qualified. She's intelligent and will appeal to a wider audience than Panorama traditionally attracts. And at the moment, it needs all the help it can get if what we read about viewing figures is anything to go by. If Johnny Vaughan had been asked to do the programme, I reckon there would have been some discreet backslapping going on.

As it is, we have the dreich chorus shrieking about a 'lightweight film presenter' being elevated well beyond her abilities. Shame on her. If only she'd stick to that pigeonhole, but she will keep getting out of the coop.

And please let's not talk about serious journalistic credentials here. This is a television programme about television. Okay, so it goes into the realms of psychology, but it's not an undercover report on shady companies flogging torture implements to the Third World.

What you need is intelligence and a thirst for information. Anyone who's spent time with Mariella will know that she possesses both. To hear the comments, you'd think she'd spent her adult life reading Jackie and doing the odd bit of topiary on her nails. Instead of which, she's just finished presenting the arts programme Edinburgh Nights and is currently trawling through several dozen novels as a judge for the Booker Prize.

I read in one newspaper that a senior current affairs insider at ITV (male, by any chance?) dismissed her as 'blonde totty'. Such a pity she's not dark haired: 'brunette totty' just doesn't sound nearly derogatory enough. Should we be at all surprised, though?

Women have made great strides in the media. When I was in my teens, I used to dream of being Katharine Whitehorn on The Observer. There were very few major female icons in journalism. Jean Rook on the Express and Jilly Cooper on the Sunday Times, perhaps. And on television it was wall-to-wall men, with occasional women sidekicks. Then came Angela Rippon and Anna Ford. And Joan Bakewell and Esther Rantzen. It was a time when it was cool to be a feminist. We had the sisterhood and women were on the march. We could go right to the top.

Next it was lad culture. Well, it was there before, it was merely sulking in the undergrowth. And all of a sudden we had women on television because they wanted to get to the top so badly they'd take their tops off. Unfortunately, the result was a setback for women in the media. Want to be taken seriously? For God's sake don't smile or have celebrity friends. And NEVER go blonde.

I happen to think that choosing Mariella for a Panorama programme is inspired. If there was a programme about barristers, why shouldn't a top, sexy barrister present it? Tony Blair, for example? Oops, sorry, investigative journalism credentials lacking.

And yet, there is an eminent (male) TV newsreader not famous within the industry for being needle witted, whose name would not have raised an eyebrow had he been asked to do a Panorama programme. But then, he doesn't have blonde hair and ovaries.

A friend of mine spent months presenting a rolling news programme with a man whose lack of insight led to the comment that in his case, 'still waters run shallow'. You could gaze deep into his eyes and all you'd see would be the back of his head.

But day after day he was given the juicy interview. And day after day, he'd ask the questions no journalist would dare to ask. Because they were too idiotic. It took weeks before anyone in charge realised he was dim.

It does seem that a woman - particularly one who's chosen to go blonde - is guilty of being thick until proved thinnocent.

Penny Smith is a journalist and presenter

webTitle: BBC bans Trevor Phillips for political link

fields.headline: BBC bans Trevor Phillips for political link
fields.standfirst:
MediaGuardian.co.uk
Special report: the future of the BBC
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: One of Britain's most highly acclaimed black broadcasters has been banned from the BBC because of his close links with the Labour Party.
fields.body:
One of Britain's most highly acclaimed black broadcasters has been banned from the BBC because of his close links with the Labour Party.

Leaked letters obtained by The Observer reveal that Trevor Phillips, Frank Dobson's running mate in the London mayoral elections, has been told by the Director-General, Greg Dyke, that rules on impartiality make it too dangerous to allow him to continue working for the organisation.

Phillips's supporters argue that the Labour peer, Lord Bragg, regularly presents programmes for the BBC and that well-known Conservatives who have worked for the BBC include Michael Portillo, the Shadow Chancellor, and Peter Ainsworth, the Shadow Culture Secretary.

The Labour MPs, Austin Mitchell and Ken Livingstone, and former Conservative MP David Mellor have also appeared.

It has been pointed out that Phillips was believed to be one of the few regular black broadcasters on Radio 4, where his science programme, Material World, was highly regarded.

Friends of Phillips say Dyke's move reveals intense sensitivity about the issue of political bias at the BBC. It has been criticised by the Conservative Party, which accuses it of being anti-Tory and pro-euro.

The corporation was also attacked when it was announced that the former Observer commentator, Andrew Marr, who is connected with senior figures in the Labour Party, had been appointed as the BBC's new Political Editor.

Dyke himself gave £50,000 to the Labour Party before becoming Director-General.

In a series of letters written last June and passed to The Observer by a senior BBC executive, Phillips, who has received three distinguished Royal Television Society awards for his broadcasting work, reveals his own fury at the decision. 'Yes, I am aggrieved. No, I do not understand the problem,' he writes to Dyke.

Phillips, who is now the Labour chairman of the Greater London Assembly, was responding to a letter from Dyke in which the Director-General says the broadcaster will no longer present programmes.

Dyke says: 'The BBC's first duty is not just to preserve our impartiality but also to be perceived to preserve our impartiality, and that does make it difficult for elected politicians who have fought high-profile election campaigns to combine their political careers with regular presentation commitments.'

Responding to a question from Phillips asking if he had been dropped because he was not up to standard, Dyke wrote: 'The reason the BBC did not tell you that the programme [ Material World ] had benefited from your absence, or that you had become a lesser broadcaster than previously, was simply that that was not the case.

It has been criticised by the Conservative Party, which accuses it of being anti-Tory and pro-euro. webTitle: Muted farewell for one who lived her life loudly

fields.headline: Muted farewell for one who lived her life loudly
fields.trailText: Tiger lilies swamped the white and silver coffin, while at its foot nestled a small posy of pink roses bearing the words 'To Mummy, I Love You'.
fields.byline: by Tracy McVeigh and Nick Paton Walsh
fields.body:
Tiger lilies swamped the white and silver coffin, while at its foot nestled a small posy of pink roses bearing the words 'To Mummy, I Love You'.

Paula Yates made her final journey yesterday from the twelfth-century St Mary Magdalene church in the picturesque village of Davington in Kent, where 14 years ago she stood in a red dress and veil for her marriage to Bob Geldof to be blessed.

In the cars that swept past the small crowd outside the church grounds on their way to the crematorium, her four daughters sat next to a visibly drawn Geldof.

Wearing white, four-year-old Tiger Lily gazed out through the back window, cradled in the arms of Jean Marine, Geldof's girlfriend, while her half-sisters sat sombrely on the back seat. The eldest, Fifi Trixibelle, 17, wept as her car drove away.

It had been a fittingly star-studded service. The tightest of security was ordered by Geldof and provided by his friend Matthew Freud's public relations firm.

The black-suited star ensured that only the 450 named on the guest list could file into the small chapel which backs onto Geldof's home, Davington Priory, a house Yates had loved, where she had spent 13 years of her life but failed to find enduring happiness.

Even details of the service were afterwards kept secret, again on orders from Geldof, although the organist and choir from Canterbury Cathedral said a Keats poem was read by family friends and Jools Holland played piano while Bono, lead singer of Irish rock band U2, sang 'Blue Skies'. Holland helped choose the traditional music and had the choir sing 'Ave Maria', 'Jerusalem', music from Fauré's Requiem, and 'I Vow To Thee My Country'.

In the congregation sat many of the famous people, including musicians Annie Lennox, Jasper Conran, Nick Cave, Paul Young, Roger Taylor and Kevin Godley, who had formed Yates's wide circle of friends in life and who had shared the shock of her daughters at her sudden and tragic death.

The 41-year-old television presenter was found dead in the bed of her London home a week ago today by Tiger Lily. The cause of death has yet to be established officially, although quantities of alcohol and drugs, including heroin, were found in her bloodstream.

It was an untimely end for a woman who was teetotal for much of her life and had been devoted to her children.

But the traumas of the last five years of her life had been great: the loss of her lover Michael Hutchence, the bitter custody struggle she lost for her three children by Geldof, and the shattering revelation that the man who fathered her was not Jess Yates but in fact Hughie Green, the late TV game show host.

Her estranged mother, Helene Thornton, who Yates said had betrayed her, arrived at the funeral yesterday by taxi. She joined actor Rupert Everett, the DJ Paul Gambaccini, and the media mogul Waheed Alli together with other mourners in Geldof's garden, adjoining the church grounds, where drinks were served by uniformed waitresses after the 50-minute service.

Only those closest to her - the children, Geldof and Marine, her friend Belinda Brewin, and a few others, accompanied Paula Yates's body to the crematorium where a five-minute ceremony marked the final farewell for one of Britain's most colourful and vibrant personalities.

webTitle: British woman free after jail horror in Cuba

fields.headline: British woman free after jail horror in Cuba
fields.trailText: A frail Rachel McGee arrived back in Britain yesterday after her unexpected release from a Cuban jail where she had been held for drug trafficking.
fields.body:
A frail Rachel McGee arrived back in Britain yesterday after her unexpected release from a Cuban jail where she had been held for drug trafficking.

She and fellow prisoner Michelle Malcolm, both 24 and from London, had their 15-year sentences annulled by the Cuban government after being held for almost two years in squalid and filthy conditions. Malcolm, who travelled with McGee, left London's Gatwick airport unnoticed.

McGee, who had been sick throughout the flight home, was supported by her younger brother Michael and half-sister Katie and looked pale and drawn as she spoke briefly of her new found freedom. 'It's unbelievable. There are no words to describe it,' she said.

McGee and Malcolm shared a cell in the women's prison near Havana which was infested with rats and cockroaches. The pair existed on a meagre diet of milk, bananas and crackers.

McGee's lawyer, Steven Jakobi, described his client as 'very ill' and said she was expected to be treated for suspected dysentery at the Hospital for Tropical Diseases in London. McGee's weight is down to six stone and she has kidney and stomach problems. Malcolm's state of health is not known.

McGee's Irish-born mother, Maureen, led a high-profile campaign for the release of her daughter, who has always maintained her innocence.

Maureen McGee said it was wonderful to see her daughter again: 'I feel like I have won the pools.'

McGee and Malcolm were arrested in 1998 in a drugs swoop that netted £9 million worth of cocaine. Two British men, Karite Clacher and Desmond Gordon, and four Jamaicans remain in prison.
